Section Title: OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We operate a significant store estate of 614 stores (excluding standalone PFSs) that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). The graph below compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers. (Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020. *Ocado Market share shown.) We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. See also "Industry." One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to "Every Day Low Price" and our wholly-owned supplier, IPL, which enables us to take a vertically-integrated approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers and our team of flexible and engaged colleagues. Historically, we have benefited from the support of Walmart, our former parent company. We will continue to receive support from Walmart over the next three years pursuant to the Transitional Agreements negotiated in connection with the Acquisition. For more information about the ongoing support to be provided by Walmart, please see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions— _Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_ ### 23 ----- We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended December 31, 2019, our revenue was approximately £22.9 billion (including petrol), of which approximately £2 billion was online sales, and our Adjusted EBITDA was approximately £1.2 billion (including petrol). The chart below presents the breakdown of our 2019 revenue by product category (food, general merchandise, clothing and petrol), food category (ambient and fresh and produce) and channel (stores and online (including George.com)). (Source: ASDA information. Year ended December 31, 2019. Note: Does not include £61 million of other revenue.) Our differentiated operating model has resulted in strong financial performance: our successful financial profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. In 2018 and 2019, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 5.5% (including petrol), our cumulative free cash flow was approximately £1.7 billion and our average cash conversion was approximately 70%. The charts below show our EBITDA Margins, Adjusted EBITDA Margins, Unadjusted Cash Conversion ("Unadjusted Cash Conversion" is calculated as Unadjusted Free Cash Flow divided by EBITDA) and Unadjusted Free Cash Flow ("Unadjusted Free Cash Flow" is calculated as EBITDA less capital expenditure) for the years ended December 31, 2015 to December 31, 2019 and our cash conversion and free cash flow for the years ended December 31, 2018 to December 31, 2019. (Source: ASDA information.) ### 24 ----- (Source: ASDA information.) We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our significant freehold real estate asset portfolio. See "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing." We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we maintain a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. Within the UK value market, we have strong market shares across ambient products (13.0%), fresh/chilled (11.6%) and total grocery (12.2%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). Our offer is strong across the full food basket: our category market shares range from 12% to 14% (except household and toiletries) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal ASDA data, our prices are approximately 6% to 7.5% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on a 2020 year-to-date (weeks 1-42) average, based on total goods price gap percentage). Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is supplemented by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food and non-food products to customers as a convenient "one-stop shop" experience that is supported and enhanced by our strong online offer. We believe our omni-channel offer, through which we reach customers at our brick-and-mortar stores, through our significant online offering and on our app, appeals to our customers. In 2020, there were approximately 9.8 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February 28, 2020), and approximately 723,000 weekly orders post COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended September 30, 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has increased use of and engagement with our online platforms and we currently fulfil approximately 720,000 online orders per week. Our online grocery business operates from 350 stores, we offer at-home delivery and customers are also able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 ASDA Click & Collect sites. We are also expanding our 1-hour Click & Collect offer. Our business model integrates our store-based and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders. ### 25 ----- Our online grocery business is profitable and has been consistently gaining market share within one of the world's most developed online grocery markets. We have consistently outperformed the UK online grocery market and increased our online market share in the last three years. According to Kantar, we currently operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, holding 18.2% of market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) as of December 2019, which grew to 19.8% as of December 27, 2020 (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales), representing a 1.5% gain and the second-strongest share gain since December 2019 amongst our key competitors. The chart below shows the evolution of our market share as compared with our key competitors for the periods presented. See also "Industry." (Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the year-to-date as of December 27, 2020 as compared to the 52-week periods through December 31 for 2017, 2018 and 2019.) Our online business is already of significant scale: the chart below shows the growth of our online sales, including a breakdown of online grocery versus George.com sales, for the periods presented. (Source: ASDA information.) According to Kantar, we are the second-largest online clothing retailer overall by volume in the United Kingdom and we held 6.0% of the total UK online clothing (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) market by volume for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020. Combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £1.9 billion in 2019 (of which £1.6 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales) to a total of £2.7 billion for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 (of which £2.4 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 26% between 2018 and September 30, 2020. Additionally, our toyou service allows customers to conveniently collect and return orders from George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 119 brands and process more than 10 million parcels per year. With our team of approximately 140,000 flexible and engaged colleagues serving approximately 15 million customers each week (based on the average of weeks 39 to 42 of 2020), we are committed to and deeply invested in the UK food supply chain. Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the entire UK population, in terms of both customer demographics and geography, with our customer base ### 26 ----- skewing slightly towards value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers who are attracted by our Every Day Low Price strategy and with strong market shares in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. For more information about our customer mix, see "—Our Customers," and for more information about the geographic distribution of our stores, see "—Our Real Estate Portfolio." Second, we believe we are well-positioned geographically, with a strong regional footprint across the United Kingdom. Our store footprint is strongest in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Our large and diverse store estate offers customers a variety of differentiated shopping formats. We operate 30 supercentres, 396 superstores, 155 supermarkets and 33 ASDA Living stores. For more information on our stores, see "— _Our Store Formats."_ Subject to receipt of regulatory approvals, our 18 standalone PFSs and 305 co-located PFSs (including both their underlying real estate assets and their business operations) will be sold to EG Group pursuant to the Forecourt Business Disposal. However, to the extent we are required to do so in order to obtain regulatory approval for the Acquisition, we will sell all or part of our forecourt business to third parties. In addition, we will transfer to Propco 2 (or an affiliate) the real estate relating to the Warehouse Assets, and to the extent required pursuant to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets promptly following the CMA Clearance Date. We will continue to operate the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets pursuant to the ASDA Leases which will be put in place in accordance with the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. For more information, see "The Transactions—The _Post Completion Disposals." This "Business" section, including historical statements herein, principally_ relates the ASDA's business as it will be following the completion of the Transactions. Following the completion of the Acquisition, we will continue to benefit over the next three years from support provided by Walmart, the world's largest retailer, through the Transitional Agreements. See "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart." In addition to the Transitional Agreements, we have also agreed with Walmart to set up_ separation planning working groups to ensure a smooth transition. Our ongoing relationship with Walmart is expected to bring a number of benefits, in particular: ## • Information and technology support to facilitate the change from the Walmart ecosystem; • Deep research and development expertise and capabilities; • Global sourcing, leveraging Walmart's sourcing capabilities in clothing and general merchandise; • Best practices, leveraging Walmart's expertise and experience as a leading global retailer; and • Long-term support and continued partnership with Walmart's management and leadership.

Section Title: KEY STRENGTHS
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we benefit from the following strengths, including being a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance, a differentiated operating model, a successful financial profile and a significant asset backing, as further described below. We believe that we benefit from the following strengths, including being a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance, a differentiated operating model, a successful financial profile and a significant asset backing, as further described below.

Section Title: BUSINESS STRATEGY
Subsection Title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS COVID-19 Update
Subsubsection Text: Structural shifts due to COVID-19 have led to increased overall growth in the grocery retail market. During the COVID-19 pandemic, customer behaviour has changed, with a shift away from out-of-home food consumption towards at-home food consumption, to the benefit of the UK grocery market. The chart below shows COVID-19-accelerated channel shifts over the periods presented. For further information on prevailing trends in the UK grocery retail market and, in particular, the recent channel shifts which have been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, please see "Industry." (Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.) Grocery sales have grown by 12.3% between December 1, 2019 and December 27, 2020, according to Kantar, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales. Changes to consumer behaviour that have positively benefitted the grocery market during the COVID-19 pandemic include: increased consumption of food at home, a shift to online shopping channels, increased preference for shopping locally, in particular during the first UK lockdown (which we believe benefitted retail groups with a strong convenience store presence), and an increased focus on food safety, hygiene and health. Despite significant challenges posed by COVID-19, our business has remained resilient, supported by a well-developed online channel, which saw significant growth during government-imposed lockdowns as customer behaviour evolved. We were able to quickly increase the capacity of our online offer in response to increased demand driven by the pandemic, gaining market share and improving the profitability of our online business. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have benefitted from healthy revenue growth driven by higher food sales volumes (which were in turn driven by stockpiling and increased customer demand for in-home groceries via the online grocery channel), while margins contracted due to adverse changes in sales and product mix resulting from decreases in clothing sales, which impacted the George Clothing brand, the temporary closure of 33 ASDA Living stores and the shift in product mix within the food category away from higher-margin categories, such as food-to-go, and towards lower-margin categories, such as beer, wine and spirits and meat, which factors were partially offset by lower levels of promotional activity and stronger general merchandise sales. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories. Profitability was also adversely impacted by COVID-19-related increases in operating costs, such as the increase in retail colleague wage costs (driven by bonus payments, overtime wages and wages paid colleagues absent from work due to COVID19, as well as wages paid to colleagues who worked during such sick colleagues' absences, rather than as a result of increased wage rates), increased costs incurred in connection with goodwill compensation paid to clothing suppliers, holiday markdowns, enhanced cleaning and related health and safety measures, as well as higher retail operating expenditures. We have considered the outbreak of COVID-19 to be a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event: the 207 ----- impact on future results and cash flows is difficult to estimate and we have therefore considered a range of scenarios as described in note 1 ("Accounting Policies") of the 2019 Financial Statements. See "Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—The impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to create uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control."_ We took significant steps during the first twelve weeks of the first lockdown period in the spring of 2020 to protect our most vulnerable colleagues, asking them to remain home on contracted pay in order to ensure their safety, while we increased social-distancing and protective measures at our stores. When we welcomed these colleagues back, we carried out individual risk assessments and conducted socialdistancing training for them. In September 2020, we further tightened our safety measures across our stores to provide an enhanced level of protection to our customers and colleagues, introducing new door marshals at the front of stores and increasing security presence in the aisles of larger stores; marshals also provide sanitised baskets to customers as they enter stores. Colleagues continue to be on hand to help customers with safety queries and reiterate government guidelines to wear a face covering and maintain social distancing while they shop. Customers who do not have a face covering when they enter the store are offered a pack of disposable masks that they can pay for as they complete their shopping. Additional hand sanitisation stations are in place in the busiest sections of all stores in addition to the multiple cleaning points already found throughout stores. Should current safety guidelines continue, we believe that it is unlikely that we will continue to incur a significant portion of the additional costs in the future that we incurred in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic during the first two lockdowns, as many of these costs incurred were one-off in nature. The chart below shows the COVID-19 impacts for ASDA on a year-to-date basis as of September 30, 2020. (1) "GNFR" refers to goods not for resale. (Source: ASDA information.) In March 2020, as part of a number of measures to support businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK government, the Scottish government and the devolved administrations for Wales and Northern Ireland announced full relief for rates charges applicable to certain eligible commercial properties for the rates year beginning in April 2020 (and in the case of Northern Ireland, such support ended after July 2020). This relief applied to a number of properties owned or leased by the Group and as such, no rates charge has been recognised in these accounts for the period to which this relief applied. On December 3, 2020, we publicly announced that we would voluntarily pay business rates for the April 2020/21 year on the properties to which the relief applied. As rates relief was in place at September 30, 2020, no liability existed at that date and as such, our directors have concluded that the announcement on December 3, 2020 is a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event per the guidance set out in IAS 10. Discussions with the relevant local authorities relating to the timing of payment are ongoing. 208 -----

Section Title: BUSINESS STRATEGY
Subsubsection Text: Our primary strategy is designed to "win on price" by narrowing our price gap with discounters (such as Aldi and Lidl) while providing good value and maintaining our price leadership position against our traditional grocery peers, which we expect to further enhance customer loyalty. We aim to provide a consistent, trusted experience, incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere, through the creation of attractive store propositions and partnerships that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while increasing the number of self-serve opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth where customers care, expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience. Our primary strategy is designed to "win on price" by narrowing our price gap with discounters (such as Aldi and Lidl) while providing good value and maintaining our price leadership position against our traditional grocery peers, which we expect to further enhance customer loyalty. We aim to provide a consistent, trusted experience, incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere, through the creation of attractive store propositions and partnerships that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while increasing the number of self-serve opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth where customers care, expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience.

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: The Transactions
Subsubsection Text: On October 2, 2020, the Issa Brothers and TDR Capital (the "Shareholders") caused their jointly controlled entity, Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited (the "Purchaser"), to enter into the Acquisition Agreement with the Seller, a subsidiary of Walmart, pursuant to which the Purchaser committed to acquire all of the issued ordinary shares of the Company on the Acquisition Completion Date (the "Acquisition"). The Purchaser, a limited company formed under the laws of Jersey, is an indirect, wholly-owned subsidiary ### 33 ----- of the Issuers. It was formed by the Shareholders solely for the purpose of engaging in the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement and has not commenced any operations, other than as set forth in the Acquisition Agreement. Pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement, the consideration payable by the Purchaser on the Acquisition Completion Date will be £6,614.0 million (assuming an Acquisition Completion Date of February 16, 2021) (the "Purchase Consideration"). Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Seller was required to use commercially reasonable endeavours to cause the Company to make distributions to the Seller or other Walmart Group Companies of at least £1,769.5 million prior to the Acquisition Completion Date. On December 21, 2020, the Company approved a distribution of £1,769.5 million to ASDA Holdings UK Limited, of which £1,269.5 million was a distribution in specie through the transfer of intercompany receivables and £500.0 million was settled in cash. On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Company will settle outstanding intercompany payables due by the ASDA Group to Walmart Group Companies in cash. The Acquisition Agreement includes customary warranties by the Seller and the Purchaser. The Seller and the Purchaser have also separately agreed on a dedicated indemnification regime applicable to any losses arising from the Equal Value Claims. As contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition will be completed following receipt of the FCA's approval, but during the pendency of the review of the Acquisition by the CMA, which is the competition authority that has the authority to review the Acquisition following referral by the European Commission. The CMA's review is ongoing. Currently, the CMA is conducting its phase 1 inquiry into the Acquisition. If the CMA identifies competition-related concerns over the course of this phase 1 inquiry, we intend to propose remedies to address these concerns, which may include the sale of certain PFS sites to unaffiliated third parties. See "—The Post-Completion _Transactions—Forecourt Disposals." However, there can be no assurance that any remedies we may_ propose will be acceptable to the CMA. If the remedies we may propose are rejected, the CMA Clearance Date could be significantly delayed and more extensive remedies may be required from us, which could potentially include a mandated sale of the ASDA Group. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the _Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties and risks, which could adversely impact recoveries under the Notes."_ In connection with the CMA's review of the Acquisition, we expect the CMA to issue an IEO shortly before or immediately after Completion, which we expect to remain in force until the CMA Clearance Date. Under this IEO, the Bellis Group will not be permitted to exercise de facto control over the ASDA Group or otherwise direct its operations until the CMA Clearance Date. As a result, although we acquired the ASDA Group on the Acquisition Completion Date, we will not effectively control the ASDA Group until the CMA Clearance Date. Furthermore, while the IEO is in effect, it will prevent us from making any significant structural or organisational changes to the ASDA Group, including the Forecourt Business Disposal, the Excluded Forecourt Divestments or any other Post-Completion Transactions, unless we seek and obtain a derogation from the CMA. Accordingly, we do not intend to initiate these post-completion transactions until the CMA Clearance Date.

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: The Transactions
Subsubsection Text: _The Financing in the event that the Acquisition Completion Date occurs prior to the Issue Date_ We expect to settle the Offering after the consummation of the Acquisition. In this case, we expect to fund our payment of the Purchase Consideration on the Acquisition Completion Date using the Equity Contribution (including Walmart's Rollover Equity Investment) and amounts drawn under the Senior Facilities, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, the Senior Bridge Facility and the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities (the "Initial Financing") and the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. On the Issue Date, we will then use the proceeds from the Offering to repay a portion of the Initial Financing, including all amounts drawn under the Senior Bridge Facility and the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities (together with the Initial Financing and the other related transactions described in this section of the Offering Memorandum, the "Financing"). See "Use of Proceeds." _Utilisations of Senior Bridge Facility_ On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Senior Notes Issuer expects to draw the full amount of the Senior Bridge Facility under the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement and to on-lend the amounts received to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer under the Senior Financing Proceeds Loan. See "Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements."_ ### 34 ----- _Utilisations of Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility_ On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer expects to draw the full amount of the Term Loan Facilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will on-lend the net proceeds from these drawings along with funds received from the Senior Notes Issuer under the Senior Financing Proceeds Loan to the Purchaser, to be used as described in "Use of Proceeds." See "Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements." Utilisation of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility_ On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower expects to draw £950 million under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, which will be on-lent by way of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Proceeds Loan to Midco 2. Midco 2 and its subsidiaries, in turn, will on-lend the net proceeds of the drawing to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer pursuant to a deeply subordinated instrument, to be used as described in "Use of Proceeds." See "Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility." To secure the Distribution Asset_ Disposal Bridge Facility, certain entities within the ASDA Group will grant first priority mortgages, fixed charges or standard securities, as applicable, over the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent required thereunder, certain Substitute Retail Assets, as well as first-ranking pledges on the Designated Bank Accounts. Prior to the execution of these mortgages, fixed charges, standard securities and pledges, as applicable, entities within the ASDA Group are expected to enter into lease agreements in respect of the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets on substantially the terms summarised in "Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions―ASDA Leases." The Equity Contribution_ In connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders and Walmart will cause Bellis TopCo Limited and its subsidiaries to contribute to the equity of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or on-lend to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer pursuant to deeply subordinated instruments approximately £1,280 million in aggregate (the "Equity Contribution"), which includes the proceeds of Walmart's £500 million Rollover Equity Investment and £780 million of funds raised by the Shareholders. _The Offering and the repayment of the bridge loans_ On the Issue Date, the Senior Notes Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Notes to repay all amounts outstanding under the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement, and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Secured Notes to repay all amounts outstanding under the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement. See "Use of Proceeds." _Estimated cash and cash equivalents as of the Acquisition Completion Date_ On or about the Acquisition Completion Date, ASDA will settle in cash intercompany loans owed to Walmart of £409.0 million. In addition, on December 3, 2020, the Company announced that it will pay in full its business rates for the UK tax year ending April 5, 2021 to the UK government (and the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland), thus waiving the relief it had received earlier in 2020 in respect of such payment as part of the UK government's measures in support of UK businesses in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is estimated to be within a range of £320 million to £340 million. As a result, the Company expects to pay £254 million in retrospective business rates for the period from April to December 2020, to be funded from cash available on the Company's balance sheet. The Company expects to engage in due course with the competent UK authorities to discuss and agree the exact terms of such payment, including its timing. ASDA also plans to resume its regular payments of the business rates on a monthly basis commencing with the month of January 2021. The Company estimates that its average cash and cash equivalents from January 4 to February 2, 2021 (inclusive), as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Acquisition Completion Date and excluding the amount earmarked to retrospectively pay business rates tax relief accepted from the UK government for the period to December 31, 2020 was £505.6 million. ASDA's net working capital for the month of January tends to be slightly lower than the yearly average due to the customary seasonal dip in stock levels and the build-up of trade payables to suppliers in the early part of each financial year following the Christmas trading period. ASDA's actual cash and cash equivalents available as of the Acquisition Completion Date may however be different. ### 35 ----- _The Financing in the event that the Issue Date occurs prior to, or substantially concurrently with, the Acquisition Completion Date_ It is possible that the Acquisition Completion Date may be delayed until after the Issue Date, including due to the timing of our receipt of the FCA's approval of the Acquisition. In this case, unless the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition, we will, pending completion of the Acquisition, fund the gross proceeds of the Offering into Escrow Accounts, which will be held in the name of the relevant Issuer, but controlled by the relevant Escrow Agent, and pledged in favour of the relevant Trustee on behalf of and for the benefit of the holders of the relevant Notes, pursuant to the terms of the Escrow Agreements and Escrow Account Charges dated on or before the Issue Date. Under the terms of the Escrow Agreements, release of the Escrowed Proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including the completion of the Acquisition and the solvency of the relevant Issuer. Following release from escrow, we expect to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with the Equity Contribution and amounts drawn under the Senior Facilities, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility and the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility (as described above and in "Use of Proceeds.") to fund our payment of the Purchase Consideration on the Acquisition Completion Date. In the event we deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Accounts on the Issue Date and the Acquisition Completion Date has not occurred, or the conditions to the release of such Escrowed Proceeds have not been satisfied, on or before the Outside Date, Midco has not elected to extend the initial Shortfall Agreement Termination Date (or any extension thereof) and the Release has not occurred as at such date or in certain other circumstances, subject to certain conditions, the Notes will be mandatorily redeemable at a price equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date to, but not including, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date and Additional Amounts, if any. If the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the completion of the Acquisition, we will forgo these escrow procedures and will instead retain the proceeds of the Offering to fund part of the consideration payable under the Acquisition Agreement on the Acquisition Completion Date. See "Use of _Proceeds," "Description of the Senior Notes—Acquisition Agreement, Timing of Completion Date and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds" and "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Acquisition Agreement, Timing of Completion Date and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds."_

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: The Transactions
Subsubsection Text: _Warehouse and Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility_ Following the CMA Clearance Date, ASDA will transfer the Warehouse Assets, the balances credited to the Designated Bank Accounts, and to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets, to Propco 2 or other affiliates who are obligors thereunder (the "Post-Completion Disposals") in exchange for consideration left outstanding (the "Post-Completion Disposal Receivables"). Alternatively, Select Retail Assets and, as relevant, Substitute Retail Assets may remain held by the ASDA Group but will continue to be charged in favour of the lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility as described in the paragraph below. ASDA will agree to subordinate its claims against Propco 2 or such other affiliates to those of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility pursuant to a separate subordination agreement. The transfers of each of the Warehouse Assets and, to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets in connection with the PostCompletion Disposals will be subject to the ASDA Leases, which will remain in effect. To the extent any part of a Substitute Retail Asset or a Select Retail Asset comprises a Forecourt Asset, following the CMA Clearance Date, if documents are agreed by such date, that part of the ASDA Lease which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be surrendered (or, as applicable, renounced) and any security affecting that part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be released such that the intention is for the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset to be transferred to Propco 2 or its affiliates (to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility) to exclude the title to the Forecourt Asset which will be retained by ASDA by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation. If any relevant Substitute Retail Asset or Select Retail Asset remains held by the ASDA Group at the time of the Forecourt Business Disposal, that part of the ASDA Lease which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be surrendered (or, as applicable, renounced) and any security affecting that part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be released and the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility will permit the disposal of the Forecourt Asset pursuant to the terms of the Forecourt SPA by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation such that the remaining part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset excludes the title to that Forecourt Asset. After the Forecourt Business Disposal has been completed, (to the extent the Post-Completion Disposals were made to Propco 2, rather than to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower, following the CMA Clearance Date) we expect Midco 2 to transfer Bellis Select Warehouse Holdings Limited ("Propco ### 36 -----

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: The Transactions
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, references to the "Transactions" are to the (i) Acquisition and our performance of all obligations contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, (ii) Financing and (iii) PostCompletion Transactions, collectively, (with each of (i) through (iii) and any subcomponent thereof or other transaction or intermediate step reasonably necessary to consummate any of the foregoing, a "Transaction").

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: 1") to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower, in consideration of repayment of the
Subsubsection Text: outstanding balance of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Proceeds Loan. Please see "Summary Corporate and Financing Structure." Because certain third-party consents, approvals or certifications in relation to the grant of an ASDA Lease, the grant of Third-Party Asset Security in respect of one or more Warehouse Assets or, in each case, the registration of any such ASDA Lease or grant of Third-Party Asset Security may remain outstanding at a cut-off point prior to the Acquisition Completion Date, entities in the ASDA Group owning such Warehouse Assets may not be able to grant an ASDA Lease or grant Third-Party Asset Security in respect of such Warehouse Assets at the relevant time. In this case, on or about the Acquisition Completion Date, entities in the ASDA Group will enter into ASDA Leases in respect of one of more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the aggregate value of the Affected Warehouse Assets and grant Third-Party Asset Security over such Substitute Retail Assets to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. In the event that the Land Registry (or jurisdictional equivalent) will not register any Third-Party Asset Security because a deed of covenant is not in the prescribed form due to changes required by the security agent under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility or third-party authorisations are outstanding (in each case in respect of a Warehouse Asset), then an ASDA Lease will be granted instead in respect of a Substitute Retail Asset of approximately equivalent value and Third-Party Security will be granted over such Substitute Retail Asset. See "The Transactions—Post-Completion Transactions— _Warehouse and Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility." If,_ prior to the CMA Clearance Date, outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications are received to permit the grant of an ASDA Lease, the grant of Third-Party Asset Security or the registration of either of the following (as the case may be) in respect of any Affected Warehouse Asset, entities in the ASDA Group will enter into an ASDA Lease in respect of such Affected Warehouse Asset (to the extent not already entered into) and grant Third-Party Asset Security over such Affected Warehouse Asset (to the extent not already granted) to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. Third-Party Asset Security which was granted on or about the Acquisition Completion Date over one or more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the value of that Affected Warehouse Asset will then be released and discharged, subject to the Third-Party Asset Security in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset being successfully registered at the Land Registry (or its jurisdictional equivalent) in favour of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. If, following the CMA Clearance Date, requisite third-party consents, approvals or certifications in relation to the transfer of one or more Warehouse Assets (in respect of which either an ASDA Lease and Third-Party Asset Security have been granted or an ASDA Lease has been granted and requisite thirdparty consents, approvals or certifications in relation to the grant of any first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities to be granted by Propco 2 or other affiliates (and the registration of the foregoing) have been obtained) pursuant to the Post-Completion Disposals or the registration of any transfer in respect of such Warehouse Assets remain outstanding, entities in the ASDA Group will enter into ASDA Leases in respect of one of more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the aggregate value of such Affected Warehouse Assets. Entities in the ASDA Group that own such Substitute Retail Assets will grant Third-Party Asset Security in respect of such Substitute Retail Assets. To the extent required by the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, such Substitute Retail Assets will be transferred to Propco 2 or other affiliates pursuant to the Post-Completion Disposals to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. Alternatively, such assets may remain held by the ASDA Group but continue to be charged in favour of the lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. If, following the date of the Post-Completion Disposals, outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications are received to permit the grant of an ASDA Lease, the transfer to and the grant of firstranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities (to the extent that Affected Warehouse Asset is not transferred subject to existing Third-Party Asset Security) by Propco 2 or other affiliates in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset, entities in the ASDA Group will enter into an ASDA Lease in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset (to the extent not already entered into) and transfer the Affected Warehouse Asset to Propco 2 or other affiliates, which will grant (unless the Affected Warehouse Asset is transferred subject to existing Third-Party Asset Security) a first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of it to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. First-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities which were granted over one or more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the value of that Affected Warehouse Asset will then be released and discharged, subject to the first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed ### 37 ----- charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset being successfully registered at the Land Registry (or its jurisdictional equivalent) in favour of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. See "The Transactions—Post-Completion Transactions—Warehouse and _Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility."_ If outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications are received following the CMA Clearance Date to permit the grant of an ASDA Lease and the transfer of an Affected Warehouse Asset to Propco 2 or other affiliates, but not the grant of a first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, such Affected Warehouse Asset may nevertheless be transferred to Propco 2 or other affiliates. If, following such transfer, outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications are received to permit the grant of first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities by Propco 2 or other affiliates, and the registration of the foregoing in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset, Propco 2 or other affiliates will grant a first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of them to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. First-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities which were granted over one or more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the value of that Affected Warehouse Asset will then be released and discharged, subject to the first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset being successfully registered at the Land Registry (or its jurisdictional equivalent) in favour of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. If following the transfer of a Warehouse Asset, Select Retail Asset and/or Substitute Retail Asset to Propco 2 or other affiliates, the ASDA Lease granted in respect of such asset is not held by ASL, the relevant tenant is required under the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement to assign the ASDA Lease to ASL with the intent that all ASDA Leases in respect of Warehouse Assets, Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets held by Propco 2 or other affiliates are held by ASL. If, following the transfer of a Substitute Retail Asset to Propco 2 or other affiliates, first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities which were granted over that Substitute Retail Asset are released, Propco 2 or other affiliates may transfer such Substitute Retail Asset to the ASDA Group in advance of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility being repaid in full. The initial term of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility is one year from the Acquisition Completion Date, with the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower retaining an option to extend it for a further six months at its own discretion. The Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility has no scheduled amortisation and we intend to repay it in full ahead of maturity primarily with the net proceeds from the Warehouse Sale Transactions we expect to consummate before and after the transfer of Bellis Select Warehouse Holdings Limited to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower, which would have to be applied promptly in mandatory prepayment of the facility. Depending on market conditions and expected transaction values, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower or Propco 2, as applicable, may also sell some or all of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets (in each case subject to ASDA Leases), the proceeds of which would also have to be applied in mandatory prepayment of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. We anticipate that the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower (or Propco 2, as may be the case) will return to the Issuers, by way of contribution to their equity, in-kind loan pursuant to a deeply subordinated instrument or repayment of Post-Completion Disposal Receivables held by the Group, any Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets that it does not sell to repay the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, and, to the extent such proceeds are not used to repay amounts outstanding under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, amounts equal to any net proceeds directly or indirectly received from the sale of any Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets (including any Retail Asset Disposal Proceeds) (the "Retail Assets Contributions"). After the Retail Assets Contributions have been made, we expect to distribute any remaining Post-Completion Disposal Receivables to Topco, in the amounts that remain outstanding at the time, by way of dividends in kind and anticipate that Topco would then arrange for such receivables to be extinguished by contribution to Propco 2. Subject to certain limitations, the Post-Completion Disposals and the in-kind distribution of the Post-Completion Receivables will be permitted by the Indentures and the Senior Facilities Agreement notwithstanding the restrictive covenants or other terms that would otherwise apply to such transactions. Moreover, these distributions will not constitute Restricted Payments under the Indentures and the Senior Facilities Agreement and will not reduce the Issuers' capacity to make distributions or pay dividends in the future. See "Description of _the Senior Secured Notes—General—Restricted Subsidiaries and Unrestricted Subsidiaries; Extraction of_ ### 38 ----- _Warehouse Assets and Select Retail Assets" and "Description of the Senior Notes—General—Restricted Subsidiaries and Unrestricted Subsidiaries; Extraction of Warehouse Assets and Select Retail Assets."_ In connection with sale transactions entered into by the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower, we may be required to amend the terms of the ASDA Leases. Such amendments will be permitted under the Indentures and the Senior Facilities Agreement, subject to compliance with the covenants described in "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on _Affiliate Transactions" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions." Forecourt Disposals_ On February 3, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and Bellis Forecourts Limited entered into the Forecourt SPA, whereby the Senior Secured Notes Issuer undertook to sell to Bellis Forecourts Limited the share capital of Acquisition 2 or any other member of the Bellis Group or a member of the ASDA Group that holds the Forecourt Business, directly or indirectly, following the Acquisition Completion Date, the CMA Clearance Date and completion of the acquisition by Acquisition 2 (or such other company) of the Forecourt Business. Pursuant to a separate agreement, the EG Forecourt SPA, entered into on or about the same date, Property Newco agreed to sell to Euro Garages Limited the share capital of Holdco (owning in turn Bellis Forecourts Limited and therefore the Forecourt Business) promptly upon closing under the Forecourt SPA. Property Newco may assign such separate agreement to the shareholders (i.e., Optima Group S.à r.l. and Able Holdings Limited), who may sell Property Newco itself, rather than Holdco or one of its subsidiaries. In preparation for, and prior to, the closing of the Forecourt SPA, we expect that ASDA will distribute the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as soon as practicable following the CMA Clearance Date. In order to effect the distribution of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as a dividend in kind, ASDA will have to arrange for the separation of the freehold or leasehold title to its co-located forecourts (comprising the vast majority of the Forecourt Assets) from the parent title currently comprising adjacent store or retail assets or sites by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation and the entities within the ASDA Group that currently hold non-co-located Forecourt Assets will need to distribute such assets to Acquisition 2. We expect that the process of effecting these title separations and distributions to take several months following the Acquisition Completion Date. The headline enterprise value established under the Forecourt SPA, subject to customary working capital adjustments, is £750 million, less the aggregate value of any Excluded Forecourts (and of any other assets relating to the Excluded Forecourts). The consideration will be left outstanding at the closing of the Forecourt SPA (the "Forecourt Disposal Receivable") and we expect it to be ultimately settled in cash and in full promptly following the closing of the EG Forecourt SPA. See "Certain Relationships and Related _Party Transactions—Forecourt SPA." The parties may decide to novate and assign the Forecourt SPA to_ another member of the Bellis Group or a member of the ASDA Group (as seller) and to a member of the EG Group (as buyer), in which case the separate agreement between Property Newco and Euro Garages Limited would be terminated and the Forecourt Business (or a holding company thereof) would be sold directly to EG Group by the ASDA Group. The IEO that is expected to be issued by the CMA will not permit us to sell any Forecourt Assets pursuant to the Forecourt SPA for so long as the IEO remains in force. Consequently, we do not expect to consummate the Forecourt Business Disposal before the CMA Clearance Date. The Forecourt SPA requires us to complete the transactions contemplated thereunder as soon as reasonably practicable following the satisfaction of the conditions precedent stipulated in its terms, which include the IEO to be issued by the CMA ceasing to be in effect. The CMA's investigation of the Acquisition is ongoing, and we may be required to take remedial action to address any competition-related concerns the CMA may identify. If remedies prove necessary, we may be required to designate certain Forecourt Assets (along with certain related assets) as Excluded Forecourts and sell them to unaffiliated third parties (the "Excluded Forecourt Divestments"). Although we will attempt to carry out the Excluded Forecourt Divestments by way of orderly sales following a competitive sales process, there can be no assurance that the market conditions or circumstances of the Excluded Forecourt Divestments will permit such an outcome, and the price we receive for any Excluded Forecourts sold through the Excluded Forecourt Divestments may be less than what we would have ultimately received in a fully voluntary sale. In addition, third parties may have rights over the Forecourt Assets (including rights to acquire and pre-emption rights) exercisable in the event of a transfer of the Forecourt Assets (whether of the freehold or leasehold interest or of whole or part). In all such cases, the transfer of those Forecourt Assets may be significantly delayed, prevented in part or prevented entirely. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties _and risks, which could adversely impact recoveries under the Notes."_ ### 39 ----- Under the terms of the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, the proceeds from the sale of both the Forecourt Business Disposal and the Excluded Forecourt Divestment must be used to repay amounts outstanding under the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility until it has been repaid in full. See "Description _of Certain Financing Arrangements—Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility."_

On the Issue Date, we will then use the proceeds from the Offering to repay amounts drawn under the Senior Bridge Facility and Senior Secured Bridge Facilities. Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: The Issuers
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a public limited company incorporated and existing under the laws of England and Wales. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is resident in the United Kingdom for tax purposes. The registered name of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is Bellis Acquisition Company plc and it was incorporated on September 3, 2020 under registration number 12855280 and re-registered as a public limited company on December 18, 2020 for the purpose of consummating the Transactions. Its registered office and its principal place of business is Waterside Head Office, Haslingden Road, Guide Blackburn, Lancashire BB1 2FA, United Kingdom. The Senior Notes Issuer is a public limited company incorporated and existing under the laws of England and Wales. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is resident in the United Kingdom for tax purposes. The registered name of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is Bellis Finco plc and it was incorporated on September 3, 2020 under registration number 12855336 and re-registered as a public limited company on December 21, 2020 for the purpose of consummating the Transactions. Its registered office and its principal place of business is Waterside Head Office, Haslingden Road, Guide Blackburn, Lancashire BB1 2FA, United Kingdom.

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: The Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE have been active in the forecourt and convenience retail sector since the acquisition of a single petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001. Following a merger of their UK-based Euro Garages business with TDR Capital LLP's EFR Group in 2016, EG Group was established, which the Issa Brothers now lead as co-CEOs. The business, globally headquartered in Blackburn, United Kingdom, has an established pedigree of delivering a world class fuel, grocery & merchandise and foodservice offering and currently employs in excess of 44,000 people working in more than 6,000 sites across Europe, USA and Australia. The Issa Brothers were honoured as Commanders of the Order of the British Empire by HM The Queen in her Birthday Honours List 2020 for their contribution to business and charity. They were also jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United Kingdom. TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing over €10.0 billion of committed capital across three European buyout funds. Founded in 2002 by Manjit Dale and Stephen Robertson, TDR Capital LLP has been creating value by applying a high-impact approach to investing in a focused portfolio of companies. TDR Capital LLP has a proven value-based and operationally focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of investment and operating professionals from its single office in London. TDR's strong returns have been driven by combining ambitious operational plans for portfolio companies with a rigorous focus on capital preservation. TDR Capital LLP takes an active role in overseeing the transformation and growth of its investments, working in partnership with management through board representation and professional support. To date, TDR Capital LLP has completed 22 investments across the leisure, consumer, business and financial services sectors. Walmart Inc. helps people around the world save money and live better – anytime and anywhere – by providing the opportunity to shop in retail stores and through eCommerce. Each week, Walmart serves over 265 million customers who visit approximately 11,400 stores and numerous eCommerce websites under 55 banners in 26 countries. Walmart is engaged in global operations of retail, wholesale and other units, as well as eCommerce, located throughout the U.S., Africa, Canada, Central America, Chile, China, India, Japan, Mexico and the United Kingdom. ### 43 -----

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS COVID-19 Update
Subsubsection Text: _The unaudited preliminary financial results presented below are derived from the Company's unaudited management accounts. This information has not been audited or reviewed, nor have any procedures been performed by the Company's independent auditors with respect thereto, and it has not been prepared with a view towards compliance with IFRS. Accordingly, you should not place undue reliance on it, and no opinion or any other form of assurance is provided with respect thereto. The Company's unaudited preliminary financial results are based upon a number of assumptions and judgments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and are subject to change, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of the Company's financial or operational results for the 12 months ended December 31, 2020. Although the Company believes the management estimates and unaudited preliminary financial information and the assumptions on which they are based to be reasonable, the Company's actual results as of and for the 12- month period ending December 31, 2020 to be published in the coming months may vary from the information contained above and such variations could be material._ Based on preliminary, unaudited management accounts of ASDA, like-for-like sales growth (excluding petrol) for the eight weeks through December 24, 2020 was 6.9%, as compared to the same dates in 2019. We expect that EBITDA for ASDA for the year to December 31, 2020 will be in line with internal expectations, adjusted for the charges relating to business rates which arise from our announcement on December 3, 2020 to forgo COVID-19 business rates relief. ### 46 -----

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsection Title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS COVID-19 Update
Subsubsection Text: Structural shifts due to COVID-19 have led to increased overall growth in the grocery retail market. During the COVID-19 pandemic, customer behaviour has changed, with a shift away from out-of-home food consumption towards at-home food consumption, to the benefit of the UK grocery market. The chart below shows COVID-19-accelerated channel shifts over the periods presented. For further information on prevailing trends in the UK grocery retail market and, in particular, the recent channel shifts which have been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, please see "Industry." (Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.) Grocery sales have grown by 12.3% between December 1, 2019 and December 27, 2020, according to Kantar, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales. Changes to consumer behaviour that have positively benefitted the grocery market during the COVID-19 pandemic include: increased consumption of food at home, a shift to online shopping channels, increased preference for shopping locally, in particular during the first UK lockdown (which we believe benefitted retail groups with a strong convenience store presence), and an increased focus on food safety, hygiene and health. Despite significant challenges posed by COVID-19, our business has remained resilient, supported by a well-developed online channel, which saw significant growth during government-imposed lockdowns as customer behaviour evolved. We were able to quickly increase the capacity of our online offer in response to increased demand driven by the pandemic, gaining market share and improving the profitability of our online business. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have benefitted from healthy revenue growth driven by higher food sales volumes (which were in turn driven by stockpiling and increased customer demand for in-home groceries via the online grocery channel), while margins contracted due to adverse changes in sales and product mix resulting from decreases in clothing sales, which impacted the George Clothing brand, the temporary closure of 33 ASDA Living stores and the shift in product mix within the food category away from higher-margin categories, such as food-to-go, and towards lower-margin categories, such as beer, wine and spirits and meat, which factors were partially offset by lower levels of promotional activity and stronger general merchandise sales. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories. Profitability was also adversely impacted by COVID-19-related increases in operating costs, such as the increase in retail colleague wage costs (driven by bonus payments, overtime wages and wages paid colleagues absent from work due to COVID-19, as well as wages paid to colleagues who worked during such sick colleagues' absences, rather than as a result of increased wage rates), increased costs incurred in connection with goodwill compensation paid to clothing suppliers, holiday markdowns, enhanced cleaning and related health and safety measures, as well as higher retail operating expenditures. We have considered the outbreak of COVID-19 to be a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event: the impact on future results and cash flows is difficult to estimate and we have therefore considered a range of scenarios as described in note 1 ("Accounting Policies") of the 2019 Financial Statements. See "Risk ### 44 ----- _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—The impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to create uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control."_ We took significant steps during the first twelve weeks of the first lockdown period in the spring of 2020 to protect our most vulnerable colleagues, asking them to remain home on contracted pay in order to ensure their safety, while we increased social-distancing and protective measures at our stores. When we welcomed these colleagues back, we carried out individual risk assessments and conducted socialdistancing training for them. In September 2020, we further tightened our safety measures across our stores to provide an enhanced level of protection to our customers and colleagues, introducing new door marshals at the front of stores and increasing security presence in the aisles of larger stores; marshals also provide sanitised baskets to customers as they enter stores. Colleagues continue to be on hand to help customers with safety queries and reiterate government guidelines to wear a face covering and maintain social distancing while they shop. Customers who do not have a face covering when they enter the store are offered a pack of disposable masks that they can pay for as they complete their shopping. Additional hand sanitisation stations are in place in the busiest sections of all stores in addition to the multiple cleaning points already found throughout stores. Should current safety guidelines continue, we believe that it is unlikely that we will continue to incur a significant portion of the additional costs in the future that we incurred in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic during the first two lockdowns, as many of these costs incurred were one-off in nature. The chart below shows the COVID-19 impacts for ASDA on a year-to-date basis as of September 30, 2020. (1) "GNFR" refers to goods not for resale. (Source: ASDA information.) In March 2020, as part of a number of measures to support businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK government, the Scottish government and the devolved administrations for Wales and Northern Ireland announced full relief for rates charges applicable to certain eligible commercial properties for the rates year beginning in April 2020 (and in the case of Northern Ireland, such support ended after July 2020). This relief applied to a number of properties owned or leased by the Group and as such, no rates charge has been recognised in these accounts for the period to which this relief applied. On December 3, 2020, we publicly announced that we would voluntarily pay business rates for the April 2020/21 year on the properties to which the relief applied. As rates relief was in place at September 30, 2020, no liability existed at that date and as such, our directors have concluded that the announcement on December 3, 2020 is a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event per the guidance set out in IAS 10. Discussions with the relevant local authorities relating to the timing of payment are ongoing. ### 45 -----

Section Title: HISTORY
Subsubsection Text: Headquartered in Leeds, we are an omni-channel retailer across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. We have built our business on listening to our diverse range of customers, offering what they need at the best value and bringing innovation to the UK market. ### 32 ----- We were founded in 1965 through the merger of the Asquith family grocery business with the Associated Dairies company in Yorkshire. Our name is derived from this historic merger, combining "Asquith" and "Dairies" to form "ASDA." Founded in the North of England, we have a rich history, heritage and culture. The Asquith family has deep ties to the grocery business, W.R. Asquith having run a butchers shop in Knottingly, West Yorkshire, which eventually expanded to seven shops. W.R. Asquith's sons, Peter and Fred, went on to create the United Kingdom's first self-service supermarket in Castleford, introducing food discounting to the UK grocery market, and eventually co-founded ASDA. In parallel to the growth of the Asquith family business, a group of West Riding dairy farmers joined forces, eventually becoming Associated Dairies & Farm Stores Limited led by Arthur Stockdale. Arthur's son, Sir Noel Stockdale, went on to co-found ASDA with Peter and Fred Asquith. In 1965, we acquired GEM, a major U.S. discount retailer operating in the United Kingdom. With the addition of general merchandise to the former GEM stores, we introduced the superstore to the UK market, a landmark event in the development of UK retailing. To complement this offer, Peter Asquith also introduced the first discounted petrol filling station. By 1970, we operated over 30 stores and were poised to expand beyond our original home in the North of England. Throughout the 1970s, we grew our presence in the South of England, opening stores in Newport, Plymouth and Gosport. In 1977, we launched our "ASDA Price" TV adverts, featuring the "pocket tap" which came to be the official sign language for ASDA. By the end of the 1970s, we were operating over 80 stores and opened our 100th store in 1981. Throughout the 1980s, we focused on expanding our distribution capabilities, opening seven new distribution centres strategically located throughout the United Kingdom by 1985. In 1987, our flagship Watford store opened, another landmark in UK retailing, and featured the longest-ever checkout bank at the time, with 45 checkouts. In 1988, we opened our headquarters in Leeds, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher overseeing the opening ceremonies. In 1989, George Davies was asked to produce a line of clothing for us that was high-quality, high-value and had its own identity: the pioneering George brand was born. In the 1990s, we developed the ASDA Way of Working, an innovative framework for a new organisational structure that focuses on our stores and promotes colleague involvement, which set the stage for the ASDA culture of today. In 1996, we opened our first ASDA Pharmacy location in Harrogate, North Yorkshire and launched our "Tickled Pink" campaign to raise money for the fight against breast cancer, a partnership that continues to this day. In 1998, we began our online retail operations with a dedicated depot in Croydon. In 1999, we joined the Walmart family, becoming part of the world's largest retailer. Throughout the early 2000s, we continued to grow and innovate, expanding our online and Click & Collect offers, opening our first ASDA Living store and our first Eco Store, winning awards for the value we offer customers as well as for the positive environment we create for colleagues, launching our Free From and Extra Special offers, launching standalone PFSs as well as ASDA Opticians. In 2015, we celebrated our 50th birthday and George's 25th birthday. In 2016, Roger Burnley joined our team as Chief Operating Officer and Deputy Chief Executive and was promoted in 2018 to President and CEO. ASDA has continued to roll out innovations, including the United Kingdom's first parcel tower, which allows customers to collect online orders in less than 60 seconds, and voice-activated shopping through Google Home. Our values are rooted in service to our customers, respect for the individual, striving for excellence and acting with integrity. We pursue our values with the support of our colleagues, culture and technology. Headquartered in Leeds, we are an omni-channel retailer across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Following the execution of the ASDA Leases, entities in the ASDA Group owning the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets will grant first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities by way of third-party security over such assets, to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility (the "Third-Party Asset Security"). Certain thirdparty consents, approvals or certifications may remain outstanding in relation to the grant of an ASDA Lease or the grant of Third-Party Asset Security in respect of one or more Affected Warehouse Assets or, in each case, the registration of any such ASDA Lease or Third-Party Asset Security. As a result, the entities in the ASDA Group owning the Affected Warehouse Assets may not be able to grant or register an ASDA Lease or grant or register Third-Party Asset Security in respect of such Affected Warehouse Assets on the Acquisition Completion Date. If not, entities in the ASDA Group will enter into ASDA Leases in respect of one of more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the aggregate value of the Affected Warehouse Assets and will grant Third-Party Asset Security over each of the relevant Substitute Retail Assets to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. See "The Transactions—The Post-Completion Transactions—Warehouse and Other Select Retail _Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility."_ In addition to the Third-Party Asset Security, each entity in the ASDA Group owning Warehouse Assets (or, to the extent applicable, certain Substitute Retail Assets), subject to an ASDA Lease will grant third-party security over its Designated Bank Accounts into which the rental income derived from the ASDA Leases in respect of the Warehouse Assets or Substitute Retail Assets is to be paid, to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. The security interests created by the security over the Designated Bank Accounts and the Third-Party Asset Security exclusively benefit the creditors and other secured parties under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. Accordingly, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes, and the Notes Guarantees in respect thereof, will be effectively subordinated to indebtedness under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility to the extent of the value of the Warehouse Assets and the Select Retail Assets (and, to the extent applicable, some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets depending on the value of any Affected Warehouse Assets) and of the value of the monies standing to the credit of each Designated Bank Account. (5) We are offering £500.0 million aggregate principal amount of Senior Notes. If we settle the Offering after the Acquisition Completion Date, we will draw the Term Loan Facilities, Senior Bridge Facility, Senior Secured Bridge Facilities and Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility to fund a portion of the consideration payable for the Acquisition on the Acquisition Completion Date and will repay a portion of the drawings under the Senior Bridge Facility with the proceeds of the Senior Notes on the Issue Date. If the Acquisition Completion Date is delayed until after the Issue Date, unless the Offering is consummated substantially concurrently with the Acquisition, we will fund the gross proceeds of the Senior Notes into an Escrow Account, which will be held in the name of the Senior Notes Issuer, but controlled by the relevant Escrow Agent, and pledged in favour of the Senior Notes Trustee on behalf of and for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Notes, pursuant to the terms of the relevant Escrow Agreement and Escrow Account Charge dated on or before the Issue Date. In that case, on or about the Acquisition Completion Date, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, the Escrowed Proceeds will be released from escrow and utilised to fund part of the consideration payable under the Acquisition Agreement. If the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the completion of the Acquisition, we will forgo the escrow procedures and will instead retain the proceeds of the Senior Notes to fund part of the consideration payable under the Acquisition Agreement on the Acquisition Completion Date. The Shared Security will also secure the Senior Secured Notes Issuer's obligations in respect of its Senior Notes Guarantees on a second-priority basis.
