(1) On February 3, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and Bellis Forecourts Limited entered into the Forecourt SPA, whereby the Senior Secured Notes Issuer undertook to sell the share capital of Acquisition 2 or any other subsidiary holding the Forecourt Business, directly or indirectly, to Bellis Forecourts Limited following the Acquisition Completion Date, the CMA Clearance Date and the acquisition of the Forecourt Business by Acquisition 2 or such other subsidiary. Pursuant to a separate agreement entered into on the same date, Property Newco agreed to sell to Euro Garages Limited (a member of the EG Group) the share capital of Holdco (which will in turn own Acquisition 2 and therefore the Forecourt Business) or any other entity holding, directly or indirectly, the Forecourt Business promptly upon closing under the Forecourt SPA. Property Newco may assign such separate agreement to the shareholders (i.e., Optima Group S.à r.l. and Able Holdings Limited), who may sell Property Newco itself, rather than Holdco or one of its subsidiaries. In preparation for, and prior to, closing under the Forecourt SPA, we expect that ASDA will distribute the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as soon as practicable following the CMA Clearance Date. In order to effect the distribution of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as a dividend in kind, ASDA will have to arrange for the separation of the freehold or leasehold title to its co-located forecourts (comprising the vast majority of the Forecourt Assets) from the parent title currently comprising adjacent store or retail assets or sites. The entities within the ASDA Group that currently hold Forecourt Assets will then distribute such assets to Acquisition 2. We ### 50 ----- expect the process of effecting these title separations and distributions to take several months following the Acquisition Completion Date. The headline enterprise value established under the Forecourt SPA, subject to customary working capital adjustments, is £750 million, less the aggregate value of the Excluded Forecourts (and of any other assets relating to the Excluded Forecourts). The consideration will be left outstanding at the closing of the Forecourt SPA (the "Forecourt Disposal

Subsubsection Text: or Property Newco pursuant to the separate agreement between Property Newco and Euro Garages Limited. See "Certain _Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Forecourt SPA."_ Following closing under the Forecourt SPA, assuming no novation and assignment thereof, Bellis Topco Sub Limited will acquire Midco from Holdco. The consideration for the transfer from Holdco will be the cancellation of Topco 2's class A shares in Holdco. In connection with this transfer, Bellis Topco Sub Limited will issue additional shares to Topco 2. Following this reorganisation (i) Bellis Topco Sub Limited will become the direct parent of Midco and an indirect parent of Midco 2, the Senior Notes Issuer, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Purchaser and the ASDA Group, (ii) Property Newco will be the sole shareholder in Holdco and (iii) Holdco's only direct subsidiary will be Bellis Forecourts Limited, which will be the direct parent of Acquisition 2. Holdco or Property Newco will then be acquired by EG Group and the Forecourt Disposal Receivable will be settled in cash, with the Senior Secured Notes Issuer being required under the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement to use the proceeds of such payment to repay all or a portion of the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility. As an alternative to the foregoing steps, the parties may decide to novate and assign the Forecourt SPA to the Company or one of its subsidiaries (as seller) and/or to a member of the EG Group (as buyer), in which case the separate agreement between Property Newco and Euro Garages Limited would be terminated and the Forecourt Business (or a holding company thereof) would be sold directly to EG Group by the ASDA Group. The proceeds of such sale would be applied following receipt by the ASDA Group to repay all or a portion of the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility. The transfer of the Forecourt Assets and the implementation of the Forecourt Business Disposal entail certain risks, and there can be no assurance we will be able to consummate these transactions as described herein or at all. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—We _may not be able to consummate the Post-Completion Transactions as quickly as we anticipate, or at all, and the manner in which we execute the Post-Completion Transactions may differ from what we present in this Offering Memorandum."_ (2) Following the CMA Clearance Date, ASDA will transfer the Warehouse Assets, the balances credited to the Designated Bank Accounts, and, to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement, some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets, to Bellis Select Warehouse Limited ("Propco 2") or other affiliates who are obligors thereunder (the "Post-Completion Disposals") in exchange for consideration left outstanding (the "Post**Completion Disposal Receivables"). Alternatively, Select Retail Assets and, as relevant, Substitute Retail Assets may remain held by the ASDA Group but will continue to be charged in favour of the lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility as described in the paragraph below. ASDA will agree to subordinate its claims against Propco 2 or such other affiliates to those of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility pursuant to a separate subordination agreement. The transfers of each of the Warehouse Assets and, to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets in connection with the Post-Completion Disposals will be subject to the ASDA Leases, which will remain in effect. To the extent any part of a Substitute Retail Asset or a Select Retail Asset comprises a Forecourt Asset, following the CMA Clearance Date, if documents are agreed by such date, that part of the ASDA Lease which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be surrendered (or, as applicable, renounced) and any security affecting that part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be released, such that the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset will be transferred to Propco 2 or its affiliates (to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility) without title to the Forecourt Asset, which will be retained by ASDA by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation. If any relevant Substitute Retail Asset or Select Retail Asset remains held by the ASDA Group at the time of the Forecourt Business Disposal, that part of the ASDA Lease which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be surrendered (or, as applicable, renounced) and any security affecting that part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be released and the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility will permit the disposal of the Forecourt Asset pursuant to the terms of the Forecourt SPA by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation such that the remaining part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset excludes the title to that Forecourt Asset. Because certain third-party consents, approvals or certifications in relation to the grant of an ASDA Lease, the grant of ThirdParty Asset Security in respect of one or more Warehouse Assets or, in each case, the registration of any such ASDA Lease or grant of Third-Party Asset Security may remain outstanding prior to the Acquisition Completion Date, entities in the ASDA Group owning such Warehouse Assets may not be able to grant an ASDA Lease or grant Third-Party Asset Security in respect of such Warehouse Assets at the relevant time. Instead, on or about the Acquisition Completion Date, entities in the ASDA Group may enter into ASDA Leases in respect of one of more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the aggregate value of the Affected Warehouse Assets and mortgage (or, as applicable, grant a standard security over) such Substitute Retail Assets to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. In the event that the Land Registry (or jurisdictional equivalent) will not register any Third-Party Asset Security because a deed of covenant is not in the prescribed form due to changes required by the security agent under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility or third-party authorisations are outstanding (in each case in respect of a Warehouse Asset), then an ASDA Lease will be granted instead in respect of a Substitute Retail Asset of approximately equivalent value and Third-Party Asset Security will be granted over such Substitute Retail Asset. See "The _Transactions—Post-Completion Transactions—Warehouse and Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility." If, prior to the CMA Clearance Date, outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications_ are received to permit the grant of an ASDA Lease, the grant of Third-Party Asset Security or the registration of either of the foregoing (as the case may be) in respect of any Affected Warehouse Asset, entities in the ASDA Group will enter into an ASDA Lease in respect of such assets (to the extent not already entered into) and will enter into Third-Party Asset Security (to the extent not already entered into) to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. Third-Party Asset Security which will be granted on or about the Acquisition Completion Date over one or more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the value of that Affected Warehouse Asset will then be released and discharged, subject to the Third-Party Asset Security in respect of that Affected Warehouse Asset being successfully registered at the Land Registry (or its jurisdictional equivalent) in favour of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. If, following the CMA Clearance Date, requisite third-party consents, approvals or certifications in relation to the transfer of one or more Warehouse Assets (in respect of which either an ASDA Lease and Third-Party Asset Security have been granted or an ASDA Lease has been granted and requisite third-party consents, approvals or certifications in relation to the grant of any first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities to be granted by Propco 2 or other affiliates (and the registration of the foregoing) have been obtained) pursuant to the Post-Completion Disposals or the ### 51 ----- registration of a transfer in respect of such assets remain outstanding, entities in the ASDA Group will enter into ASDA Leases in respect of one of more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the aggregate value of such Affected Warehouse Assets. Entities in the ASDA Group that own such Substitute Retail Assets will grant Third-Party Asset Security in respect of such Substitute Retail Assets. To the extent required by the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, such Substitute Retail Assets will be transferred to Propco 2 or other affiliates pursuant to the Post-Completion Disposals. Alternatively, such assets may remain held by the ASDA Group but continue to be charged in favour of the lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. If, following the date of the Post-Completion Disposals, outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications are received to permit the grant of an ASDA Lease, the transfer to and the grant of first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities (to the extent that Affected Warehouse Assets are not transferred subject to the existing Third-Party Asset Security) by Propco 2 or other affiliates, and the registration of the foregoing in respect of such Affected Warehouse Assets, the relevant entities in the ASDA Group will enter into an ASDA Lease in respect of the Affected Warehouse Assets (to the extent not already granted) and transfer the Affected Warehouse Assets to Propco 2 or other affiliates, which will grant (unless the Affected Warehouse Asset is transferred subject to existing Third-Party Asset Security) a first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of it to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. First-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities which were granted over one or more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the value of the Affected Warehouse Assets will then be released and discharged, subject to the first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of such Affected Warehouse Assets being successfully registered at the Land Registry (or its jurisdictional equivalent) in favour of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. See "The Transactions—Post-Completion Transactions— _Warehouse and Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility."_ If outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications are received following the CMA Clearance Date to permit the grant of an ASDA Lease and the transfer of Affected Warehouse Assets to Propco 2 or other affiliates, but not the grant of a first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of such Affected Warehouse Assets to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, such Affected Warehouse Assets may nevertheless be transferred to Propco 2 or other affiliates. If, following such transfer, outstanding third-party consents, approvals or certifications are received to permit the grant of first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities by Propco 2 or other affiliates, and the registration of the foregoing in respect of such Affected Warehouse Assets, Propco 2 or other affiliates will grant a first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of them to secure the obligations of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. First-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities which were granted over one or more Substitute Retail Assets with an aggregate value approximately equal to the value of such Affected Warehouse Asset will then be released and discharged, subject to the first-ranking legal mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security in respect of such Affected Warehouse Asset being successfully registered at the Land Registry (or its jurisdictional equivalent) in favour of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. If following the transfer of a Warehouse Asset, Select Retail Asset and/or Substitute Retail Asset to Propco 2 or other affiliates, the ASDA Lease granted in respect of such asset is not held by ASL, the relevant tenant is required under the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement to assign the ASDA Lease to ASL with the intent that all ASDA Leases in respect of Warehouse Assets, Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets held by Propco 2 or other affiliates are held by ASL. If, following the transfer of a Substitute Retail Asset to Propco 2 or other affiliates, first-ranking legal mortgages, fixed charges or, as applicable, standard securities which were granted over that Substitute Retail Asset are released, Propco 2 or other affiliates may transfer such Substitute Retail Asset to the ASDA Group in advance of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility being repaid in full. The initial term of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility is one year from the Acquisition Completion Date, with the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower retaining an option to extend it for a further six months at its own discretion. The Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility has no scheduled amortisation and we intend to repay it in full ahead of maturity primarily with the net proceeds from the Warehouse Sale Transactions, which would have to be applied promptly in mandatory prepayment of the facility. We may consummate Warehouse Sale Transactions before or after the transfer of Bellis Select Warehouse Holdings Limited to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower described in footnote 3 below. Depending on market conditions and expected transaction values, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower or Propco 2, as applicable, may also sell some or all of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets (in each case subject to ASDA Leases), the proceeds of which would also have to be applied in mandatory prepayment of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. We anticipate that the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower (or Propco 2, as may be the case) will return to the Issuers, by way of contribution to their equity, in-kind loan pursuant to a deeply subordinated instrument or repayment of Post-Completion Disposal Receivables held by the Group, any Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets that it does not sell to repay the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, and, to the extent such proceeds are not used to repay amounts outstanding under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, amounts equal to any net proceeds directly or indirectly received from the sale of any Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets (including any Retail Asset Disposal Proceeds) (the "Retail

Subsubsection Text: Completion Disposal Receivables to Topco, in the amounts that remain outstanding at the time, by way of dividends in kind, and Topco to then arrange for such receivables to be extinguished by contribution to Propco 2. In connection with sale transactions entered into by the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower, we may be required to amend the terms of the ASDA Leases. Such amendments will be permitted under the Indentures and the Senior Facilities Agreement, subject to compliance with the covenants described in "Description of the Senior Secured Notes— _Certain Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants— Limitation on Affiliate Transactions."_ (3) After the Forecourt Business Disposal has been completed, we expect Midco 2 to transfer Bellis Select Warehouse Holdings Limited (and, indirectly, Propco 2) to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower, in repayment of amounts outstanding under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Proceeds Loan.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes:
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes .......................... The Senior Secured Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, secured as set forth under "—Security;" - rank _pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future Indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including the Senior Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility; - rank senior in right of payment to any future Indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including the Senior Secured Notes Issuer's Guarantee of the Senior Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation (including obligations to trade creditors) of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its Subsidiaries that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes (including the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility for so long as the Warehouse Assets, Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets are held by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its Subsidiaries, and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, for so long as any Forecourt Disposal Receivable is held by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its Subsidiaries), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness only; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness of the Subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that are not Senior Secured Notes Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors. Senior Notes ........................................... The Senior Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer, secured as set forth under "— _Security;"_ - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future Indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to any future Indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes; ### 54 ----- - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation (including obligations to trade creditors) of the Senior Notes Issuer and its Subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Senior Notes (including the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility for so long as the Warehouse Assets, Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets are held by the Senior Notes Issuer or its Subsidiaries, and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, for so long as any Forecourt Disposal Receivable is held by the Senior Notes Issuer or its Subsidiaries), or that secure such Indebtedness or obligation on a priority basis (including obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness of the Subsidiaries of the Senior Notes Issuer that are not Senior Notes Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes Guarantees ......... The Senior Secured Notes Guarantee of each Senior Secured Notes Guarantor will: - be a general senior obligation of the applicable Guarantor, secured as set forth under "—Security;" - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing or future Indebtedness of the applicable Guarantor that is not subordinated in right of payment to the applicable Senior Secured Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor's obligations under the Senior Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing or future Indebtedness of the applicable Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the applicable Senior Secured Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor's Notes Guarantee of the Senior Notes; ### 56 ----- - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the applicable Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes Guarantee (including the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility for so long as the Warehouse Assets, Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets are held by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its Subsidiaries, and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, for so long as any Forecourt Disposal Receivable is held by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its Subsidiaries), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness or obligation only; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the Subsidiaries of the applicable Guarantor that are not Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors. The Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will be subject to the Agreed Security Principles and the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees may be subject to release under certain circumstances. See "Description of the Senior Secured Notes— Security—Enforcement_ _of_ _Security"_ and _"Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— Intercreditor Agreement."_ Senior Notes ........................................... The Senior Notes Guarantee of each Senior Notes Guarantor will: - be a general senior subordinated obligation of that Guarantor; - be subordinated in right of payment to any existing and future senior Indebtedness of that Guarantor, including that Guarantor's obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement or the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any future senior subordinated Indebtedness of that Guarantor; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future Indebtedness of that Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Senior Notes Guarantee; ### 57 ----- - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the applicable Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Notes Guarantee (including the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility for so long as Warehouse Assets, Select Retail Assets or Substitute Retail Assets are held by the applicable Guarantor or its Subsidiaries and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, for so long as any Forecourt Disposal Receivable is held by the Senior Notes Issuer or its Subsidiaries) or that secured such Indebtedness or obligation on a priority basis (including obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness or obligation; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the Subsidiaries of the applicable Guarantor that are not Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors. The Senior Notes Guarantees will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, including payment blockage, standstill on enforcement and turnover provisions and may be released in certain circumstances. See _"Description of the Senior Notes—Security—Enforcement of Security"_ and _"Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— Intercreditor Agreement."_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Security:
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes .................................. If the Offering is consummated prior to, and not substantially concurrently with or after, the Acquisition, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured on the Issue Date by first-priority security interests over the relevant Escrow Account in which the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Secured Notes have been deposited. ### 58 ----- On the later of the Issue Date and the Acquisition Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by first-priority security interests over (a) the issued share capital of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, and the Initial ASDA Guarantors, (b) the Senior Financing Proceeds Loan and any other material intra-group receivables owing to the Senior Notes Issuer by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, (c) the material intercompany receivables owing to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Initial ASDA Guarantors, not including the Post-Completion Disposal Receivables, (d) the material bank accounts located in England and Wales of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Initial ASDA Guarantors, not including the Designated Bank Accounts, and (e) a floating charge over all or substantially all of the assets (other than customarily excluded assets) of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Initial ASDA Guarantors, as and when created. Within 90 days of the Acquisition Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by (i) first-priority security interests over (a) all the issued Capital Stock of each of the Post-Completion Guarantors, (b) the material intercompany receivables of each of the Post-Completion Guarantors (not including the Post-Completion Disposal Receivables) and (c) the material bank accounts (without control over use) located in England and Wales of each of the PostCompletion Guarantors (not including the Designated Bank Accounts) and (ii) a floating charge over all or substantially all assets of each of the Post-Completion Guarantors (other than any customarily excluded assets). Within 180 days of the Acquisition Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be further secured by each ASDA Guarantor's Material Real Property (by way of mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security) (not including the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets or the Substitute Retail Assets). The security interests securing the Senior Secured Notes may be released under certain circumstances. ### 59 ----- Senior Notes ........................................... If the Offering is consummated prior to, and not substantially concurrently with or after, the Acquisition, the Senior Notes will be secured on the Issue Date by first-priority security interests over the relevant Escrow Account in which the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Notes have been deposited. On the later of the Issue Date and the Acquisition Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Notes will be secured by (i) first-priority security interests over (a) all the issued Capital Stock of the Senior Notes Issuer, (b) the Senior Notes Issuer's material intercompany receivables owing by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, (c) the Senior Notes Issuer's material bank accounts located in England and Wales and (ii) second-priority interests in the Shared Security. The security interests securing the Senior Notes may be released under certain circumstances. Use of Proceeds..........................................** We estimate that the gross proceeds from the Offering will be £2,750 million. The gross proceeds from the Offering will be used to repay principal amounts drawn under the Senior Bridge Facility, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities and a portion of the amounts drawn under Facility B in connection with the Acquisition, if the Acquisition Completion Date occurs prior to the Issue Date. If the Acquisition Completion Date is delayed until after the Issue Date, unless the Offering is consummated substantially concurrently with or after the Acquisition, we will fund the gross proceeds of the Offering into Escrow Accounts, which will be held in the name of the relevant Issuer, but controlled by the relevant Escrow Agent, and pledged in favour of the relevant Trustee on behalf of and for the benefit of the holders of the relevant Notes, pursuant to the terms of the Escrow Agreements and Escrow Account Charges dated on or before the Issue Date. In this case, on or about the Acquisition Completion Date, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, the Escrowed Proceeds will be released from escrow and utilised to fund part of the consideration payable under the Acquisition Agreement. If the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the completion of the Acquisition, we will forgo the escrow procedures and will instead retain the proceeds of the Offering to fund part of the consideration payable under the Acquisition Agreement on the Acquisition Completion Date.

If any deduction or withholding for, or on account of, any taxes imposed or levied by or on behalf of a Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction is required by law to be made from any payments under the Notes or the Notes Guarantees, the relevant Issuer or the Guarantors will, subject to certain exceptions, pay additional amounts so that the net amount received by each holder in respect of such payments after such withholding or deduction (including any deduction or withholding from such additional amounts) is not less than the amounts which would have been received by such holder in the absence of such withholding or deduction. Tax redemption ...........................................** If certain changes in the law of any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction become effective that would impose withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Notes and the relevant Issuer or Guarantor is required to pay additional amounts, the relevant Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, together with accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the date fixed for redemption and all additional amounts, if any. Change of Control ......................................** Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control the Issuers will be required to make an offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof. ### 62 ----- Escrowed Proceeds; Special Mandatory** If the Offering settles after the Acquisition Redemption .................................................** Completion Date, we will draw committed credit facilities to fund a portion of the consideration payable for the Acquisition on the Acquisition Completion Date and will repay part of those drawings with the proceeds of the Offering on the Issue Date. If the Acquisition Completion Date is delayed until after the Issue Date, including due to the timing of our receipt of the FCA's approval of the Acquisition, unless the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition, we will, pending completion of the Acquisition, fund the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Accounts, which will be held in the name of the relevant Issuer, but controlled by the relevant Escrow Agent, and pledged in favour of the relevant Trustee on behalf of and for the benefit of the holders of the relevant series of Notes, pursuant to the terms of the Escrow Agreements and the Escrow Account Charges. The release of the Escrowed Proceeds, if any, will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including the consummation of the Acquisition in accordance with the terms of the Acquisition Agreement. Changes or other modifications to the Escrow Agreements and the Escrow Account Charges can be made either with the consent of Holders of at least a majority in aggregate principal amount of the applicable series of Notes then outstanding or without the consent of the applicable Holders, if such changes or other modifications will not, individually or when taken as a whole, adversely affect the rights of any of the applicable Holders in any material respect. In the event we deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Accounts on the Issue Date and the Acquisition Completion Date has not occurred or the conditions to the release of such Escrowed Proceeds have not otherwise been satisfied, on or before April 30, 2022 (the Outside Date) or in certain other circumstances (including at the discretion of Midco, a holding company of the Issuers, subject to certain conditions), the Notes will be mandatorily redeemable at a price equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issued Date to, but not including, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date, and Additional Amounts, if any. In the event of a special mandatory redemption, Midco, a wholly owned subsidiary of Topco and a holding company of the Issuers, will be required to provide the Issuers with such funding as is necessary for the Issuers to contribute to the Escrow Accounts, up to the maximum aggregate amount of £20.0 million pursuant to the terms of the Shortfall Agreements, an amount in cash expected to equal the sum of (i) interest accrued on the Notes from the Issue Date, and (ii) any Additional Amounts, in each case, to March 31, 2021 (unless such date has been unilaterally extended by Midco in its sole discretion ### 63 ----- in accordance with the terms of the Shortfall Agreements), which is the date by which we expect to have received the FCA's approval of the Acquisition. Midco's obligations under the Shortfall Agreements will be guaranteed by a bank of international standing, which will deliver to the Issuers an irrevocable letter of credit or on-demand guarantee initially expiring on March 31, 2021. If the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the completion of the Acquisition, we will forgo the escrow procedures and will instead retain the proceeds of the Offering to fund part of the consideration payable under the Acquisition Agreement on the Acquisition Completion Date. Certain Covenants ......................................** The Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Senior Notes Indenture will, among other things, restrict the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer, respectively, and their respective restricted subsidiaries, to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the relevant Issuer's subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests created for the benefit of the holders of the relevant Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the relevant Notes obtain and maintain an investmentgrade rating. Each of the covenants in the Indentures will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See "Description of the Senior Secured Notes— _Certain Covenants" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants."_ Transfer Restrictions .................................** The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See "Notice to Investors." The Group has not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes under the securities laws in any jurisdiction (including by way of an exchange offer). ### 64 ----- Original Issue Discount .............................** The Notes may be issued with original issue discount ("OID") for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In such event, U.S. holders (as defined under "Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United _States Federal Income Tax Considerations")_ generally will be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, U.S. holders generally will include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See "Certain Tax Considerations—Certain _United States Federal Income Tax Considerations— Original Issue Discount."_ No Established Market for the Notes ........** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. Listing ..........................................................** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited to list the Notes on the Official List the Exchange and to admit the Notes for trading on the Exchange. Governing Law ............................................** The Indentures, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement, the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement, the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement are governed by English law. The security documents will be governed by the applicable law of the jurisdiction in which the relevant collateral is located. Senior Secured Notes Trustee ..................** Deutsche Trustee Company Limited. Senior Notes Trustee .................................** Deutsche Trustee Company Limited. Security Agent ............................................** Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Paying Agent ...............................................** Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Registrar and Transfer Agent ....................** Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. Listing Agent ...............................................** Carey Olsen Corporate Finance Limited.

SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsection Title: Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA ........._** **1,164.4
Subsubsection Text: (A) IFRS 16 was adopted on January 1, 2019. The modified retrospective approach was taken and prior year comparatives have not been restated. EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the nine months ended September 30, 2019, for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 is presented after giving effect to the adoption of IFRS 16. Adoption of IFRS 16 in the year ended December 31, 2019 resulted in a decrease in operating costs of £31.4 million and an increase in finance costs of £52.7 million compared to lease-related expenses charged in the prior year under IAS 17. Adoption of IFRS 16 is the primary reason for the increase in finance lease interest of £52.7 million and the increase in depreciation of assets held under finance leases of £149.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to the prior year. The addition of these line items back into the calculation of EBITDA results in a higher EBITDA than if EBITDA were prepared under IAS 17, which would include operating lease expense charges within EBITDA. The operating lease expense included in EBITDA in the year ended December 31, 2018 is £188.3 million. (B)   The elimination of IFRS 16 impact adjustment deducts from EBITDA rental payments made during the period in respect of finance leases that would have been accounted for as operating leases under IAS 17 prior to the entry into force of IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019. Under IAS 17, our leases would be classified primarily as operating leases, with no assets or liabilities on the balance sheet and rental charges instead of depreciation and interest in the income statement. Increases in rental charges of £133.8 million, £129.7 million and £177.9 million for the nine-month periods ended September 30, 2019 and September 30, 2020, and the year ended December 31, 2019, respectively, are recognised through the foregoing adjustments within EBITDA. Additionally, below EBITDA adjustments decreasing depreciation and amortisation by £107.7 million, £104.1 million and £143.6 million, and adjustments decreasing interest by £38.4 million, £37.6 million and £51.3 million for the same respective periods have also been made. (C)   The asset write-off adjustment relates to the non-cash write off of all tangible fixed assets with value written off in the normal course of business, usually as a result of store or depot remodelling activities. 2019 also includes an additional write off for some work in progress on an IT system project. ### 71 ----- (D) The prior year ATM rates adjustment reflects the removal of income that has been included in EBITDA following a change in the assessment of business rates for automated teller machines (ATMs). In 2020, a retrospective change was made, as a result of which the Company was entitled to a refund for business rates previously paid. This adjustment removes the income resulting from those refunds for periods earlier than financial year 2020. (E) The bonus top-up adjustment comprises discretionary retrospective enhancements to the annual bonus over and above the parameters of the standard bonus structure. (F) The contract implementation costs adjustment comprises one-off costs relating to the implementation of a new contract for retail colleagues in 2019. In particular, these cost comprised (i) a one-off cost associated with estimated incremental costs as a result of the one-to-one consultations with individual colleagues affected by the proposals, which required such colleagues to be absent from work on the retail shop floor and replaced with incremental time from other colleagues, and (ii) a holiday pay top-up resulting from a transitional agreement made with colleagues to top-up their holiday allowance for 2019 after the new colleague contract introduced in November 2019. (G) The merger costs adjustment reflects an adjustment to remove the directly attributable one-off costs incurred as part of the proposed merger between the Company and J Sainsbury's plc that was subsequently abandoned following CMA review. The adjustment reflects actual costs incurred and management's judgement around which costs were directly attributable to the proposed merger. Costs include consultancy and legal fees, as well as one-off retention bonuses paid to colleagues in connection with that transaction. The proposed merger was announced in May 2018 and the CMA's review was completed in April 2019. (H) The pension contribution adjustment comprises one-off transitional arrangement voluntarily made by the Company that included two annual payments to colleagues' pension funds resulting from changes to the eligibility regime for such contributions. (I) The transaction bonuses adjustment comprises £0.5 million accrued for one-off bonuses that will be paid to colleagues working on the Acquisition. There are expected to be additional transactional bonuses accrued prior to completion. (J) The restructuring adjustments comprise one-off provisions relating to severance costs in connection with the restructuring of home office functions. (K) The pension guarantee adjustment removes amounts paid to Walmart in connection with Walmart's guarantee of the ASDA defined benefit pension scheme. This guarantee payment was terminated when the pension scheme buy-in was completed in October 2019. Therefore, these charges will not continue on a going-forward basis. (L) Options in Walmart shares have historically been awarded to employees of the Company; these share option awards have been accounted for within EBITDA as cash settled equity awards. As no new awards of such options in Walmart shares will be granted and all existing options in Walmart shares will be settled within six months following the Separation, the corresponding charges will fall away and, as a result, are added back for the relevant periods (for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, £96.3 million, for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2020, £116.7 million and £83.7 million, respectively, and for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2019, £44.6 million and £129.3 million, respectively). On a going-forward basis, the Company will, however, enhance other colleague incentive programmes. The estimated annual incremental cost of these enhanced incentive programmes is estimated to be £38 million. Therefore, a charge of £38.0 million has been included for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 as well as the years ended December, 31 2018 and 2019. A prorated charge of £28.5 million has been included for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2020. This adjustment thus reflects the net amount remaining following the removal of the Walmart shares options and the incremental cost of the enhanced colleague incentive programmes. (M)   The Walmart royalties adjustment reflects the removal of royalties paid by the Company to Walmart as part of an advance pricing agreement calculated using a transfer pricing methodology whereby the amount payable is based on the financial performance of ASL. The services covered by the charge include the use of Walmart intellectual property, which is broadly defined as trade marks, business strategies and business systems. These costs will no longer be applicable following the Separation. However, on-going use of Walmart's trade marks, business strategies and business systems will be covered by the TSA, the TMA and the ASA. (N)   The ISD recharge adjustment removes recharges paid to Walmart in respect of IT services that are allowable for tax purposes. This cost will no longer be applicable following the Separation. However, some of the same services that this cost captures will be covered by the TSA. (O) The TSA charge adjustment relates the charge under the TSA for on-going access to Walmart's IT services, business systems and technology related intellectual property following the Separation. (P) For the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, other adjustments relate to: £8.0 million in adjustments relating to the impact of having had an additional trading day in February 2020 as a result of leap year and £10.0 million in IT and non-IT costs relating to ASDA operating as a standalone company. These costs include the increase in the commissions payable by the Company as consideration for the services provided to the Company by Walmart Global Sourcing, the increase in costs associated with ocean freight, the costs incurred in connection with the creation of new roles to replace certain capabilities previously sourced from Walmart and the cost of insurance cover replacing the insurance cover ASDA has received prior to the Separation through Walmart under Walmart's umbrella insurance policies. (Q) This adjustment relates to certain one-off costs due to the impact of COVID-19 (£226 million), net of certain one-off benefits related to the UK government's business rates holiday for businesses affected by COVID-19 (£171 million). Management has identified incremental costs for the first three quarters of 2020 due to COVID-19, including costs resulting from colleague absences (due to quarantine requirements and protective measures taken for vulnerable colleagues), a one-time "thank you" bonus paid by the Company, costs relating to goods not for resale (e.g., face masks, safety provisions, additional security and screens), incremental inventory and supplier costs and the impact of changes in product mix that are expected to be temporary. Management identified a one-off benefit of £171 million, being approximately £28 million per month for the period from April 2020 to September 2020, resulting from a business rates holiday announced by the UK government, which applies to businesses in eligible sectors, including retail businesses, for the UK 2020-2021 tax year. On December 3, 2020, however, ASDA announced its decision to pay business rates tax relief accepted from the UK government in 2020. In calculating this adjustment we have not taken into account any benefit related to the increase in revenues we have experienced as a result of and during the COVID-19 pandemic. (R) In connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders engaged an international leading consultant to assist them in conducting financial and operational due diligence on ASDA management's plan, with a particular focus on SG&A costs (excluding personnel costs). Based on these due diligence activities conducted to date in connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders currently believe that there is an opportunity to achieve net run-rate cost savings of £60 million from ASDA's SG&A cost base (excluding personnel costs) within 18 months of the Acquisition Completion Date. In particular, the Shareholders expect projected cost savings from product rationalisation and business integration initiatives. While detailed bottom-up plans are yet to be developed due to regulatory restrictions in place prior to the CMA's approval of the Acquisition, these SG&A cost savings estimated to be realised within 18 months of the Acquisition Completion Date represent only 1.3% of ASDA's SG&A costs of £4.5 billion during the 12 months ended September 30, 2020. The CMA might complete its regulatory approval process relating to the Acquisition later than currently anticipated. Any such delay by the CMA might limit our ability to achieve these expected SG&A cost savings, whether within the timeframe or to the full extent currently anticipated. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating _to the Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties and risks, which could adversely impact recoveries under the Notes"_ and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart." ### 72 ----- (S) EG foodservice partnership synergies relate to rental income payable from EG Group to ASDA related to EG Group's roll out of foodservice restaurants across the existing ASDA estate. (T) Synergies from the roll out of the ASDA wholesale convenience business relate to the anticipated benefit from the incremental wholesale margin from the roll out of the ASDA convenience proposition (ASDA On the Move) across the EG Group's network. ASDA On the Move is a wholesale arrangement whereby ASDA's own brand products as well as branded products will be sold in third-party-owned smaller convenience store formats. The adjustment of £7.0 million reflects the Shareholders' estimates of the total potential forward-looking run-rate synergies that could be realised in the first 24 months as a result of the Transactions. (U) The adjustment eliminates the EBITDA generated by the Forecourt Assets that will be disposed of pursuant to the Forecourt Business Disposal. See "The Transactions—The Post-Completion Transactions—Forecourt Disposals." (V) Rent for Warehouse Assets refers solely to the rental costs associated with the Warehouse Assets. In addition to the Broker's Opinion of Pricing prepared by Colliers, the Issuers received advice from Eastdil Secured in connection with the rental pricing of the Warehouse Assets. This adjustment reflects additional input from Eastdil Secured on the rental pricing of the Warehouse Assets (and, in particular, those Warehouse Assets which are cold storage facilities and would be included in the disposal of any Warehouse Assets as a landlord's fixture and fitting). The Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower aims to refinance the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility using only proceeds from the Warehouse Sale Transactions, which relate to such Warehouse Assets. However, the funds raised from the Warehouse Sale Transactions may not be sufficient for this purpose. If this is the case, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower is expected to supplement the proceeds from the Warehouse Sale Transactions with additional proceeds from the transfer of some or all of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets in sale transactions with unaffiliated third parties. Any rental costs associated with any Select Retail Assets or Substitute Retail Assets so disposed of are not included in this adjustment. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—We may not be able to consummate the Post-Completion Disposals as _quickly as we anticipate, or at all, and the manner in which we execute the Post-Completion Disposals may differ from what we present in this Offering Memorandum" and "The Transactions."_ (4) Free Cash Flow is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure. The following table sets forth a reconciliation of Free Cash Flow to Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: _The historical consolidated financial information and other financial data of the Company as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019 have been extracted from the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum or from the Company's accounting records. The unaudited condensed consolidated historical financial information and other financial data of the Company as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and September 30, 2020 have been extracted from the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Company included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum or from the Company's accounting records. This Offering Memorandum includes unaudited financial information for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, which is calculated by adding the results of operations for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 to the results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2019 and subtracting the results of operations for the nine months ended September 30, 2019. The financial information for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 is not necessarily indicative of the results of operations that may be expected for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2020 or any future period, and should not be used as the basis for or prediction of an annualised calculation. The unaudited financial information for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 has not been audited or reviewed by our auditors, is not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles and has been prepared for illustrative purposes only. Results of operations for prior periods or years are not necessarily indicative of the result to be expected for any future period. Prospective investors should bear in mind that the performance indicators and ratios that we report herein, such as the EBITDA Measures, Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion, capital expenditure and certain other measures are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS and, as such, may be calculated by other companies using different methodologies and having different results. Therefore, these performance indicators and ratios are not directly comparable to similar figures and ratios reported by other companies. The following tables also contain financial measures and ratios that are not presented in accordance with IFRS. For the definitions and analytical limitations of these Non-IFRS Measures, see "Presentation of Financial and Other Information." You should read the information summarised below in conjunction with the information contained in "Presentation of Financial and Other Information," "Use of Proceeds," "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" and the consolidated financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: We operate in a highly competitive industry and our business, financial condition and results operations, as well as the strength of our brand, may be materially adversely affected by actions of our competitors and our failure to respond to competitive pressures.
Subsubsection Text: The UK grocery market is particularly competitive. There can be no assurance that we can continue to successfully compete with existing competitors or new market entrants. Our competition generally includes international and domestic brick-and-mortar retailers (including, generalist grocers, supermarket chains, discount retailers, grocery specialists and convenience stores), some of which also operate omni-channel businesses, as well as online pure players, such as Amazon and Ocado. In recent years, the historically stable grocery retail market in the United Kingdom has undergone a structural shift towards discounters, such as Aldi and Lidl, convenience formats and online retailers, to the detriment of traditional supermarkets and hypermarkets. We generally compete for, among other things, customers, market share, employees, digital prominence, products and services and in other important aspects of the business with many other local, regional, national and global omni-channel retailers, wholesale operators and retail intermediaries. Our competitors generally compete with us on the basis of, among other things, price, quality, selection, availability, services offered to customers, location, store hours, in-store amenities, shopping convenience, brand reputation, overall shopping experience, attractiveness and ease of use of our online platforms, cost and delivery speed of merchandise purchased through our digital platforms or through our omni-channel integration of our physical and digital operations. In executing our strategy, we may face a variety of competitive challenges, including, among others: - potential emergence of new competitors, including foreign and domestic retailers entering our markets, or consolidation, strengthening or expanded offerings of existing operators, as has been the case in recent years with the emergence of discounters (for more information, see "Industry" and "Business—Key Strengths"); - potential creation by competitors of new store formats, additional convenience grocery retail store offerings, in-store or online services, delivery and pick-up options or online platforms that customers may prefer; - the risk of our competitors successfully adopting our business model in their own stores; - competitive pressure on product pricing from core competitors, as well as discount and online retailers; and - the risk of our competitors providing better service, quality, value or availability of products. The performance of our competitors and changes in their pricing, promotions, product mix or other business strategies, and our response (or failure to respond) to such competitive pressures, may lead to lower sales revenue, higher operating expenses and/or lower profit margins and may require a significant amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or otherwise have a material adverse effect on our ongoing business operations. There can be no assurance that, with evolving customer preferences, our customers will not shift towards competitors with a different business model. ### 75 ----- Even in geographies, channels and formats where we have a strong retail presence, we face the risk that new retail market entrants may attempt to gain market share through pricing pressure. For example, the UK grocery retail market has seen the rapid growth of discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) that compete through differentiation on price coupled with a more limited selection of own-brand products. We experience downward pricing pressure, and if we are unable to maintain our competitive position, we could experience additional downward pressure on prices, lower demand for our products, reduced retail margins, the inability to take advantage of new business opportunities and the loss of market share, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. In recent years, and in particular during the COVID-19 pandemic, the demand for online shopping services has increased substantially and many of our competitors have expanded their online offerings. If our competitors are able to offer faster or cheaper deliveries, and/or more convenient delivery options, we could lose current or potential customers, our brand and reputation could suffer, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations. To remain competitive, we must continue to develop and enhance our online offering and the information systems that support our online activities, as well continue to optimise our logistics and distribution capabilities. This may require the acquisition of equipment and software and the development, either internally or through third-parties, of new proprietary software and logistics and distribution solutions. In addition, any impairment of or disruption to our supply chain or delivery fleet could result in a disruption in the delivery of our products to our online customers, which could harm our brand and could generate additional costs. Furthermore, the online grocery industry in the United Kingdom may not sustain or improve upon current levels of demand, and we may fail to develop our online retail proposition to successfully appeal to a broader customer base and sustain current growth rates. If we are unable to effectively compete with our online competitors or if we fail to retain and attract online customers, this may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, we may fail to successfully compete with the growing convenience retail market. If we are unable to successfully expand our operations into the convenience retail market and the convenience retail market continues to grow, this may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: The impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to create uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control.
Subsubsection Text: In late 2019, a new strain of coronavirus (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 or SARSCoV-2), which can cause coronavirus disease (COVID-19), was detected in Wuhan, China. In March 2020, the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a global pandemic and governmental authorities around the world implemented measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19. For example, in March 2020, the United Kingdom imposed the first set of significant lockdown measures to control the spread of COVID19. These measures to stop the spread of COVID-19 have adversely affected workforces, customer sentiment, economies and financial markets, and, along with causing overall decreased customer spending and widespread uncertainty following months of lockdowns and related uncertainty, have led to an economic downturn in the United Kingdom and have had a direct impact on our business. COVID-19 poses a risk to our colleagues, our customers, our suppliers and the communities in which we operate. As the pandemic has developed, customer fear about becoming ill with the virus and recommendations and/or mandates from national and local authorities to social distance or self-quarantine have continued to have an impact on the UK marketplace. These recommendations and mandates, as well as general fears about gathering in public places, has adversely affected, among other things, our instore traffic, our ability to adequately staff our stores, depots, packing and processing facilities and other facilities and our suppliers' ability to provide products on a timely basis. See "Management's Discussion _and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Result of Operations—COVID-19." If we do not respond appropriately or in a timely enough manner to the pandemic_ and its effects, or if customers or colleagues perceive our response to be inadequate or inappropriate, our brand, reputation, business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected. Resurgences (or "waves") of COVID-19 are likely to occur. We cannot predict when or where these waves will occur, the duration of such waves, how far into the future such waves will continue to occur nor can we predict with any certainty the impacts of such subsequent waves, including the impacts of future national or local lockdowns or other measures implemented by national and/or local authorities. As of January 2021, subsequent waves of COVID-19 were significantly affecting many countries, including the United Kingdom and other countries from which we source products, with cases rising markedly in recent weeks and with new, more contagious strains of the virus emerging. On October 12, 2020, the UK Prime Minister announced a three-tiered system of restrictions across England, which came into effect on ### 76 ----- October 14, 2020 in order to help control the spread of the virus. Under this system, regions are classified as either 'medium', 'high' or 'very high' risk and assigned increasingly stringent lockdown restrictions to correspond with their designated tier. On November 5, 2020, the United Kingdom imposed its second set of significant lockdown measures, which ended on December 2, 2020. On December 18, 2020, the UK Prime Minister announced the addition of a fourth tier in the COVID-19 restrictions system, due to the presence of a new, more infectious variant of the virus in the United Kingdom. On December 20, the United Kingdom imposed its third set of significant lockdown measures and placed the South East of the United Kingdom, including London, into tier four lockdown. On January 4, 2021 the UK Prime Minister announced the addition of a fifth tier in the COVID-19 restrictions system, the highest level of COVID-19 restrictions, due to the record high and escalating case numbers of COVID-19 present in the United Kingdom. In tier five, England is in a full lockdown, pursuant to which all persons are instructed to stay home except for a few necessary purposes, including essential work and buying food and medicine. The tier five lockdown is expected to continue until at least February 15, 2021. While none of our grocery retail stores have been closed as a result of such lockdowns, there can be no guarantee that this will continue to be the case or that more stringent rules and restrictions will not be applied in the future in a manner that could materially adversely impact our business. Additionally, local authorities have imposed and may impose stricter rules and restrictions in addition to those imposed by the national tiered system, which may have further material adverse impacts on our business and industry. The placement of areas into the tiers is outside of our control and is expected to be dynamic and unpredictable for the foreseeable future. The tiered alert system applies only to England: the devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are in charge of designing and implementing their own COVID-19 restrictions, which may be as or more stringent than the English tiered system. In light of rising case levels in the United Kingdom and around the world, future national and local lockdowns are foreseeable. Additionally, there may be a decrease in demand for certain of our products in the event of further resurgences of COVID-19 or the occurrence of other pandemics, other public health emergencies or threats, or potential or perceived threats to food and drug safety, any of which may necessitate certain regulatory responses and the result of which may materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. We currently operate our grocery retail stores and facilities as an "essential" business. If the classification of what an "essential" business is changes, or other government regulations are adopted, we may be required to severely or even completely curtail operations, which would have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Even though our stores and facilities are considered essential businesses, national and local authorities may impose regulations and limitations on the operations of our stores and facilities, such as, among other things, limiting customer traffic, hours of operation or access to certain products (as has been the case in Wales, where "firebreak" measures have limited the products that grocery retailers are permitted to sell during the firebreak period to certain essential goods), requiring us to implement track and trace measures and mandating certain health and safety measures. Complying with these regulations and limitations requires the diversion of financial and human resources away from other parts of our business and increases costs, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, our noncompliance, or perceived non-compliance with lockdown measures could lead to formal sanctions and could also harm our brand and reputation. Even while our stores are open, social distancing and other policies implemented to slow the further spread of COVID-19 may impact the operation and appeal of our stores. For example, customers unaccustomed to wearing face coverings or observing social distancing guidance may choose to shop online, which may reduce our in-store business. Even when social distancing policies are lifted, interest in visiting stores and making discretionary purchases may remain weak due to health concerns or recessionary spending patterns. Furthermore, we believe that some of the changes that have arisen during and in response to the COVID-19 pandemic by us and in the United Kingdom as a whole will be persistent and potentially long-lasting, while others may be less so. For example, following the end of the pandemic, there may be a shift of consumer preferences to more out-of-home dining, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Certain of our colleagues have tested positive for COVID-19. We have, and may in the future be required to temporarily close certain of our stores, offices or other facilities for cleaning or to take other responsive or precautionary measures. Likewise, planned construction, renovation and maintenance, as well as the opening of new stores may be delayed, suspended or terminated due to COVID-19-related requirements, such as requiring that workers only leave their homes for essential business, or due to the suspension of governmental permit issuances due to the pandemic. Where appropriate and possible, we have transitioned a significant number of our colleagues to a remote work environment, in an effort to mitigate the spread of COVID-19, which may exacerbate certain risks to our business. ### 77 ----- A large part of our workforce, such as our colleagues who work in our stores, factories or our distribution facilities, cannot work remotely and we cannot be certain that the measures we have taken can fully mitigate the risks posed to them and to our customers by COVID-19 and we may be subject to potential litigation as a result of colleagues alleging that we have facilitated an unsafe working environment or have increased their exposure to COVID-19, or customers or colleagues who claim they have contracted the virus at our stores or other facilities, which may cause us to incur significant costs and which may have a negative impact on our brand and reputation. During the first lockdown, we experienced increased costs, including, amongst others, as a result of goodwill payments to suppliers, increased employment costs relating to increased absences (including for sick colleagues or colleagues following quarantine recommendations), full pay to vulnerable staff members during the 12-week isolation period, employment of safety marshals and operation of stores with extended hours to decrease store congestion. Certain of these costs continued during the second lockdown and we may be subject to similar costs in the event of future lockdowns. We may also be subject to potential litigation initiated by colleagues alleging that we have facilitated an unsafe working environment or have increased their exposure to COVID-19. All of these risks may be further exacerbated by resurgences of the virus. Although the government has increasingly employed sophisticated strategies for combatting the virus such as Test and Trace and localised R-factor measurement in an effort to avoid costly and extensive lockdown measures, the magnitude of possible virus resurgences and the resulting impacts on the economy may materially negatively impact our business, financial condition, and results of operations. Our business is sensitive to reductions in discretionary spending by customers, public health events and other factors described elsewhere in this "Risk Factors" section. To date, the COVID-19 pandemic has caused, and is continuing to cause, significant disruption in economic activity globally, which is expected to lead to a decline in discretionary spending. Our revenue may be negatively impacted by adverse changes in the perceived or actual economic climate, including higher unemployment rates, declines in income levels and loss of personal wealth resulting from the impact of COVID-19 and measures implemented to respond to it. Although we are generating revenue, our revenue may not increase in proportion to our fixed costs and deferred costs and our revenue may not be sufficient to offset the full impact of a potential shutdown of our stores, were that to occur, or curtailment of our operations. If our cost base is higher than our revenue, our cash management policies may fail due to factors beyond our control. In 2020, our profitability has been adversely impacted by COVID-19 in terms of increased costs associated with retail colleague wages, bonus payments and higher retail operating expenditures. During the first lockdown, consumers favoured convenience stores over larger grocery retail stores. Unlike the traditional grocers, currently we do not operate any convenience grocery retail stores and, as a result, this shift towards convenience grocery retail stores adversely affected us. Future lockdowns with similar consumer preferences could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. COVID-19 has also impacted our sales in terms of product mix, with changing customer habits towards less out-of-home consumption, stockpiling and increased use of online grocery services driving higher food sales volumes, while decreased clothing sales and the temporary closure of our ASDA Living stores has led to decreases in non-food sales and the effects of lockdowns on automobile usage has driven decreases in fuel sales. During the first wave of COVID-19 and the accompanying lockdown periods, we relied on access to government aid and mitigation programmes, including the business rates relief holiday for the 2020 to 2021 tax year. Our mitigation strategy was reinforced by legislation such as the UK Coronavirus Act 2020, the Coronavirus (Scotland) Acts of 2020 and the UK Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020, which introduced certain protections in relation to lease forfeitures (and irritancies), and temporary restrictions on the ability of creditors to file statutory demands and winding up petitions in the United Kingdom based solely on the failure to comply with (for example) rent payment obligations as a result of COVID-19. However, in December 2020, we announced our intention to voluntarily resume payments of the applicable business rate, for the period during the COVID-19 pandemic where we had benefitted from the business rates holiday relief.
