Subsubsection Title: If the technology-based systems that give our customers the ability to shop with us online do not function effectively, our results of operations, as well as our ability to grow our omni-channel business, could be materially adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: Increasingly, customers are using computers, tablets, and smart phones to shop with us and with our competitors and to do comparison shopping. We use our websites, social media, online advertising, and email campaigns to interact with our customers and as a means to enhance their shopping experience. As a part of our omni-channel strategy, we offer home delivery and pickup options under which many products available for purchase online can be picked up in-store by the customer via our Click & Collect offer, which provides additional customer traffic at such stores. Omni-channel retailing is a rapidly evolving part of the UK retail grocery industry. We must anticipate and meet our customers' changing expectations while adjusting for technology investments and developments in our competitors' operations through focusing on the building and delivery of a seamless shopping experience across all channels. Any failure on our part to provide attractive, user-friendly secure digital platforms that offer a wide assortment of merchandise at competitive prices and with low-cost and rapid delivery options and that continually meet the changing expectations of online shoppers and developments in online and digital platform merchandising and related technology could place us at a competitive disadvantage, result in the loss of online and other sales, harm our reputation with customers, have a material adverse impact on the growth of our online business and have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: Use of social media may adversely impact our reputation or subject us to fines or other penalties.
Subsubsection Text: There has been a marked increase in the use of social media platforms and similar devices, including blogs, social media websites and other forms of internet-based communications which allow individual access to a broad audience of customers and other interested persons. Consumers value readily available information concerning retailers, manufacturers and their goods and services and often act on such information without further investigation, authentication and without regard to its accuracy. The availability of information on social media platforms and devices is virtually immediate as is its impact. Social media platforms and devices immediately publish the content their subscribers and participants post, often without filters or checks on accuracy of the content posted. The opportunity for dissemination of information, including inaccurate information, is virtually limitless. Information concerning or affecting us may be posted on such platforms and devices at any time. Information posted may be inaccurate and adverse to us, and it may harm our business. The harm may be immediate without affording us an opportunity for redress or correction. Such platforms also could be used for the dissemination of trade secret information or compromise of other valuable company assets, any of which could harm our business. We also use social media platforms as marketing tools. For example, we maintain Instagram, Facebook and Twitter accounts. As laws and regulations rapidly evolve to govern the use of these platforms and devices, the failure by us, our colleagues or third parties acting at our direction to abide by applicable laws and regulations in the use of these platforms and devices could adversely impact our business or subject us to fines or other penalties. ### 92 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may suffer a loss as a result of operational risk, including human error, ineffective or inadequate designed processes, failure of IT or other systems, improper conduct by colleagues and third parties, failures by suppliers and third-party providers and criminal activity including fraud, theft and cybercrime.
Subsubsection Text: Any failure to maintain the security of the information relating to our business, customers, and colleagues, whether as a result of cybersecurity attacks on our information systems or otherwise, could damage our reputation, result in litigation or other legal actions against us, cause us to incur substantial additional costs, and materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. In the ordinary course of our business, we are exposed to the risk of theft or misappropriation of funds and products and to the risk of fraud and corruption in our stores and warehouses, as well as human error. For example, from time to time, products may be misappropriated during transportation or we may experience a misappropriation of funds in our stores or at other levels of our business. We cannot assure that incidences of inventory loss and theft will not increase in the future, that insurance will cover such losses adequately or that the measures we are taking against such theft will effectively decrease inventory shrinkage. In addition to increasing security costs to combat inventory theft, the occurrence of such risks may have a material adverse impact on our results of operations and reputation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: We rent certain of our properties pursuant to commercial leases that may be subject to adjustments that could increase expenses and have a materially adverse impact on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Certain of our stores and warehouses are leased pursuant to commercial leases for fixed terms consistent with market practice. Such leases usually provide for regular rent reviews, at which time our rental costs may increase in line with certain indices. Our ability to maintain our existing rental rates during renewals or to renew any expired lease on favourable terms will depend on many factors which are not within our control, such as applicable real estate laws and regulations, payments for utilities, local taxes or assessments, conditions in the local real estate market, competition for desirable properties and our relationships with current and prospective landlords. If rent reviews were to increase at higher rates than currently anticipated or if we were unable to renew any expired leases on commercially favourable terms, our financial performance could be adversely impacted. Further, we may be unable to extend expiring lease agreements at all or may have no or limited ability to close certain store locations that do not meet our financial targets or are no longer consistent with our brands' positioning. These changes in the size of our store network can have a significant impact on our revenues and expenses from one period to the next, which affect the comparability of our results during these periods. Our ability to enter into leases to open new retail locations depends on the availability of locations that meet our criteria for traffic, square footage, lease economics, demographics and other factors. In addition, the market for suitable retail locations is highly competitive. Some of our competitors may have the ability to negotiate more favourable commercial lease terms than we can. If we are unable to renew our lease agreements as they expire or if any of our existing lease agreements are terminated for any reason and we are unable to secure other favourable locations on acceptable terms, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also "—We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates _made or procedures followed in the third-party brokers' opinions of pricing of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: A significant disruption in our workforce or the workforce of our suppliers or a failure to extend, renew or renegotiate trade union agreements could lead to labour disputes that might interfere with our operations or otherwise could materially adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2019, we employed 144,951 colleagues. Approximately 124,491 of these colleagues worked in our store network and 12,662 in our distribution network. From time to time, and in particular in our distribution networks, we may experience labour disputes and we can never rule out the possibility of work stoppages. We are also exposed to similar risks involving the workforce of our thirdparty suppliers, including all of our distribution centre operators. In particular, a labour stoppage or other interruption at one of our suppliers or distribution centres would impact our ability to supply our stores or online orders and could have a pronounced effect on our operations as a result. As we do not directly control our suppliers, we have limited information on labour relations between our suppliers and their workforces. ### 93 ----- In addition, some of our colleagues are members of trade unions and are parties to collective bargaining agreements, which contain provisions covering issues such as working hours and compensation. See "Business—Our Colleagues." We may not be able to extend existing agreements, renew them on their current terms or, negotiate such agreements in a favourable and timely manner or without work stoppages, strikes or similar industrial actions, any of which may have a material adverse effect on our business. If we seek to reduce colleague terms, or otherwise are unable to maintain satisfactory colleague and labour relations, the results could include work stoppages, strikes or other industrial action or labour difficulties (including higher labour costs), any of which could materially adversely affect our operations. As a result, any deterioration in our relationships with our colleagues, unions and other colleague representatives could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. From time to time disagreements and other disputes may emerge with our workforce and/or their representatives and we are presently engaged in ordinary course litigation regarding dismissals, overtime work and other routine disputes or actions. See "Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation." We cannot assure you that a future labour disturbance, work stoppage, or failure to attract and retain operative personnel at any of our stores, depots or our suppliers' facilities in the United Kingdom or elsewhere would not have a material adverse effect on such store's or facility's operations and, potentially, on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our failure to attract and retain qualified colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and other changes to wage regulations could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are reliant on our staff for the management, operation, creation, maintenance, repair and upgrading of our business, operations and systems. Our ability to recruit or adequately replace, retain and motivate suitably qualified and experienced staff is important for our ongoing success. It may in the future become more difficult for us to recruit or retain such members of staff and the UK labour market may become more competitive. An inability to recruit and retain sufficient personnel of the right calibre or the incurring of significant costs in order to do so may have an adverse effect on our financial condition and future prospects. Furthermore, our automated warehouses and delivery trucks still require intensive labour. Colleague benefits (which include wages, National Insurance contributions and other payments) currently represent one of our most significant cost items, accounting for a substantial portion of our total expenses. Consequently, our commercial success depends in part on our ability to manage our labour costs and control their impact on our margins. We may in the future be forced to raise our wages due to changes in market conditions, new labour laws and regulations, collective bargaining with our recognised trade unions or general wage increases across the industry or in any particular region in which we operate. For instance, given the high proportion of our colleagues who are hourly paid, future increases or changes to the National Minimum Wage legislation, the National Living Wage or other hourly wage legislation or regulations could have an impact on our future financial success. As of April 2020, the National Living Wage increased from £8.21 per hour to £8.72 per hour from April 2019. The National Living Wage will increase in increments with a target to be set by the UK government of reaching two-thirds of median earnings by 2024. As of October 2020, the UK government has not set out a projected pathway to the 2024 target, given the uncertainty about the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak. We must comply with such legislation. Any failure to comply could result in criminal prosecution with any party found to be guilty of deliberate non-compliance being subject to disqualification as a company director for up to 15 years. From time to time, we are subject to legal proceedings in connection with the wages we pay: see "Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation." As national minimum hourly wage rates increase, we may be required to increase not only the wage rates of our hourly paid colleagues but also the wages of our salaried managers as an increase in hourly rates inevitably erodes the pay gap between hourly paid and first line managers. This makes it more challenging to incentivise our most talented colleagues to progress into management positions. It also makes it difficult to retain our talented managers. Although difficult to predict with certainty, these higher salaried costs could have a material adverse effect on our profitability. While we cannot be certain how this will affect our business, an increase in the minimum wage rate paid to certain workers will increase our labour costs which may adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition. Our ability to meet our management labour needs, while controlling wage and labour-related costs, is subject to numerous external factors, including the availability of and competition for qualified persons in the local markets in which we are located, unemployment levels within those markets, prevailing pay rates, changing demographics, and changes in employment and labour laws. Such laws related to hours, wages, job classification and benefits could significantly increase operating costs. ### 94 ----- If we fail to maintain our competitive position on pay and benefits, the quality of our workforce could decline, causing our customer service to suffer, while increasing wages for our colleagues could cause our profit margins to decrease. If we are unable to hire, retain, and train colleagues capable of meeting our business needs and expectations, our business and brand image may be impaired. Any failure to meet our staffing needs or any material increase in turnover rates may have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and prospects. Furthermore, we are required to pay social security, National Insurance contributions, pension contributions and other similar charges for our colleagues. These may increase over time or the laws and regulations setting forth any exonerations or other exemptions from payment of such charges from which we currently benefit may change, increasing our liabilities. We maintain defined benefit and defined contribution pension plans that cover current and former colleagues pursuant to which, with respect to defined benefit plans, the participants receive defined payment amounts regardless of the value or investment performance of the assets held by such plans and, with respect to defined contribution plans, the employer, employee or both make contributions on a regular basis to such plans. Deterioration in the value of plan assets resulting from a general financial downturn or otherwise, could cause an increase in the underfunded status of our defined benefit pension plans, thereby increasing our obligation to make contributions to the plans, which in turn would reduce the cash available for other business needs or for capital expenditures. Our main defined benefit pension plan, the ASDA Group Pension Scheme ("ASDA Group Pension Scheme"), benefits from a bulk purchase annuity policy issued by Rothesay Life plc. The policy covers all known members of the scheme and all known benefit liabilities, subject to certain exclusions. If Rothesay Life were to get into financial difficulty and default on its payment obligations under the policy, or if any of the excluded liabilities were to crystallise, this could result in a requirement for us to make further, material contributions to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme. Future contributions to our defined benefit pension plans could reduce the cash otherwise available to operate our business and could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Information—ASDA Group Pension Scheme Buy-In."_ Any of the foregoing may affect our profitability and may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. If we are not able to pass on such higher costs to our customers, these higher labour costs could materially adversely affect our profitability.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our intellectual property rights may be infringed or challenged. Intellectual property claims by third parties or our failure or inability to protect our intellectual property rights could diminish the value of our brand and weaken our competitive position.
Subsubsection Text: We own or use a variety of trade names, logos, domain names, service marks and trade marks in our business and rely on trade mark and copyright laws, confidentiality procedures and contractual provisions to protect our intellectual proprietary rights. We may not have adequate protections for our intellectual property rights or may be accused of infringing intellectual property rights of third parties. We cannot be certain that third parties will not infringe, misappropriate or terminate these rights. We own nearly all the intellectual property rights over the trade marks, trade signs and copyrights that we use. We also own some of the intellectual property rights over the software and technologies that we use. However, such use may be challenged by third parties. If we are unable to protect and maintain our own intellectual property rights or our use of the intellectual property rights owned by others, or we are unable to renew our intellectual property rights when they expire, the value of our brands could be diminished and our competitive position could weaken. We may not be able to discover or determine the extent of any unauthorised use of our proprietary rights. Third parties that licence our proprietary rights may also take actions that diminish the value of our proprietary rights or reputation. The protection of our intellectual property may require the expenditure of financial and managerial resources. Moreover, the steps we take to protect our intellectual property may not adequately protect our rights or prevent third parties from infringing or misappropriating our proprietary rights. We also cannot be certain that others will not independently develop or otherwise acquire equivalent or superior technology or other intellectual property rights. In addition, our products, services, websites or acts conducted in the ordinary course of our business may violate, or be perceived to violate, intellectual property rights of third parties (in particular, copyrights, trade marks, design rights, patents and software) and we may be subject to infringement claims. We may also be involved in claims raised by third parties against our suppliers. For example, we may be involved in claims regarding products or services supplied by our suppliers that are perceived as infringing intellectual property rights of third parties. ### 95 ----- Third parties may assert intellectual property claims against us as we expand our business to include new services and continue to develop our online channel. We may also face claims from our suppliers if they consider that their intellectual property rights are being misused, especially where those suppliers have a strong brand image and reputation. Our defence of any claim, regardless of its merit, could be expensive and time consuming, and could divert management resources. Successful infringement claims against us could result in significant monetary liability and prevent us from selling some of our products and/or services. In addition, the resolution of claims may require us to abandon the sale or provision of the litigious product or service, redesign our own private-label products or acquire licence rights from third parties, which could have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: Robbery, shop crime and fraud in our stores may adversely affect us.
Subsubsection Text: We have been the target of robberies, burglaries, theft, fraud, embezzlement by our colleagues and other forms of crime. Despite our efforts to reduce our exposure to such crimes, for instance through security guards or security cameras on our sites, we expect to continue to be exposed to such crimes and new forms of crime. There can be no assurance that our current or future efforts to counteract crimes will be effective or that the cost of such efforts will not increase. Further, any crime we become victim of may give rise to litigation and related costs, including reputational costs and the costs linked to the diversion of the attention from our management team from day-to-day operations of our business. A single significant incident of fraud, or increases in the overall level of fraud, may be sufficient to result in significant reputational damage to us or could lead to the imposition of regulatory sanctions. Our inability to control and reduce robberies, whether intentional or not, burglaries, fraud, embezzlement or other forms of crime in a cost effective manner could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: Certain activities of our business are seasonal or cyclical in nature, and our revenue, working capital requirements and results of operations may vary from quarter to quarter as a result.
Subsubsection Text: Our sales, profits, working capital requirements and cash flows within any given year have historically been affected by seasonal fluctuations. For example, sales volumes have historically been higher in December in the run-up to the holiday season and historically lower in February. In addition, sales of certain of our products have historically been higher during the summer tourist season. These seasonal influences have a direct impact on our earnings, and fluctuations in our inventory or store closings during these peak periods could affect our working capital requirements. If seasonal fluctuations are greater than anticipated, there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our quarterly results of operations may also fluctuate significantly as a result of other factors, including the timing of new store openings, temporary or definitive closings or disposals, and the revenue contributed by new stores or the loss of revenue from closed or sold stores. For these reasons, sequential quarterly comparisons may not be a good indication of our performance or how we may perform in the future. For a further discussion of the impact of seasonality on our business, see "Management's _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Information—Seasonality of Our Results of Operations."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to payments risks, including processing risks, increases in transaction fees, actions taken by third parties that could disrupt our operations, failure by us or third parties on whom we rely to fully comply with rules and standards governing payment processing, and system failures and security breaches.
Subsubsection Text: We are reliant on electronic payment methods. We accept payments using credit and debit cards, gift cards, contactless, PayPal, Android Pay and Apple Pay. As we offer new payment options to customers, we and our customers may be increasingly exposed to fraud (although fraud is not currently a significant concern). For existing and future payment options we offer our customers, we may become subject to additional regulations and compliance requirements (including obligations to implement enhanced authentication processes that could result in significant costs and reduce the ease of use of our payments products). We pay interchange and other fees for these card payments, which may increase over time and raise operating costs and lower margins. Interchange fees on Visa and MasterCard are regulated and are therefore currently subject to an effective minimum amount, which is beyond our control. Interchange fees on American Express payments are negotiated with American Express on an arm's-length basis. We rely on third parties to provide payment processing services, and it could disrupt our operations if these companies become unwilling or unable to provide these services. We are also subject to payment card association operating rules, certification requirements, PCI-DSS and rules governing electronic funds transfers, which could change or be reinterpreted, making them difficult or impossible to comply with. If we fail to comply with these rules or requirements, we may be subject to fines and/or higher transaction fees and, in extreme cases, may lose our ability to accept payments from customers, process electronic funds ### 96 ----- transfers or facilitate other types of online payments. See also "—We rely extensively on information _systems to process transactions, summarise results and manage our business. These systems are interdependent and disruptions in the IT infrastructure that we use could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition."_ Any failure of our payment processing systems, whether caused by a systems failure or otherwise, will adversely affect our income in the short-term and may result in us losing customers which may have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and prospects. In addition, there can be no assurance that advances in computer capabilities, new discoveries in the field of cryptography, or other events or developments will not result in a compromise or breach of the processes we use to protect customer transaction data. If any such compromise or breach were to occur, it could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. In certain circumstances, our contract with our payment card acquirer and American Express generally require us to adhere to payment card network rules which could make us liable to payment card issuers and others if information in connection with payment cards and payment card transactions that we process is compromised. In such cases, resulting liabilities could be substantial.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may from time to time pursue acquisitions, which may prove more costly than anticipated and may not generate anticipated synergies and which may have an adverse impact on our business, as could our failure to successfully integrate such businesses following acquisition. Our business could also be negatively impacted by merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by supranational and national laws and regulations.
Subsubsection Text: We have in the past acquired and may in the future from time to time acquire other companies or businesses. Pursuing future acquisitions depends on, among other things, identifying suitable acquisition or investment opportunities and successfully completing those transactions. Acquisitions involve numerous risks, any of which could harm our business, including difficulties in integrating the technologies, operations, existing contracts and personnel of an acquired company; difficulties in supporting and transitioning vendors, if any, of an acquired company; diversion of financial and management resources from existing operations or alternative acquisition opportunities; failure to realise the anticipated benefits or synergies of a transaction; failure to identify all of the problems, liabilities or other shortcomings or challenges of an acquired company or technology, including issues related to intellectual property, regulatory compliance practices, revenue recognition or other accounting practices or colleague or customer issues; risks of entering new markets in which we have limited or no experience; potential loss of key colleagues, customers and suppliers from either our current business or an acquired company's business; inability to generate sufficient revenue to offset acquisition costs; additional costs associated with funding the acquisition; and possible write-offs or impairment charges relating to acquired businesses. Furthermore, acquisitions of businesses outside of our markets may present additional challenges due to cultural and linguistic differences and the difficulties presented by integrating and managing a business that is geographically more remote. Our ability to integrate and manage acquired businesses effectively and to handle any future growth will depend upon a number of factors, and failure to manage growth effectively could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, the growth of our business to date, and our future growth, has placed and is expected to continue to place significant demands on our management and operational and financial infrastructure. Managing growth has in the past and will in the future continue to require significant expenditure and allocation of management resources, as well as an expansion in headcount. If we fail to achieve the necessary level of efficiency as we continue to grow, there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also "—We depend on the services of key _executives, and our business and growth strategy could be materially adversely impacted if we were to lose these executives and were unable to replace them with executives of equal experience and capabilities."_ Acquisitions may also increase our indebtedness, both through debt incurred to finance the acquisition and existing indebtedness of the acquired company, which could make it more difficult to incur additional indebtedness. Any increase in indebtedness in connection with an acquisition may have a material adverse effect on us. See "Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness—We may _incur additional debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Notes, and impact our ability to operate our businesses."_ Moreover, merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by national laws and regulations could negatively impact our business if such laws and regulations prevent us from expanding our growth through the consummation of mergers or acquisitions in certain categories or oblige us to divest certain stores or activities that may have an impact on our market shares in some geographical areas. At the same time, if ### 97 ----- smaller players in our markets are able to consolidate, this could increase the competitive pressure on our business due to an increase in such competitors' economies of scale and a reduction in their operating costs. Moreover, our competitors might acquire smaller players in our markets, further strengthening their position in the market. These events could cause our business, financial condition and results of operations to be materially and adversely affected.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: We depend on the services of key executives, and our business and growth strategy could be materially adversely impacted if we were to lose these executives and were unable to replace them with executives of equal experience and capabilities.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on our key executives as one of our major competitive strengths. Our success depends, in part, upon the continued services of our executive management team and our highly qualified managers to operate our business and execute our strategies. Our executives' and managers' knowledge of the market, our businesses and our company represents a key strength of our business model. The success of our business strategy and our future growth also depend on our ability to attract, train, retain and motivate skilled colleagues, managerial, sales, administration, development and operating personnel. There can be no assurance that any of our key personnel will continue to be employed by us or that we will be able to attract and retain qualified personnel in the future. The loss of a significant number of our key leaders who are in critical roles, or the failure to attract additional key personnel, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. This could also result in additional duties for the remaining members of management, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry Risks Relating to Our General Operations
Subsubsection Title: Increased criminal sophistication to facilitate human trafficking and modern slavery may lead to our business operations being infiltrated and abused more often for the illegal purpose of exploiting vulnerable individuals.
Subsubsection Text: Because of our dependency on cross-continental goods transport and the type of operations such as food packaging manufacturing that are well-documented targets for exploitation schemes by criminals, there is a risk that criminals will continue to attempt to conduct their exploitative schemes undetected within our supply chain or business operations. We have dealt with occasional incidents of modern slavery and human trafficking in recent years, and we believe that these criminal acts in general across any business sector in the United Kingdom will continue to exist and possibly increase. If we are unable to identify, act and remediate third party criminal acts quickly then, despite not having acted illegally ourselves, there is a significant risk of negative publicity.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to ASDA Pharmacy and ASDA Opticians
Subsubsection Title: Certain risks are inherent in providing pharmacy services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against us.
Subsubsection Text: We currently operate 254 pharmacies and, as a result, we are exposed to risks inherent in the packaging, dispensing, distribution and disposal of pharmaceuticals and other healthcare products, such as risks of liability for products which cause harm to customers, as well as increased regulatory risks and related costs. We cannot guarantee that the coverage limits under our insurance programmes will be adequate to protect us against future claims, or that we will be able to maintain this insurance on acceptable terms in the future, or at all. Our results of operations, financial condition or cash flows may be materially adversely affected if in the future our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate or unavailable, or there is an increase in the liability for which we self-insure, or we suffer harm to our reputation as a result of an error or omission. We are subject to numerous government regulations. Each of our in-store pharmacies must be registered with the General Pharmaceutical Council. Additionally, before a registered pharmacy can dispense prescriptions under the National Health Service, it must be included in the pharmaceutical list relating to a Health and Wellbeing Board Area, maintained by NHS England, NHS Scotland or NHS Wales. In addition, pharmacies dispensing controlled substances are required to maintain records of sale and supply and report incidents to the NHS. If we fail to comply with existing or future laws and regulations, we could be in breach of professional standards and/or NHS terms of service, which could lead to a hierarchy of penalties up to and including the loss of such pharmacy's registration. Each pharmacy therefore has a responsible pharmacist to ensure it operates in a safe and legal manner and corporate-wide this responsibility is shared by the Superintendent Pharmacist. Application of laws and regulations could subject our current practices to allegations of impropriety or illegality, or could require us to make changes to our operations. In addition, we cannot predict the impact of future legislation and regulatory changes on our pharmacy business or assure that we will be able to obtain or maintain the regulatory approvals required to operate our business. ### 98 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to ASDA Pharmacy and ASDA Opticians
Subsubsection Title: Changes in results of our pharmacy business could materially adversely affect overall results.
Subsubsection Text: A majority of our retail pharmacy revenue is generated by filling prescriptions for which we receive payment from the NHS. We also generate revenue through providing NHS services, private services and the sale of over the counter P Medicines. Our retail pharmacy operations are subject to numerous risks, including: changes in NHS reimbursement for prescription drugs; a reduction in the pharmacy global sum leading to reduced retained purchase margins available for pharmacy in England; a reduction in dispensing activity payments; the introduction of new NHS services; and a move away from reimbursement for dispensing prescription drugs; increased competition from other retail pharmacy operations, including online; overall economic conditions; and changes in the regulatory environment for the retail pharmacy industry and the pharmaceutical industry, and other changes in laws, rules and regulations that affect our retail pharmacy business. If the supply of certain pharmaceuticals provided by one or more of our vendors were to be disrupted for any reason, we would in turn have to seek a new supplier for such pharmaceuticals, with related risks of shortages or delays in our own pharmacy operations. Any such disruption could cause reputational damage and result in a number of our pharmacy customers transferring their prescriptions to other pharmacies. One or a combination of such factors may adversely affect the volumes of prescriptions we dispense, our cost of sales associated with our retail pharmacy operations, and the revenue and gross margin of those operations or result in the loss of cross-store selling opportunities and, in turn, affect our overall revenue, other results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to ASDA Pharmacy and ASDA Opticians
Subsubsection Title: Certain risks are inherent in providing optometry services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against us.
Subsubsection Text: We currently operate Opticians in 156 stores and in all four nations of the United Kingdom. We also have an online site supplying contact lenses under "General Direction." The majority of our revenue is from the sale of spectacles and eye examinations. We are regulated by the General Optical Council ("GOC"). To operate in the United Kingdom and use the title "Opticians" we have to be registered as a Body Corporate with the GOC and therefore are subject to the GOC Business Standards as well as the Opticians Act 1989. It is a requirement of the GOC that any Body Corporates which do not have GOC registrants as the majority of their Board, must have a Responsible Officer (Superintendent Optometrist) in position. All Optometrists and Opticians also have to be registered with the GOC to be able to practice and they are subject to the GOC Professional Standards as well as the Opticians Act 1989. Breaches to the GOC standards could lead to warnings, fines, sanctions on practice up to being removed from the GOC register either as a business or individual and unable to practice. All of our optical departments also hold a contract with the NHS local area team or Health Board to be able to provide NHS services. Breaches of the terms within such contracts can lead to penalties, including up to revoking such contract and stopping us providing NHS services. These penalties can occur at the store level, regional level or national level. Since 67% of our eye examinations in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and 100% of our eye examinations in Scotland were funded by the NHS in 2020, any penalties or stoppage in NHS services would have a material adverse impact on our business. Our Optometrists in all four nations also have to be registered on an NHS performer's listing to be able to provide NHS eye examinations. In England, some of our stores also conduct additional NHS services which are commissioned at a local level, which requires such stores to abide by additional NHS standard contracts with local service level agreements. Changes in the regulatory environment for the optical industry and other changes in laws, rules, NHS contract terms and regulations may also have an effect on our operating and commercial model. The provision of professional eye care services entails an inherent risk of professional malpractice and other similar claims. We may become subject to professional malpractice regulatory or NHS actions or claims under various theories relating to the professional services provided by our departments. This could also lead to a public relations and/or reputational risk both at the local and national level. We may not be able to continue to obtain adequate liability insurance at reasonable rates, in which event, the cost could require us to exit this offering, as insurance is a regulatory requirement for both a Body Corporate and individual registrants. Furthermore, our insurance may not be adequate to cover claims asserted against us, thus, potentially decreasing our future cash position. If the glazing supply provided by of our main Optical vendor was to be disrupted for any reason, our Optical operations could be severely affected until at least such time as we could transfer to a new glazing ### 99 ----- manufacturer. Any such disruption could cause reputational damage and result in a number of our Optical customers transferring their purchases to other Opticians. This may adversely affect the volumes of glasses we dispense, our cost of sales associated with our Optical operations, and the revenue and gross margin of those operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability.
Subsubsection Text: We may be subject to legal and regulatory enquiries or investigations, both civil and criminal, that could divert management time and resources and result in fines, sanctions, variation or revocation of permissions and authorisations, as well as reputational damage. For example, from time to time, we and/or our management are involved in litigation, tax audits, claims and other proceedings related to the conduct of our business, including, but not limited to, claims from our current and former employees, claims of intellectual property infringement, claims from customers (such as for injuries at our premises), claims asserting unfair competition and unfair business practices by third parties and environmental, health and safety claims (including, for example, related to the presence of asbestos in any of our properties). We could face a wide variety of employee claims, including general discrimination, privacy, labour and employment and disability claims. ASL is a defendant in over 40,000 equal value claims (the "Equal Value Claims") that began in 2008 and are proceeding before an Employment Tribunal in Manchester (the "Employment Tribunal") in the United Kingdom on behalf of current and former ASDA store employees, and further claims may be asserted in the future. The claimants allege that the work performed by employees in ASDA's retail stores is of equal value in terms of, among other things, the demands of their jobs compared to that of employees working in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities, and that the difference in pay between these job positions disparately impacts women because more women work in retail stores while more men work in warehouses and distribution facilities, and that the pay difference is not objectively justified. The claimants are requesting differential back pay based on higher wage rates in the warehouse and distribution facilities and higher wage rates on a prospective basis. In October 2016, following a preliminary hearing, the Employment Tribunal ruled that claimants could compare their positions in ASDA's retail stores with those of employees in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities. ASDA appealed the ruling and the oral argument was held before the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom in July 2020. We are awaiting a decision. Notwithstanding the appeal, claimants are proceeding in the next phase of their claims. That phase will determine whether the work performed by the claimants is of equal value to the work performed by employees in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities. At present, we cannot predict the number of such claims that may be filed, and cannot reasonably estimate any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings. Accordingly, we can provide no assurance as to the scope and outcomes of these matters and any losses that may arise from these proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows. See "Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation." Any claims could result in litigation against us and could also result in regulatory proceedings being brought against us by various governmental agencies. Often these cases raise complex factual. accounting and legal issues, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and which could require significant management time and legal expenses. Litigation and claims and regulatory proceedings against us or our management could result in unexpected expenses and liability and could also materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Even if we were successful in defending such proceedings, we could still suffer from the distraction of management resources to such proceedings, incur certain expenses and possibly face harm to our reputation from case-related publicity. The involvement in litigation and arbitration proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. See "Business—Legal Proceedings." ### 100 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to extensive, increasingly stringent and frequently changing laws and regulations and increased scrutiny from regulators and enforcement authorities, including in relation to advertising, food and product safety, health and safety matters and the environment, and both compliance and non-compliance therewith could impose substantial liabilities and costs and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of our business, our operations and properties are subject to increasingly stringent laws and regulations relating to, among other things, labour, competition, imports and exports, advertising, customer protection, alcohol and tobacco licencing, supplier relations, planning approvals for the opening of new stores, business operations, product safety, intermediation in customer credit and insurance, information technology, store safety and accessibility and health, safety and environment. Moreover, some of our businesses are subject to specific regulations, compliance with each of which can be complex and costly or can result in significant cash outflows. These include compliance with marketing laws and regulations, compliance with pharmaceutical laws and regulations, compliance with optometry laws and regulations, compliance with e-commerce laws and regulations and compliance with real estate laws and regulations. Additionally, we are subject to, among other things: telecommunications regulation, both directly and indirectly; regulations that govern our relationships with our suppliers, limiting our operational flexibility; and labour and employment laws that regulate the human resources implications of any proposals to restructure our business, our colleagues' working conditions, maximum working hours and, in certain jurisdictions, the ability to have stores open 24 hours a day or work on Sundays. We may be subject to audits and/or inquiries into our labour law practices by competent authorities and enforcement costs and penalties can be significant. For example, we are subject to the Groceries Supply Code of Practice ("GSCOP"), a statute governing the largest UK food retailers which requires these retailers to treat their suppliers fairly, lawfully and in good faith. The proposed fines for breaching the legislation may be up to 1% of the breaching retailer's turnover. Even if no fines are assessed, a finding of breach by the Groceries Code Adjudicator responsible for enforcing the GSCOP may cause negative publicity and damage our image, reputation or brand, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, we are subject to the Groceries Market Investigation (Controlled Land) Order 2010 (the "Controlled Land Order"), which is legislation administered by the CMA and designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by their competitors for grocery retailing in the future. We purchase our electricity on a wholesale basis via a dedicated subsidiary, which sells electricity back into ASDA. These electricity purchases are regulated by the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets ("OFGEM"), which is the government regulator for gas and electricity markets in Great Britain. In addition, we are subject to regulation by the Office of Communications ("OFCOM"), an independent regulator and competition authority for the UK communications industries, which regulates selling practices for mobile telecommunication services and changes to mobile termination rates, among other things. The FCA is responsible for the regulation of insurance and customer credit-related activities in the United Kingdom. Firms carrying on such activities in the United Kingdom must generally be authorised by the FCA with appropriate permissions, and FCA authorised firms are subject to ongoing regulation and supervision by the FCA. In connection with distributing the ASDA Money suite of white-labelled financial services products, ASL is authorised by the FCA with limited permission to carry out credit broking, and both ASL and ASDA Financial Services Limited are registered with the FCA as introducer appointed representatives of a number of third party insurance and credit product providers. Any failures in or inadequate controls around the customer introduction process for those regulated financial services products, or any technical deficiencies in the arrangements with such third party insurance and credit product providers, could in principle result in regulatory investigations and related costs and penalties, as well as reputational damage. Additionally, as a retailer and manufacturer of food products for human consumption, we are subject to stringent production, packing, health, quality, labelling and distribution standards. Each of our stores and our suppliers' facilities may be subject to licencing, reporting requirements and official quality controls by numerous governmental authorities. Difficulties in obtaining or failure to obtain the necessary licences or approvals could delay or prevent the development or operation of a given retail location or distribution centre. Our stores and our distribution centres are subject to regular inspection by authorities for compliance with hygiene regulations applicable to the sale, storage and manufacturing of foodstuffs and the traceability of genetically modified organisms, meats and other raw materials. Should any noncompliance with such regulations be discovered during an inspection, authorities may temporarily shut down the store, distribution centre or facility concerned and/or result in prosecution and the imposition of a fine for such non-compliance which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. ### 101 ----- Further, we are subject to various environmental and health and safety requirements, including those governing discharges to water and air, waste disposal, the clean-up of contaminated sites, product content and labelling and worker health and safety. We could incur substantial costs, including clean-up obligations, fines, penalties and other criminal and civil sanctions, and third-party claims for personal injury or property damage, as a result of violations of our liabilities under these requirements. For example, we own and operate service stations, which include significant storage of petrol or other hazardous materials, and many of our sites store fuel for use in backup generators and, as a result, we are subject to a variety of legislation governing the use, management, storage and disposal of hazardous substances, wastes and other regulated materials, such as petroleum and petroleum products, and any environmental impacts from current or historical operations at such locations. Our operations and facilities also require permits and authorisations under environmental, health and safety requirements, which are subject to renewal, modification and rescission by issuing authorities. We also may be required to incur substantial capital or other costs to comply with such requirements or those that are promulgated in the future. In addition, we could be sued for health problems caused by the use of tobacco products. In fact, various health related legal actions, proceedings and claims arising out of the sale, distribution, manufacturing, development, advertising and marketing of cigarettes have been brought against vendors of tobacco products in the United States. If this trend progressed to the United Kingdom, any unfavourable verdict against us in a health-related suit could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. From time to time, we may be notified of or otherwise become aware of additional laws and regulations that governmental organisations or others may claim should be applicable to our business. Compliance with future requirements could result in substantial costs to us. Failure to comply with any such laws or regulations could subject us to sanctions which could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or results of operations. Future changes in such laws and regulations could also have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or results of operations. The laws and regulations to which we are subject frequently change, which may materially impact our business operations, and our failure to comply with such laws can result in significant fines and other penalties. See also "—The United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union may lead to increased _costs and potential staff shortages, adverse currency impacts and increased regulatory burden." As a_ general matter, legal requirements are subject to interpretation, and we are unable to predict the ultimate cost of compliance with these requirements or their effect on our operations. Failure to define clear roles and responsibilities or to regularly communicate with and train our colleagues may result in noncompliance with applicable laws and regulations. As is the case for other retailers of our size, we may from time to time be subject to inquiries or investigations from regulatory bodies by local authorities, competition authorities or financial regulators, in the ordinary course of our business. Such authorities may take the view that we have not conducted or are not conducting our business fully in compliance with applicable laws and regulations and, consequently, we may be required to make significant expenditures to defend against allegations of wrongdoing or modify our business practices to comply with differing interpretations of existing laws and regulations or with future laws and regulations, which may increase our costs and materially limit our ability to operate our business. For a further discussion of the material regulatory regimes with which we must comply, see "Business— _Regulation."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We collect and process personal data in our daily business, and the leakage of such data may violate law and could materially adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to regulations regarding the use of personal data. In the ordinary course of our business, we collect, process and in some cases store certain personal financial and other information about our customers and colleagues (some of which may be sensitive, such as information about customers' dietary preferences or restrictions), marketing initiatives and the large number of credit and debit transactions we process. We also process sensitive information about our colleagues, including their bank details, union membership and health status. We must therefore comply with strict data protection, privacy and security laws and regulatory guidance. In order for our business to function successfully, we must process personal data, including credit and debit card information in an adequately secure manner. In addition, our online operations depend heavily upon the secure transmission of confidential information over public networks, including the use of cashless payments. We rely on third-party service providers to process customer payments made using bank cards and credit cards. See also "—We are exposed to payments risks, _including processing risks, increases in transaction fees, actions taken by third parties that could disrupt our operations, failure by us or third parties on whom we rely to fully comply with rules and standards governing payment processing, and system failures and security breaches."_ ### 102 ----- The use and handling of this personal information is regulated by evolving and increasingly demanding laws and regulations at the national and international levels, as well as by certain third party contracts. The legal and regulatory frameworks governing the use and handling of personal information are relatively new in our markets, and are still evolving. Any failure or perceived failure by us or any of our third-party service providers to comply with our policies or with any other privacy related laws, regulations, industry self-regulatory principles, industry standards or codes of conduct, regulatory guidance, orders to which we may be subject or other legal obligations could materially adversely affect our reputation and brands and may result in claims, fines (including by card merchants), civil or criminal proceedings or actions against us by governmental entities or others. For example, we are subject to the GDPR which became applicable on May 25, 2018. The GDPR strengthens existing rights, provides for new rights and gives customers and colleagues increased control over their personal data, including the requirement for data collectors to process and use personal information solely for the reasons for which they were collected. Laws, such as the GDPR, restrict our ability to collect and use personal information relating to individuals including the use of that information for marketing purposes. We rely on our own colleagues to maintain our databases and seek to ensure that procedures are in place to ensure compliance (including that we maintain proper privacy notices). Non-compliance with the GDPR could result in a possible fine of up to either EUR 20,000,000 or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover for the preceding financial year, whichever is higher, for the most serious infringements. See also "—We may suffer a loss as a result of operational risk, _including human error, ineffective or inadequate designed processes, failure of IT or other systems, improper conduct by colleagues and third parties, failures by suppliers and third-party providers and criminal activity including fraud, theft and cybercrime."_ Moreover, even if we are compliant with such laws and requirements, we may not be able to prevent security breaches involving customer transaction data. If we or any of our third-party service providers fail to transmit customer information in a secure manner, if our security and information systems are compromised as a result of data corruption or loss, a cyberattack or a network security incident, or if our colleagues or certain third-parties fail to comply with data protection laws and regulations (and, as a result, information about our customers and colleagues is obtained by unauthorised persons or used inappropriately), we may be subject to the aforementioned consequences, all of which may significantly adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Laws and regulations relating to privacy, data protection, customer protection and the digital advertising business are evolving and subject to potentially different interpretations in different jurisdictions. Changes in these laws and regulations or their interpretations may force us to incur substantial costs or require us to change our business practices and may present challenges to our ability to collect customer data and promote our sites, product offerings and services through electronic communication.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We may incur liabilities that are not covered by insurance and could be exposed to significant financial risks if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate.
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to risks that are inherent to our business operations and currently maintain insurance we believe is customary for businesses of our size and type and in the markets in which we operate. For a description of our material insurance policies, see "Business—Insurance." Given the number of locations and settings in which our colleagues provide services and the range of activities our colleagues engage in, we may not always be able to foresee accurately all activities and situations in order to ensure that they are fully covered by the terms of our insurance policies and, as a result, we may not be covered by insurance in specific instances. While we seek to maintain appropriate levels of insurance, not all risks are insured or insurable. As a result, we cannot guarantee our insurance programmes will be adequate to cover future claims or operating losses incurred as a result of accidents resulting from fires, explosions, water damage, theft, political unrest, natural events causing damage to our property (buildings, furniture, equipment, merchandise or computer systems) or following a business interruption at our premises, nor that we will be able to maintain our insurance programmes on acceptable terms in the future. We typically renew our insurance on an annual basis. In connection with this renewal process, our insurance costs may increase following the occurrence of several events resulting in substantial claims for damages, in response to any negative development in our claims history or due to material price increases in the insurance market in general. The occurrence of several events resulting in substantial claims for damages in a calendar year may have a material adverse effect on our insurance premiums. If we are not able to maintain our current insurance coverage or do so at a reasonable cost or if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate or unavailable in the future, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially adversely affected. Our insurance coverage may not cover all risks, such as risks associated with the COVID-19 pandemic, and there are some risks that may only be covered to a limited extent due to limits in our insurance policies. For instance, we may incur losses that cannot be insured against or that we believe are not economically ### 103 ----- reasonable to insure. Unanticipated changes in the actuarial assumptions and management estimates underlying our reserves for such losses could result in significantly higher expense than anticipated, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also "— _Certain risks are inherent in providing optometry services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against us" and "—Certain risks are inherent in providing pharmacy services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against us."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: The international scope of the George Clothing business may subject us to additional legislative, judicial, accounting, legal, regulatory, tax, political and economic risks and conditions specific to the countries or regions in which we sell and deliver products, which could materially adversely affect our business or financial performance.
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our UK operations, George Clothing products are available for sale internationally through a third-party supplier. Our future results of operations from international sales of the George Clothing products could be negatively affected by a variety of factors, most of which are beyond our control. These factors include stability of the third-party supplier, political conditions, including political instability, local and global economic conditions, legal and regulatory constraints (such as direct marketing, regulation of product and service offerings including regulatory restrictions (such as foreign ownership restrictions) on online and retail operations in international markets), restrictive governmental actions (such as trade protection measures), local product safety and environmental laws, tax regulations, local labour laws, antimoney laundering laws and regulations, trade policies, currency regulations, laws and regulations regarding customer and data protection, and other matters in any of the countries or regions in which we operate, now or in the future. Additionally, following the Separation, pursuant to the TMA, Walmart is expected to grant us a licence to continue to use the George brand within the United Kingdom (for sale, marketing and distribution purposes on an exclusive basis) and outside the United Kingdom in certain specified countries in Europe (on a non-exclusive basis) where ASDA has been using the George brand prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement (and is expected to grant us a licence to use the George brand (on a non-exclusive basis) in certain other territories outside the United Kingdom and such specified European countries in substantially the same way and to the same extent as the brand was used by ASDA immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement, as specified in, and subject to the terms of, the TMA), in each case on and subject to the terms of the TMA. The TMA is expected to restrict ASDA from using the George brand (and other Licensed IP (as defined in "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions— _Trade Mark Agreement")) following Completion other than in accordance with the licences granted under_ the TMA and is expected to contain certain covenants and undertakings from ASL, including as regards ASDA's use of the George brand (and other Licensed IP); see "Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions—Trade Mark Agreement." As referred to in "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Trade Mark Agreement," Walmart will have a right to terminate the TMA under certain_ circumstances, including for material breach of the TMA by ASDA or repeated non-material breaches of the TMA by ASDA. ASDA will also indemnify the Walmart Group for losses arising out of ASDA's use of the Licensed IP (including the George brand) in material breach of the TMA. Violating the TMA with Walmart could lead to Walmart exercising its right to terminate the TMA and the licence to ASDA of the George brand, and ASDA therefore ceasing to have the right to use the George brand, as well as to potential claims by Walmart against ASDA for breach of the TMA. See also "—Our intellectual property _rights may be infringed or challenged. Intellectual property claims by third parties or our failure or inability to protect our intellectual property rights could diminish the value of our brand and weaken our competitive position."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to the risk of violations of anti-corruption laws, sanctions or other similar regulations.
Subsubsection Text: We must comply with certain anti-corruption laws or other similar regulations. We operate in certain parts of the world that lack a developed legal system or have experienced widespread corruption. Under some circumstances, strict compliance with anti-corruption laws may conflict with local customs and practices. Our internal policies mandate compliance with these laws, but we cannot ensure that our internal control policies and procedures will always protect us from acts committed by our associated persons. Violations of such laws can result in civil penalties, including fines, denial of export privileges, injunctions, interdicts, asset seizures, debarment from government contracts, termination of existing contracts, revocations or restrictions of licences, criminal fines or imprisonment. In addition, such violations could also negatively impact our reputation and consequently, our ability to retain existing customers and attract new customers. On the other hand, any such violation by our competitors, if undetected, could give them an unfair competitive advantage. The consequences that we may suffer due to the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. ### 104 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: Changes in tax rates or laws, tax liabilities or tax accounting rules could affect future results.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to complex tax laws in the United Kingdom and has historically been subject to international tax laws in connection with international sales of the George Clothing and George Home products. Changes in (or changes in interpretations of) tax treaties, tax laws or regulations or tax authority guidance could materially adversely affect our tax position, including our effective tax rate or tax payments, possibly with a retroactive effect. Our effective tax rate and tax liability will be affected by a number of factors in addition to our results of operations, accounting standards and changes in accounting standards, and future changes in the law. If our tax positions are challenged by relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect or pay or increase the costs of our services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations or our effective tax rate and have a negative effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. For example, in the United Kingdom, if the tax authority concluded that VAT was chargeable on a particular product on which we did not charge VAT to customers, we would be subject to account for such VAT. The occurrence of any of the foregoing tax risks could have a material adverse effect on ASDA's business, financial condition and results of operations. In the jurisdictions in which we operate, governments might centrally adjust the value of business rates in the property market. For instance, in the United Kingdom, the government adjusts the value of business rates to reflect changes in the property market approximately every five years. The most recent revaluation came into effect in England, Scotland and Wales on April 1, 2017 (based on rateable values from April 1, 2015). At revaluation, all properties are given a new rateable value which, depending on the underlying movement in the value of the property, can have an adverse impact on the tax liability due on the property. Adjustments of the business rates could result in increased costs and consequently could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: Tax disputes, tax audits and adverse decisions rendered by tax authorities may expose us to substantial tax liabilities which could materially impact our business and reputation.
Subsubsection Text: Tax authorities, such as HMRC, periodically examine our activities. We often rely on generally available interpretations of applicable tax laws and regulations, including interpretations made by the relevant tax authorities and courts of law. Although we believe that we have adequately assessed and accounted for our potential tax liabilities, and that our tax estimates are reasonable, there cannot be certainty that the relevant tax authorities are in agreement with our interpretation of these laws, nor, as the case may be, that such tax authorities or courts will not depart from their prior criteria. As with any purchase of a company, there may be historical tax questions on which views have been taken or disputes may have arisen or may arise, which if unfavourably determined may require us to pay settlement amounts, interest, fees or penalties, which may adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations. To the extent that any such tax liabilities arise, we should have the benefit of a Walmart guaranteed indemnity contained in the Acquisition Agreement, subject to any conditions, limitations and exclusions contained therein.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: The audit reports of Ernst & Young LLP included in this Offering Memorandum include statements purporting to limit the persons that may rely on such reports and the opinions contained therein.
Subsubsection Text: The audit reports of Ernst & Young LLP for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, which are included in this Offering Memorandum, include a statement, in accordance with guidance issued by The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, that Ernst & Young LLP does not assume responsibility to anyone (including holders of Notes) other than the Company and the Company's members as a body, for its audit work, audit reports or opinions it has formed. Ernst & Young LLP has undertaken its audit work, in accordance with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act 2006, to state to the Company's members those matters that it is required to state to them in an auditor's report and for no other purpose. Investors in the Notes should understand that these statements are intended to disclaim any liability to parties (such as purchasers of the Notes) other than to the Company and its subsidiaries with respect to those reports. The SEC would not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection with an offering of securities registered under the Securities Act, or in a report filed under the U.S. Exchange Act. If a U.S. court (or any other court) were to give effect to the limitation above, the recourse that investors in the Notes may have against the independent auditors based on their reports or the consolidated financial statements to which they relate could be limited. The extent to which auditors have responsibility or liability to third parties is unclear under the laws of many ### 105 ----- jurisdictions, including the United Kingdom, and the legal effect of these statements in the audit reports is untested in the context of an offering of securities. The inclusion of the language referred to above, however, may limit the ability of holders of the Notes to bring any action against our auditors for damages arising out of an investment in the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
