Subsubsection Title: We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the third-party brokers' opinions of pricing of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete.
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum refers to the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing with respect to the real estate portfolio owned by ASDA. Opinions of pricing of property (including those used in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing) are prepared on the basis of various assumptions, estimates and projections. In particular, the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing were produced without visual inspection of ASDA's properties and are thus based on information provided by management and certain assumptions, including, but not limited to, the assumptions that (i) in the case of Newsteer, the properties are let to ASL and in the case of Colliers, the properties are let to ASDA or to a AAA-tenant, which could include ASDA, and in both cases that ASDA is in the market for all the properties and benefits from an excellent rating, such as AAA and a very low risk of failure, (ii) all properties are freehold or long leasehold and all title, tenure, lettings, planning, taxation, statutory and local authority requirements are complied with and all properties possess a good and marketable title free from any onerous restrictions or conditions, (iii) all properties benefit from full access and egress rights together with parking and loading facilities and are connected to all main services, (iv) all properties are free from defect, in good repair and condition and well maintained and in marketable condition, compliant with all building, accessibility and fire safety regulations and there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, (v) the properties have no environmental issues such as contamination, deleterious materials, flooding, ground conditions, invasive or protected plants or species and the properties are not adversely affected by any existed or proposed environmental law, and (vi) the floor areas provided to Newsteer and Colliers by ASDA comply with the RICS Standards for measurement (other than those properties which were measured by Colliers as part of separate instruction and upon which Colliers have relied for the purposes of their opinion on pricing) and (vii) no capital expenditure is required in respect of the properties. Both Colliers and Newsteer have assumed that each property is a vacant shell unit which benefits from fully capped off services and no tenant fit-outs or fixtures and fittings beyond a typical specification with which a vacant shell unit would be let or sold have been taken into account in the respective broker's opinion of pricing. In addition, during the course of their engagement, Newsteer and Colliers did not perform site inspections, environmental audit, tests of services and amenities, investigations or tests as to the condition of the properties. Newsteer and Colliers did not make planning or permitting inquiries and did not examine deeds, leases or other documents relating to the title to our properties. The real estate advisers both assumed each property to be used to its respective authorised use under planning legislation and in accordance with the use registered with the relevant regulatory agency. We cannot assure you that the assumptions or projections used, estimates made or procedures followed in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing are correct, accurate or complete. Newsteer and Colliers provided their opinions of pricing on the relevant properties as of October 20, 2020 and do not take into account subsequent events, including the uncertain impacts of COVID-19 after such date. Accordingly, the information included in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing may not reflect the current physical, economic, competitive, market or other conditions with respect to the property portfolio. Furthermore, the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing are addressed to the Issuers only and Newsteer and Colliers have accepted no responsibility to any third party for the whole or any part of the contents of the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing. Other appraisers may reach different opinions on pricing of ASDA's property portfolio. Moreover, the pricing determined in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing could be significantly higher than the amount that would be obtained from the actual sale of the properties included in the ASDA Property Portfolio, especially in a distressed or liquidation scenario, in the event of a downturn in the local, regional or national real estate market, or if the properties are sold on an individual basis. Accordingly, the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing should not be considered a representation of the actual present or future pricing of ASDA's property portfolio. The realisable pricing of the applicable property portfolio at any given time will depend on various factors, including: - macroeconomic conditions in the United Kingdom, the European Union and elsewhere; - an economic downturn, including as a result of COVID-19; - potential changes to the competitive landscape for grocery retail; - capital expenditure requirements; ### 106 ----- - changes in occupier and investor demand; - supply and demand generally affecting pricing; - adaptability or obsolescence; - regulation (e.g. minimum energy efficiency standards); - changes in consumer behaviour and shopping habits, either organic or as a result of any other event listed above or elsewhere under "Risk Factors;" and - other factors discussed or referred to in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, we anticipate that the price of ASDA's property portfolio will change over time, and it may change materially. After the issuance of the Notes, neither third parties nor we will provide holders of the Notes with revised brokers' opinions of pricing and we expressly disclaim any duty to update such brokers' opinions of pricing under any circumstance.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: The unaudited financial data and forward-looking statements included in this Offering Memorandum need to be carefully considered and may materially differ from actual results.
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum incorporates data for the months of October and November 2020 that are derived from preliminary financial results and estimates contained in our unaudited management accounts, which have not been and will not be audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards and are subject to change. The data for the months of October and November 2020 presented in this Offering Memorandum is not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the 12 months ended December 31, 2020 and is based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and risks. As such, you should not place reliance on them when making an investment decision. We have included data for the months of October and November 2020 in order to provide information about our recent performance but this information should be treated with a higher level of caution for reasons including but not limited to the fact that management accounts are not prepared with the same level of rigor and are not subject to the same level of management review and scrutiny as interim or yearend financial information. In addition, we prepare our monthly management accounts, including those for the months of October and November 2020, in accordance with Walmart's accounting policies, which may differ materially from U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and/or IFRS, in accordance with which we have prepared the Financial Statements and certain other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum. Furthermore, management accounts may not provide for closing procedures that are as detailed as those conducted at period or year end. Additionally, management accounts may be subject to cut-off errors and misallocation of items between months. Further, the impact of COVID-19 may have further increased the risk of errors or omissions or misstatements in our management accounts due to the reduced level of resources allocated to their preparation due to homeworking arrangements.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: We may not have the ability to meet our additional financial and other reporting requirements or implement effective systems of internal control and other standards, which may adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our internal controls over financial reporting are intended to ensure we maintain accurate records, promote the accurate and timely reporting of our financial information, maintain adequate control over our assets, and detect unauthorised acquisition, use or disposition of our assets. Effective internal and disclosure controls are necessary for us to provide reliable financial reports and to operate successfully as a business. Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal controls. Any system of controls, however well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable, and not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the system are met. In addition, the design of any control system is based in part upon certain assumptions about the likelihood of future events. Because of these and other inherent limitations of control systems, there can be no assurance that any design will succeed in achieving its stated goals under all potential future conditions, regardless of how remote. If our internal controls do not keep pace with the size and sophistication of our businesses and the applicable financial reporting framework, we may not be able to implement and maintain adequate internal controls. If we fail to implement and maintain effective internal controls, it could result in material misstatements in our financial statements or failure to meet our reporting obligations in a timely manner, which may cause a loss of confidence in our reported financial information which could increase our operating costs and materially impair our ability to operate our business. ### 107 ----- Moreover, we may acquire companies or assets which we determine to be complementary to our current business. Such acquired companies or assets may have insufficient systems of internal control, or otherwise have defects which we do not discover until we begin to integrate these systems of internal control with ours. We cannot assure you that we will be successful in integrating these systems of internal control with ours, or that such a task will be within our initial expectations in terms of costs, resources and time expended.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: Our long-lived assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, may not be fully realisable and are subject to periodic testing for impairment, and we may incur significant impairment charges as a result.
Subsubsection Text: Our long-lived assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, are subject to periodic testing for impairment. We have recorded a significant amount of goodwill. Total goodwill, which represents the difference between the consideration paid plus any non-controlling interest and the acquisition date fair value of identifiable net assets, was £508.0 million as of September 30, 2020, or 2.8% of our consolidated total assets on a post-IFRS 16 basis. This represents the current carrying value of goodwill in ASDA Group Limited prior to any purchase accounting relating to the Acquisition and does not necessarily reflect the goodwill which will be recorded following the Completion when purchase price accounting will have been completed in accordance with IFRS 3 (Business Combinations). The value of any goodwill recorded on our financial statements may not be fully realisable upon sale of all or part of the business or any other liquidity event. Goodwill is recorded on the date of acquisition and, in accordance with IFRS, is tested for impairment annually and whenever there is any indication of impairment. Impairment may result from, among other things, deterioration in our performance, a decline in expected future cash flows, adverse market conditions, adverse changes in applicable laws and regulations, any changes in the key assumptions used for internal calculations of values in use and a variety of other factors. The amount of any impairment must be expensed immediately as a charge to our income statement. We can give no assurance that we will not record any goodwill impairments in the future. Any future impairment of goodwill may result in material reductions of our income and equity under IFRS.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties and risks, which could adversely impact recoveries under the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Acquisition was referred by the European Commission to the CMA on December 8, 2020. While consummation of the Acquisition is expected to take place on or about February 16, 2021, the CMA's phase 1 review of the Acquisition remains ongoing. There can be no assurance that the Acquisition will be approved within the expected timeframe, approved at all, or approved subject to conditions. If in the course of its phase 1 investigation, the CMA considers that the Acquisition may be expected to result in a substantial lessening of competition within any market or markets for goods or services in the United Kingdom, the CMA may refer the Acquisition for an in-depth phase 2 investigation. It is common practice in such circumstances to propose remedies to address any concerns identified by the CMA, in lieu of proceeding with a full phase 2 inquiry. Such remedies may include an undertaking to sell certain Forecourt Assets, to unaffiliated third parties. In the event we propose remedies to the CMA following their phase 1 investigation, there can be no assurance that our proposal will be accepted. The CMA may reject our proposal, require additional divestments or impose terms or other conditions that we may be unable or unwilling to accept. If we are unable to reach an agreement with the CMA concerning remedies in lieu of a referral to a phase 2 investigation and the Acquisition is so referred, the CMA Clearance Date could be significantly delayed. If we agree to remedies that require divestment of certain Forecourt Assets to unaffiliated third parties, the price we receive from such a mandated sale may be less than what we would have received in a fully voluntary sale process. There can be no guarantee that market conditions would be favourable in the period provided for such sales or that the price we would obtain from buyers in a mandated sale would be equal to the price that would otherwise be offered as part of a customary sales process. If we agree to remedies that require divestments but are unable to complete these transactions on acceptable terms in the time permitted, we would be in breach of our agreement with the CMA, which could result in loss in control over the divestment process or other consequences that could have a material adverse effect on our business. If the CMA believes the Acquisition may implicate a material public interest consideration, it is required to bring the matter to the attention of the UK Secretary of State. Under certain circumstances, the UK Secretary of State may issue a Public Interest Intervention Notice ("PIIN"), which would allow the UK ### 108 ----- Secretary of State to assume responsibility for review of the Acquisition. If a PIIN is issued in connection with the Acquisition, the CMA Clearance Date could be delayed. In the event the CMA refers the Acquisition to a phase 2 investigation, it has broad authority to impose remedies to address their concerns. In the event the CMA considers that remedies would not address their concerns, the CMA may decide not to approve the Acquisition. If this were to occur, the entire ASDA Group would have to be divested to unaffiliated third parties. The price we receive from such a mandated sale may be less than what we would have received in a fully voluntary sale process. There can be no guarantee as to the consideration we would obtain from buyers in a mandated sale and, in such an event, there may be insufficient funds for the Notes to be repaid. In connection with the CMA's review of the Acquisition, we expect the CMA to issue an IEO shortly before or immediately after Completion, and we expect the IEO to remain in force until the CMA Clearance Date. Under the IEO, the ASDA Group business will have to be operated independently so as not to take any action that could potentially impede the CMA's review and remediation of Acquisition-related competition concerns. In addition, the IEO will prevent any integration activities, substantive changes to the organisational structure of the ASDA Group, dispositions of ASDA Group assets and exchanges of commercially sensitive information between the ASDA Group and the Bellis Group unless we seek and obtain a derogation from the CMA. As a result of the IEO, the Bellis Group will not be able to exercise de _facto control over the ASDA Group during the pendency of the CMA investigation. Accordingly, the Issuers_ will not be able direct the ASDA Group to comply with the covenants described in "Description of the Senior _Secured Notes" and "Description of the Senior Notes" until the CMA Clearance Date, and the ASDA Group_ will have no contractual obligation to comply with those covenants until each of the ASDA Guarantors accedes to the relevant Indenture. Nevertheless, those covenants will apply to the ASDA Group from the Issue Date, and any failure to comply with these covenants will constitute a default under the Indentures. Furthermore, subject to any derogations granted, the IEO's restrictions on the ability to exchange information with the ASDA Group may limit the support that the Bellis Group may be able to provide to the ASDA Group and affect our ability to grant and creditors' ability to enforce guarantees and security interests for so long as the IEO is in force. As a result, there may be a delay in our ability to realise anticipated synergies. If we fail to abide by the terms of the IEO, the CMA may impose financial penalties of up to 5% of our total turnover. The CMA may appoint a monitoring trustee to monitor compliance with the IEO and, if it were ultimately to consider it to be necessary, the CMA may appoint a hold separate manager to operate the ASDA Group on an arm's-length basis until the CMA Clearance Date. Furthermore, if the conditions to the release of the Escrowed Proceeds, as more fully described under "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Acquisition Agreement; Timing of Completion and Issue Date; _Escrow of Proceeds" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Acquisition Agreement; Timing of Completion and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds" have not been satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date or in certain_ other circumstances (including at the discretion of Midco, a holding company of the Issuers, subject to certain conditions), the Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption and you may not obtain the return you expect to receive on the Notes. See "—If the conditions precedent to the release of the _Escrowed Proceeds are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Shortfall Agreements" and "—In the event that the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, the Issuers will be required to redeem some or all of the Notes, which means that you may not obtain the return you expect on the Notes."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: In connection with the Post-Completion Disposals or the in-kind distribution of the Post- Completion Disposal Receivables, the Issuers will not be required to comply with the restrictive covenants described in the Description of the Senior Secured Notes and the Description of the Senior Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets, the Substitute Retail Assets, the Designated Bank Accounts and the Post-Completion Disposal Receivables will not be pledged as collateral for the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Notes or the Senior Facilities and will be exempt from all restrictive covenants included in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement, except to the extent described in "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions." Moreover, the limitation on affiliate transactions_ covenants in the Indentures will expressly allow the Post-Completion Disposals. See "Description of the _Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions," "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions" and "The Transactions—The Post-Completion Transactions—Warehouse and Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility." Accordingly, the Post-Completion Disposals will not constitute a Restricted_ ### 109 ----- Payment for purposes of the limitation on restricted payments covenants in the Indentures nor will they affect the Issuers' capacities for making Restricted Payments in the future.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart.
Subsubsection Text: The Separation is a complex transaction that will require significant management attention and poses a number of risks, including: - a failure to establish or maintain our own information systems; - a failure to establish and negotiate new wholesale energy supply agreements; - a failure to establish or negotiate new deep sea freight agreements; - our inability to renegotiate key contracts previously held at the Walmart level; - our inability to renegotiate key insurance policies previously held at the Walmart level; - our inability to retain key personnel of ASDA; - the incurrence of unexpected expenses and working capital requirements; - our inability to achieve our financial and strategic goals, including synergies for the combined businesses; and - difficulty in maintaining internal controls, procedures and policies. Any of the foregoing obstacles, or a combination of them, could decrease operating profit margins or increase operating costs in absolute terms and/or as a percentage of revenue, which could in turn negatively impact our profit for future periods and cash flows. Following the Acquisition, Walmart will continue to provide a reduced selection of services to ASDA, including services such as IT and access to innovation and know-how under the TSA and the ASA, for a transitional period (envisaged to be up to three years from the Acquisition Completion Date in respect of services under the TSA (although the TSA is expected to allow for services to be provided past this date subject to an increase in costs under a cost ratchet), and for a period of two years from the Acquisition Completion Date, in respect of the services under the ASA). ASDA expects that it will be dependent on these services provided by Walmart, for the duration of the agreements pursuant to which they will be provided. For more information see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional _Agreements with Walmart." At Completion, Walmart will grant ASDA a licence pursuant to the TMA to use_ the George brand within the United Kingdom (for sale, marketing and distribution purposes on an exclusive basis) and outside the United Kingdom in certain European countries where ASDA has used the George brand prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement (on a non-exclusive basis) (and is expected to grant ASDA a licence to use the George brand in certain other territories outside the United Kingdom and such specified European countries (on a non-exclusive basis) in substantially the same way and to the same extent as the brand was used by ASDA immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement, as specified in, and subject to the terms of, the TMA), in each case on and subject to the terms of the TMA (see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions – Trade Mark Agreement"), while Walmart will continue to own the brand and retain the ability to use it in all other territories. See "Business—Our _Intellectual Property."_ We will have ongoing service relationships and agreements with Walmart pursuant to which Walmart has provided certain services to ASDA in the past. These services include sourcing of clothing and general merchandise. It is possible that such ongoing service relationships and agreements will be insufficient to cover our needs as a stand-alone company or that the agreements pursuant to which they are provided may contain terms and conditions that are not favourable to ASDA or not competitive with alternatives in the market. In addition, failure by Walmart to perform the services provided for under the service arrangements and agreements to an acceptable service level or at all may result in operational problems and increased costs to ASDA. The services to be provided by Walmart after the Acquisition may not function as efficiently as they did prior to the Acquisition and, in the event any of our service relationships and agreements with Walmart are terminated, ASDA may find it difficult to find a suitable alternative supplier of such services in a timely fashion or at all. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. As a result of the commercial deleveraging resulting from the Separation, we may not have the same ability to negotiate with third-parties and achieve the same or similar terms as under existing agreements through Walmart. We may have substantially higher costs if we fail to negotiate new agreements on similar terms or at all. ### 110 ----- In addition, the Acquisition will constitute a change of control under certain agreements entered into by ASDA and its subsidiaries. Those counterparties will be entitled to terminate their agreements with us. Some of these counterparties may exercise their termination rights, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position and results of operations. The benefits of the operational improvements that we plan to make following the Acquisition may be undermined by certain other risks we face in our day-to-day operations, including, among other things, the loss of key contracts, customers and suppliers and strikes and other industrial actions by our colleagues, which could result in disruptions to our operations and increased costs. Operational efficiency measures generally require a significant amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or otherwise have a material adverse effect on our ongoing business operations. These factors may offset any cost savings we anticipate and which we have included in our _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Consequently, our inability to realise any anticipated cost savings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: The ASDA Group will need to transition to being a standalone company and there are risks associated with such a transition.
Subsubsection Text: The ASDA Group has historically been part of the operations of Walmart, which provided them with operational, financial, and other support. As a result of the Acquisition, we became a standalone company and, accordingly, we must develop and implement the systems and infrastructure necessary to support our current and future business. We cannot assure you that we will make the transition successfully. For example, historically, certain of our accounting and information technology systems were incorporated in Walmart's larger operations. There can be no assurance that there will not be errors, delays, or other related issues resulting from the transition to a standalone company and adjustments to associated business processes or that we will be able to fix any error or issue. Any such errors or issues could have a material and adverse impact on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. Any delays in implementing required systems may lead to increased operating expenses. On the Acquisition Completion Date, ASL and Walmart are expected to enter into the TSA, under which Walmart is expected to provide certain information technology services to ASDA on a transitional basis (the "Transitional Services"). The Transitional Services, which Walmart is expected to agree to provide to support and facilitate our ability to operate on a standalone basis, cover all information technology services and telecommunication services that were provided to ASDA in the 12 months prior to the Acquisition Completion Date. Under the TSA, each relevant Transitional Service is expected to be supplied by Walmart until the earlier of (i) the migration of the relevant service as part of the separation of ASDA from Walmart, and (ii) the termination of the TSA by Walmart or ASL under certain circumstances as described under "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with _Walmart—Transitional Services Agreement." (provided that where ASDA requires any Transitional_ Services to be provided after a three-year long stop date set out in the TSA, the charges for such remaining Transitional Services under the TSA will be subject to increase pursuant to a cost ratchet). If Walmart terminates the TSA in accordance with its terms or is unable or unwilling to provide the Transitional Services as agreed, we may not be able to replace these services at an acceptable price and in a timely manner, or at all. The Transitional Services include certain IT services which are provided pursuant to third-party vendor contracts. These services will require the vendor consent to extend the term of the underlying agreement past the Acquisition Completion Date, and thereafter will have to be renegotiated with the IT vendor. We may not be able to successfully transition these systems to our standalone operations in a timely manner, or at all, or may have underestimated the costs required to do so. Any delays in implementing required functionalities and systems may lead to increased operating expenses. We will also incur costs in the future that have historically been part of Walmart's larger cost structure, including costs associated with health and welfare benefits for our colleagues, as well as internal legal, tax, regulatory and treasury services. In particular, we will need to bear the cost of hiring additional colleagues to fill any gaps left by the withdrawal of Walmart services. We will incur costs searching for and hiring individuals to fill the positions, and we may not be able to find qualified candidates at a reasonable cost, or at all. Additionally, as part of Walmart, we benefited from certain economies of scale, including with respect to our relationships with our suppliers. We cannot assure you that we will be able to maintain or build the independent relationships that are necessary for us to continue to benefit from such economies of scale or operate our business successfully. Furthermore, we cannot assure you that the estimated costs to operate as a standalone company will be consistent on a forward-looking basis. Any failure to transition successfully within the terms of the applicable Transitional Agreement(s), or to otherwise transition successfully to a standalone company, may cause us to incur substantial expenses in addition to the anticipated separation costs, and would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. ### 111 ----- Further, becoming a standalone company will require a significant amount of management's time and effort, which may divert management's attention from operating and growing our business. If we fail to achieve some or all of the benefits that are expected from becoming a standalone company, or do not achieve them in the time frame expected, there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to consummate the Post-Completion Transactions as quickly as we anticipate, or at all, and the manner in which we execute the Post-Completion Transactions may differ from what we present in this Offering Memorandum.
Subsubsection Text: Following the CMA Clearance Date, we intend to transfer the Warehouse Assets, and, to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, the Select Retail Assets and certain Substitute Retail Assets to Propco 2 or an affiliate thereof that is also an obligor in respect of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. Alternatively, such assets may remain held by the ASDA Group but continue to be charged in favour of the lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. Following the date of the Forecourt Business Disposal, we intend to transfer the share capital of Bellis Select Warehouse Holdings Limited, the direct holding company of Propco 2, to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower to repay the outstanding balance of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Proceeds Loan. See "The Transactions—The Post-Completion Transactions—Warehouse _and Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility."_ Once the Post-Completion Disposals have been completed, we intend to execute the Warehouse Sale Transactions to fund the repayment of amounts outstanding under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. When the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility has been repaid in full and cancelled, we expect Topco and its controlled affiliates to contribute such Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets (to the extent applicable) that any of them hold and an amount equal to any net proceeds received from the sale of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, Substitute Retail Assets (including any Retail Asset Disposal Proceeds) that remain following repayment in full of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility to the Group in accordance with the covenants described in "Description of the _Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Topco Covenant" and "Description of the Senior Secured Notes— Certain Covenants—Topco Covenant." See "The Transactions—The Post-Completion Transactions— Warehouse and Other Select Retail Assets Securing the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility."_ Although the firm intention of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower is to refinance the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility using only proceeds from the Warehouse Sale Transactions, there can be no guarantee that the funds raised from these transactions will be sufficient for this purpose. If such funds are not sufficient, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower is expected to supplement the proceeds from the Warehouse Sale Transactions with additional proceeds from the transfer of some or all of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets in sale transactions with unaffiliated third parties. The initial maturity date for the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility is one year from the Acquisition Completion Date, and the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower has the option to extend its term by an additional six months at its sole discretion. While we expect the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower or Propco 2, as applicable, will be able to complete the Warehouse Sale Transactions within that timeframe, changes in market conditions, unanticipated obstacles, weaker than expected demand or other factors could delay or prevent completion of some or all of these transactions. If the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower is unable to complete the Warehouse Sale Transactions on favourable terms before the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility matures, it may elect to sell some or all of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets rather than accept unfavourable terms for the Warehouse Sale Transactions or refinance the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility through alternative means. If the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower or Propco 2, as applicable, elects to sell any or all of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, any or all of the Substitute Retail Assets (in each case subject to the ASDA Leases), these assets will not be contributed back to the Group, and we will continue to incur expenses related to the ASDA Leases entered into in respect of such Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets for the duration of the ASDA Lease. Moreover, the terms of the relevant sale transactions and the ASDA Leases may constrain our use of any such Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets, which could have an adverse effect on our business. The Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower is not a subsidiary of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or the Senior Notes Issuer, and the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower will not be party to the Indentures. Although the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower and Propco 2 are under common control, we will not be able to directly compel them (or Topco or any of our other relevant non-controlled affiliates) to comply with the covenants described in "Description of the Senior ### 112 ----- _Notes—Certain Covenants—Topco Covenant" and "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Topco Covenant" or direct their negotiations with potential purchasers in connection with the_ Warehouse Sale Transactions or in connection with a sale of any Select Retail Assets or Substitute Retail Assets (in each case subject to the ASDA Leases). See "—Risk Factors Related to the Group's Structure _and Financing—The interests of the Group's principal shareholders may conflict with your interests." There_ can be no guarantee that the terms of the Warehouse Sale Transactions or any sale of the Select Retail Assets or the Substitute Retail Assets (in each case subject to the ASDA Leases) will be as favourable as the terms we would have negotiated, and this could adversely affect the terms of the ASDA Leases. See "—Risk Factors Related to the Group's Structure and Financing—The terms and conditions of the ASDA _Leases are subject to change."_ Under the Forecourt SPA, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer has undertaken to sell the share capital of Acquisition 2 to Bellis Forecourts Limited following the CMA Clearance Date subject to the IEO to be issued by the CMA ceasing to be in effect and subject to the other terms and conditions set out therein (including that Acquisition 2 has acquired the Forecourt Business). Pursuant to the separate EG Forecourt SPA, Property Newco has agreed to sell to Euro Garages Limited the share capital of Holdco (which will in turn own Bellis Forecourts Limited and therefore the Forecourt Business) promptly upon the closing of the Forecourt SPA (or in each case the shares in another member of the ASDA Group or another relevant member of the Bellis Group that (directly or indirectly) holds the Forecourt Business). See "The _Transactions—The Post-Completion Transactions—Forecourt Disposal." To the extent required, we also_ intend to transfer any Excluded Forecourts by way of Excluded Forecourt Divestments. A number of the Forecourt Assets owned by ASDA and its subsidiaries are adjacent to, and captured under the same title as, retail assets such as supermarkets, superstores and supercentres. In order to execute the Forecourt Business Disposal and any Excluded Forecourt Divestments that may be required, we will separate the title to such Forecourt Assets from the title to the adjacent retail assets by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation. We will also have to secure certain easements, servitudes and other rights and permissions necessary for the Forecourt Assets to function independent from the adjacent retail sites (the "Related

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: If the conditions precedent to the release of any Escrowed Proceeds are not satisfied or in certain other circumstances (including at the discretion of Midco, subject to certain conditions), the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Shortfall Agreements.
Subsubsection Text: Any Escrowed Proceeds will be limited initially to the gross proceeds of the Offering and will not be sufficient to pay the Special Mandatory Redemption Price, which is equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date. See "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Acquisition _Agreement; Timing of Completion Date and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Acquisition Agreement; Timing of Completion Date and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds."_ Under the terms of the Escrow Agreements, amounts may also be released from the Escrow Accounts prior to the Acquisition Completion Date to pay accrued interest on the Notes on any interest payment date occurring prior to the Escrow Release Date. In the event that the Special Mandatory Redemption Price payable upon any Special Mandatory Redemption exceeds the amount of the Escrowed Proceeds in the relevant Escrow Accounts, Midco will, for the period up to and including March 31, 2021 (as may be extended by Midco at its unilateral discretion, on one or more occasions, to a date no later than the Outside Date, the "Shortfall Agreement Termination Date"), be required to contribute an amount in cash (subject to an initial cap of £20.0 million, pursuant to the terms of the Shortfall Agreements) expected to equal the ### 113 ----- accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts (if any), in each case owing to the holders of the Notes from the Issue Date to the Shortfall Agreement Termination Date, pursuant to the Shortfall Agreements. Holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Shortfall Agreements, and must rely on the Issuers' respective rights to enforcement under the Shortfall Agreements. There can be no assurance that the relevant counterparties to the Shortfall Agreements will have sufficient funds to make this payment, and the Issuers may not have access to the funds necessary to allow them to pay the full amount of the required redemption price in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption. Your decision to invest in the Notes is made at the time of purchase. Changes in the business or financial position of the ASDA Group, or the terms of the Acquisition, between the Issue Date and the Escrow Release Date, may have an impact on our creditworthiness, and you will not be able to rescind your decision to invest in the Notes as a result thereof. See also "—In the event that the Acquisition is not _consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, the Issuers will be required to redeem some or all of the Notes, which means that you may not obtain the return you expect on the Notes."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: In the event that the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the relevant Shortfall Agreement Termination Date or the Outside Date, or in certain other circumstances (including at the discretion of Midco, subject to certain conditions), the Issuers will be required to redeem all of the Notes, which means that you may not obtain the return you expect on the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: If the Offering is consummated prior to, and not substantially concurrently with or after, the Acquisition Completion Date, the gross proceeds of the Offering will be deposited in the Escrow Accounts pending completion of the Acquisition. If this occurs, in order for the respective Escrowed Proceeds to be released the terms of each Escrow Agreement require the relevant Issuer to deliver, on a date prior to the Outside Date, an officer's certificate to the relevant Escrow Agent and the relevant Trustee certifying that there is no insolvency event of default with respect to the relevant Issuer, and the Acquisition has been consummated or will be consummated reasonably promptly, and in no event later than two Business Days, following the Release, in accordance with the terms of the Acquisition Agreement as in effect on the date of this Offering Memorandum (subject to certain exceptions). In addition, under the terms of the Shortfall Agreements, Midco has only initially committed to contribute an amount in cash (subject to an initial cap of £20.0 million) expected to equal the accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts (if any), in each case owing to the holders of the Notes from the Issue Date to the Shortfall Agreement Termination Date, which will initially be March 31, 2021 (subject to any unilateral extensions of such by Midco in its sole discretion in accordance with the terms of the Shortfall Agreements). Although we currently expect the Acquisition and the Release to occur by such date, there is a risk that the Acquisition will not be completed on or prior to the Outside Date and that the Release will not occur. If the Release does not occur on or prior to the Outside Date for any reason, if Midco has not elected to extend the initial Shortfall Agreement Termination Date (or any extension thereof) and the Release has not occurred as at such date or in certain other circumstances, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be required to redeem the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes Issuer will be required to redeem the Senior Notes pursuant, in each case, to a Special Mandatory Redemption and holders of the Notes may not obtain the investment return they expect. See "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Acquisition Agreement; Timing of Completion _and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds"" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Acquisition Agreement; Timing of Completion and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds."_ Upon such redemption, you may not be able to reinvest the proceeds from the redemption in an investment that yields comparable returns. In addition, if you purchase the Notes at a price greater than the issue price of the Notes, you may suffer a loss on your investment. Although we currently believe that all conditions to the Acquisition and Release will be satisfied and we expect to consummate the Acquisition on or before the applicable Shortfall Agreement Termination Date and in any event on the Outside Date, we cannot assure you that the Acquisition will be consummated on the terms described in this Offering Memorandum, or that the relevant Issuer will not otherwise have to redeem the Notes. See "—Risks _Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness—If the Notes are redeemed early, an investor may not be able to reinvest such proceeds in a comparable security."_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: The ASDA Group may have liabilities that are not known to us.
Subsubsection Text: Before making investments, the Shareholders conduct due diligence that they deem reasonable and appropriate based on the facts and circumstances applicable to each investment. The objective of the due diligence process is to identify attractive investment opportunities, to identify possible risks associated with that investment, including actual or potential liabilities, and to prepare a framework that may be used from the date of an acquisition to drive operational achievement and value creation. In conducting due diligence in connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders also relied on resources available to them, including ### 114 ----- public information, information provided by the ASDA Group and its former owners and information provided by third-party advisers, including in the preparation of this Offering Memorandum. When conducting due diligence, the Shareholders typically evaluate a number of important business, financial, tax, accounting, environmental and legal issues in determining whether or not to proceed with an investment. Outside consultants, legal advisors, accountants and investment banks are involved in the due diligence process in varying degrees depending on the type of investment. Nevertheless, when conducting due diligence and making an assessment regarding an investment, the Shareholders must rely on resources available to them, including information provided by the target of the investment and, in some circumstances, third-party investigations. The ASDA Group may have liabilities that the Shareholders failed or were unable to discover in the course of performing due diligence investigations in connection with the Acquisition. Following the Acquisition, we may learn of additional information about the ASDA Group that adversely affects us, such as unknown or contingent liabilities and issues relating to compliance with applicable laws and regulations. Any such liabilities, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on the business of the ASDA Group, or on the financial condition and results of operations of the ASDA Group and our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes. There can be no assurance that the due diligence undertaken in connection with the Acquisition has revealed or highlighted all relevant facts necessary or helpful in evaluating the Transactions. Furthermore, there can be no assurance as to the adequacy or accuracy of information provided during the due diligence exercise or that such information will be accurate or remain accurate in the period from the conclusion of the due diligence exercise until Completion. The due diligence process is inherently subjective. If the due diligence investigation failed to identify or appreciate material information regarding the Acquisition, we may later be forced to write down or write off certain assets, significantly modify the business plan for the ASDA Group or incur impairment or other charges. Similarly, the materialisation of certain risks, which may or may not be identified during due diligence, may lead to a loss of property, loss of value and, potentially, subsequent contractual and statutory liability to various parties.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to enforce claims relating to a breach of the warranties or pursuant to certain indemnification obligations that ASDA Holdings UK Limited has provided and undertaken under the Acquisition Agreement and related transaction documents.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, ASDA Holdings UK Limited (the "Seller"), has given certain customary warranties and undertaken certain customary indemnification obligations in the Acquisition Agreement and related transaction documentation related to the ASDA Group. Nonetheless, the Purchaser may not be able to enforce any claims against the Seller relating to breaches of these warranties or in respect of such indemnification obligations. Moreover, even if the Purchaser is able to eventually recover any losses resulting from a breach of these warranties or in respect of such obligations, the Purchaser, and therefore indirectly we, may temporarily be required to bear these losses ourselves.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: We are susceptible to claims of anti-competitive practices.
Subsubsection Text: Part of our overall strategy is to be a leader in our business sectors. We may be accused of anticompetitive practices based on our conduct and taking into account our market position. This risk may increase after the Acquisition as the Shareholders also control other entities involved in the retail industry in the United Kingdom. Any such claims could materially adversely affect our reputation, potentially result in legal proceedings that could have an impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations and require us to divest assets. Such claims could also impair our ability to conduct acquisitions accretive to our business. Before certain potential future acquisitions can be consummated, we may be required to seek approvals and consents from regulatory agencies or there may be applicable waiting periods that will need to expire. We may be unable to obtain such regulatory approvals or consents, or, in order to obtain them, we may be required to dispose of assets or take other actions that could have the effect of reducing our return on potential future acquisitions. Even if regulatory authorities do not require disposals or other actions, the regulatory approval process may have the effect of delaying our ability to implement potential future acquisitions.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to achieve some or all of the operational cost improvements and other benefits that we expect to realise as a result of the Transactions.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that, after giving effect to the Transactions, we will be able to, among other matters, better focus our financial and operational resources on our business, growth profile and strategic priorities, design and implement corporate strategies and policies targeted to our operational focus and strategic priorities, streamline our processes and infrastructure to focus on core strengths, implement and maintain a capital structure designed to meet our specific needs, and more effectively respond to industry dynamics. However, we may not be able to realise all of the cost savings we expect to achieve. The Shareholders ### 115 ----- have estimated that we will be able to achieve additional annual cost savings by pursuing a number of improvements identified during diligence. However, we cannot assure you that we will be able to successfully realise the expected benefits of these initiatives or that the costs to achieve these cost savings will not be higher than anticipated. A variety of risks could cause us not to realise some or all of the expected benefits. These risks include, among others, higher than expected standalone overhead expenses, delays in the anticipated timing of activities related to such initiatives, increased difficulty, and cost in establishing ourselves as a standalone company, lack of sustainability in cost savings over time, unexpected costs associated with operating our business, inability to eliminate duplicative back-office overhead or redundant selling and general and administrative functions and inability to avoid labour disruptions in connection with any integration of the foregoing. Our ability to successfully manage organisational changes is important for our future business success. In particular, our reputation and results of operations could be harmed if colleague morale, engagement, or productivity decline as a result of organisational or other changes. The adjustments to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA annualising the impact of the removal of Walmart royalties and IT costs and their replacement with new costs under the TSA with Walmart, other adjustments including the impact of the 2020 leap year and estimated costs relating to ASDA operating as a standalone group, one-off net impact of costs and benefits associated with COVID-19 and adjustment for certain anticipated cost savings, EG foodservice partnership synergies, synergies from the roll-out of the ASDA wholesale convenience business, the EBITDA associated with the Forecourt Assets and the Excluded Forecourts and the rent associated with the Warehouse Assets and Select Retail Assets should be treated with caution when making an investment decision. The assumptions we have made with respect to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA that we present in this Offering Memorandum are based on our current estimates and they involve risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements to be materially different from any anticipated future results, performance or achievements expressed or implied by such adjusted financial information. Moreover, our implementation of these initiatives may disrupt our operations and performance, and our estimated cost savings from these initiatives are based on several assumptions that may prove to be inaccurate and, as a result, we cannot assure you that we will realise these cost savings. If, for any reason, the benefits we realise are less than our estimates, or our improvement initiatives adversely affect our operations or cost more or take longer to implement than we project, or if our assumptions prove inaccurate, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially adversely affected. These actions may not provide the expected benefits and could lead to disruption of our operations, loss of or inability to recruit key personnel, decline in colleague productivity, weakening of internal standards, controls or procedures, and impairment of key customer and supplier relationships. In addition, cost saving and operational efficiencies from improved production processes may not be able to be sustained due to changes in customer needs, changes in regulations, availability and cost of materials or other cost variables. Our anticipated cost saving and operational run-rate synergies are based upon assumptions about our ability to implement cost saving measures in a timely fashion and within certain cost parameters. Our ability to achieve planned cost saving and operational run-rate synergies is dependent upon a significant number of assumptions, some of which may be beyond our control, including the development of the markets for our products and services, political, legal, fiscal, market and economic conditions, regulatory developments, and tariff and wage increases. If one or more of our underlying assumptions regarding these measures proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realise fully or at all, or realise in the anticipated timeframe, the expected benefits from our cost saving and operational measures.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: Any change resulting from our operations as a standalone company, whether real or perceived may negatively impact our customer and supplier relationships.
Subsubsection Text: Following the consummation of the Transactions, some of our suppliers or other companies with whom we conduct business may prefer to work with larger companies or different management teams. They may also need assurances that our financial stability on a standalone basis is sufficient to satisfy their requirements for doing or continuing to do business with them. Any failure of parties to be satisfied with our management or financial credibility could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. ### 116 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: The Group's corporate structure has undergone, and will undergo, organisational changes in the context of the Transactions, including the Separation and the Post-Completion Transactions, making it challenging to transparently assess past and future performance and legal risks of the ASDA Group.
Subsubsection Text: The Group's corporate structure has undergone, and will undergo, substantial organisational changes in the context of the Transactions, including the Separation and the Post-Completion Transactions. As a consequence, past events that are described in the Offering Memorandum as having occurred with respect to the ASDA Group reflect events that occurred before the Company existed as a stand-alone business, and may not be indicative of events that will occur following the Transactions, when the Company operates a stand-alone business. It is therefore difficult to assess the applicability or magnitude of risks disclosed in the Offering Memorandum given that such risks are based on the performance of the ASDA Group when it was operating as part of Walmart rather than as part of a separate, stand-alone legal or reporting entity. Similarly, it is difficult to predict our future performance following the Transactions, given that the historical financial information for the Company as presented in this Offering Memorandum reflects periods that have occurred prior to the Separation. The measures and share transfers implemented to reorganise the ASDA Group may also have tax effects on the Company and its subsidiaries. Given the substantial value of the Company and the complexity of the measures taken, taxes relating to those measures could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Title: We have incurred, and expect to continue to incur, significant transaction costs in connection with the Transactions.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Transactions, we have incurred and expect to continue to incur and bear significant, costs and expenses, including taxes, financial advisory, legal, accounting, consulting and other advisory fees and expenses, reorganisation and restructuring costs, severance and employee benefitrelated expenses, printing expenses and other related charges. In addition, we may incur significant onetime charges as a result of costs associated with the Transactions. We will not be able to quantify the exact amount of these charges or the period in which they will be incurred until after the Transactions are completed. Some of the factors affecting the costs associated with the Transactions include the timing of the completion of the Transactions, the resources required to transition the business to a standalone company and the length of time during which transitional services are provided by Walmart. There are also a large number of processes, policies, procedures, operations, technologies and systems that must be developed in connection with the Transactions. While we have assumed that a certain level of expenses will be incurred in connection with the Transactions, there are many factors that could affect the total amount or timing of the integration and implementation expenses. There may also be additional unanticipated significant costs in connection with the Transactions that we do not anticipate and may not be able to recoup. These costs and expenses could reduce the benefits and income we expect to achieve from the Transactions.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Rights"). In certain instances, the participation of third parties will be required to secure the Related Rights
Subsubsection Text: and consent to or satisfy formalities in respect of the separation of the titles, and there can be no assurance we will be able to persuade these third parties to assist us in a timely manner or at all. In addition, third parties may have rights over the Forecourt Assets (including rights to acquire and pre-emption rights) exercisable in the event of a transfer of the Forecourt Assets (whether of the freehold or leasehold interest and whether of whole or part). In all such cases, the transfer of those Forecourt Assets may be significantly delayed, prevented in part or prevented entirely. In respect of certain Forecourt Assets which are captured under the same leasehold title as retail assets, in order to execute the Forecourt Business Disposal and any Excluded Forecourt Divestments that may be required, we will seek relevant landlord's consent to either a surrender (or, as applicable, renunciation) of part of the lease comprising the Forecourt Asset and the re-grant of a lease of the Forecourt Asset or an underlease/sublease of that part of the title comprising the Forecourt Asset or an assignment (or, as applicable, assignation) of part of the retail asset lease that comprises the Forecourt Asset. Such leasehold title separation exercise will depend on the terms of the lease of the relevant retail asset and obtaining landlord's consent which the landlord may be entitled to withhold entirely or grant subject to compliance with certain conditions. In such cases, the transfer of those Forecourt Assets may be significantly delayed or prevented entirely.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: Our leverage and debt service obligations could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operation or prospects.
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2020, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have had total third-party debt of £4,721.0 million (equivalent). See "Capitalisation." From the Issue Date, we will be highly leveraged and we anticipate that leverage will be sustained at this level or higher for the foreseeable future. The level of indebtedness that we will hold from the Issue Date could, among other things: - limit our ability to obtain additional financing to fund future working capital, capital expenditures, business opportunities and other corporate requirements; - reduce our flexibility to respond to, and pose additional risks for us in the face of, general adverse economic and industry conditions; - reduce the portion of our cash flow from operations that will be available for uses other than servicing our debt, such as funding working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures or other general corporate purposes; - restrict us from pursuing strategic acquisitions or exploiting certain business opportunities; - limit our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; - place us at a disadvantage compared to our competitors that are not as highly leveraged; ### 117 ----- - negatively impact credit terms with our creditors; and - limit our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing. Any of these, or other, consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our debt obligations, including our obligations under the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: We may incur additional debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Notes, and impact our ability to operate our businesses.
Subsubsection Text: The agreements governing our debt limit our ability to incur additional indebtedness, but do not prohibit us from doing so. The terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility (or, in the case of the Indentures, will) permit us to incur additional debt, including in respect of committed borrowings of up to £690.0 million under the Revolving Credit Facilities. Some of this debt could rank pari _passu with the Notes, be structurally senior to the Notes or be secured on assets which do not form part_ of the Collateral for the Senior Secured Notes or part of the Senior Notes Collateral for the Senior Notes. Additional debt could also mature prior to the Notes. In addition, under the terms of the Indentures and the Intercreditor Agreement, we are permitted, subject to certain conditions (including the refinancing of the Term Loan Facilities in full), to incur new debt that has super senior priority status over the Notes in respect of the proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral and certain distressed disposals. If new debt is added to the Group's existing debt levels, the related risks that we currently face would increase. Furthermore, if we are able to designate some of our Restricted Subsidiaries under the Indentures as Unrestricted Subsidiaries, those Unrestricted Subsidiaries would be permitted to borrow beyond the limitations specified in the Indentures and engage in other activities in which Restricted Subsidiaries may not engage. See "Description of the Senior Secured Notes" and "Description of the Senior Notes." In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement does not, and the Indentures will not, prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness as defined under each of these documents, including shortterm working capital facilities up to the greater of £360.0 million and 30% of our Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the respective documents), which are permitted to be secured by security interests in the Collateral (including on a super senior basis, subject to the refinancing or repayment of the Term Loan Facilities in full and certain other conditions). If we are ever unable to service our debt, it would likely have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects and our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and the Notes Guarantees.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: Each of the Issuers is a holding company dependent upon cash flow from subsidiaries to meet its obligations on the Notes and the Notes Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: Each of the Issuers is a holding company with no independent business operations or significant assets other than investments in our subsidiaries, and we depend upon the receipt of sufficient funds from our subsidiaries to meet our obligations. We expect our operating subsidiaries to provide us with funds to meet our obligations in respect of the Notes through a combination of dividends and payments in respect of intercompany loans. Our subsidiaries' obligations under intercompany loans will be junior obligations and will be subordinated in right of payment to all of the Group's existing and future senior and senior subordinated indebtedness, including obligations under, or guarantees of obligations under, the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes. If our subsidiaries do not distribute cash sufficient to make scheduled payments on the Notes, we will not have any other source of funds that will allow us to make payments to the holders of the relevant Notes. In addition, various agreements governing the Group's debt may restrict and, in some cases may actually prohibit, the ability of these subsidiaries to move cash within their restricted group. Applicable tax laws may also subject such payments to further taxation and applicable corporate law may limit the amounts that some of our subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as dividends or distributions on their equity interests, or even prohibit such payments. In particular, our subsidiaries' ability to pay dividends to us may be limited to the amount of distributable reserves available to them. Finally, our subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes have no obligation to make payments with respect to any of the Notes. The inability to transfer cash among entities within their respective consolidated groups may mean that, even though the entities, in aggregate, may have sufficient resources to meet their obligations, they may not be permitted to make the necessary transfers from one entity in their consolidated group to another entity in their consolidated group in order to make payments to the entity owing the obligations. ### 118 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be released automatically and under which the Notes Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the relevant Trustee.
Subsubsection Text: Under various circumstances, the Senior Secured Notes Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes Collateral securing the Senior Notes will be released automatically, including: - in connection with any sale or other disposition of Collateral (other than the Security Interest in respect of the Issuer Share Collateral) to (a) a Person that is not the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (in the case of the Senior Secured Notes Collateral), the Senior Notes Issuer (in the case of the Senior Notes Collateral) or a Restricted Subsidiary (but excluding any transaction subject to "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants—Merger and Consolidation" or "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Merger and Consolidation," as applicable), if such sale or other disposition_ does not violate the covenant described under "Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Sales of Assets and Subsidiary Stock" or_ "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Sales of Assets _and Subsidiary Stock," as applicable or is otherwise permitted in accordance with the_ applicable Indenture or (b) subject to certain exceptions, any Restricted Subsidiary; - in the case of a Guarantor that is released from its Notes Guarantee pursuant to the terms of the Indentures, the release of the property and assets, and capital stock, of such Guarantor; - upon becoming a member of the Regulated Group, the release of the property and other assets, and capital stock, of such member of the Regulated Group, and upon the borrower under an intercompany loan becoming a member of the Regulated Group, the release of any Security Interest in any receivables under such intercompany loan; - in case of a Restricted Subsidiary that is not a Significant Subsidiary following the release of its Lien granted in favour of the Senior Facilities Agreement (see _"Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement—Guarantees and Security"), so long as no Event of Default has occurred and is continuing, the release of_ the property and assets, and capital stock, of such Restricted Subsidiary; provided that there is no other Indebtedness secured by a Lien on the assets of such Restricted Subsidiary that would result in the requirement for the Notes and the Notes Guarantees to be secured on such property, assets or capital stock pursuant to the terms of the relevant Indenture; - pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (including as described under "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement—Provisions Following an IPO");_ - as allowed under the amendments and waivers provisions of the Indentures; - upon payment in full of principal, interest and all other obligations on the Notes or upon legal defeasance, covenant defeasance or satisfaction and discharge of the Indentures, as provided under the Indentures; - if we designate any Restricted Subsidiary to be an Unrestricted Subsidiary in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Indentures, the release of the property and assets, and capital stock, of such Unrestricted Subsidiary; - upon the occurrence of a Suspension Event as described under "Description of the _Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status" or "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants— Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status," as applicable;_ - in connection with a Permitted Reorganisation; - as otherwise permitted in accordance with the Indentures; - in the case of the Senior Financing Proceeds Loan or any other Proceeds Loan, upon its contribution to the equity of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its Restricted Subsidiaries following the Issue Date; or - in the case of the Forecourt Assets, in connection with a Forecourt Assets Separation. ### 119 ----- In addition, under various circumstances, the Notes Guarantees will be released automatically, including: - upon a sale or other disposition (including by way of consolidation or merger) of the capital stock of the relevant Guarantor (whether by direct sale or sale of a holding company) or the sale or disposition of all or substantially all the assets of the Guarantor (other than to the applicable Issuer or a Restricted Subsidiary) otherwise permitted by the applicable Indenture; - upon the designation of the Guarantor as an Unrestricted Subsidiary in accordance with the Indentures; - upon becoming a member of the Regulated Group; - upon payment in full of principal, interest and all other obligations on the Notes or upon legal defeasance, covenant defeasance or satisfaction and discharge of the Indenture, as provided in the Indentures; - with respect to a Guarantor that is not a Significant Subsidiary, so long as no Event of Default has occurred and is continuing, to the extent such Guarantor (i) is unconditionally released and discharged from its liability with respect to the Senior Facilities and (ii) does not guarantee any Syndicated Term Facility or any other Credit Facility that provides for aggregate lending commitments in excess of £50.0 million at the relevant date of determination or Public Debt; - pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (including as described under "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement—Provisions Following an IPO");_ - as allowed under the amendments and waivers provisions of the Indentures;
