Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We operate a significant store estate of 614 stores (excluding standalone PFSs) that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). The graph below compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers. (Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020. *Ocado Market share shown.) We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. See also "Industry." 153 ----- One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to "Every Day Low Price" and our wholly-owned supplier, IPL, which enables us to take a vertically-integrated approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers and our team of flexible and engaged colleagues. Historically, we have benefited from the support of Walmart, our former parent company. We will continue to receive support from Walmart over the next three years pursuant to the Transitional Agreements negotiated in connection with the Acquisition. For more information about the ongoing support to be provided by Walmart, please see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions— _Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_ We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended December 31, 2019, our revenue was approximately £22.9 billion (including petrol), of which approximately £2 billion was online sales, and our Adjusted EBITDA was approximately £1.2 billion (including petrol). The chart below presents the breakdown of our 2019 revenue by product category (food, general merchandise, clothing and petrol), food category (ambient and fresh and produce) and channel (stores and online (including George.com)). (Source: ASDA information. Year ended December 31, 2019. Note: Does not include £61 million of other revenue.) Our differentiated operating model has resulted in strong financial performance: our successful financial profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. In 2018 and 2019, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 5.5% (including petrol), our cumulative free cash flow was approximately £1.7 billion and our average cash conversion was approximately 70%. 154 ----- The charts below show our EBITDA Margins, Adjusted EBITDA Margins, Unadjusted Cash Conversion ("Unadjusted Cash Conversion" is calculated as Unadjusted Free Cash Flow divided by EBITDA) and Unadjusted Free Cash Flow ("Unadjusted Free Cash Flow" is calculated as EBITDA less capital expenditure) for the years ended December 31, 2015 to December 31, 2019 and our cash conversion and free cash flow for the years ended December 31, 2018 to December 31, 2019. (Source: ASDA information.) (Source: ASDA information.) We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our significant freehold real estate asset portfolio. See "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing." We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we maintain a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. Within the UK value market, we have strong market shares across ambient products (13.0%), fresh/chilled (11.6%) and total grocery (12.2%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). Our offer is strong across the full food basket: our 155 ----- category market shares range from 12% to 14% (except household and toiletries) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal ASDA data, our prices are approximately 6% to 7.5% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on a 2020 year-to-date (weeks 1-42) average, based on total goods price gap percentage). Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is supplemented by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food and non-food products to customers as a convenient "one-stop shop" experience that is supported and enhanced by our strong online offer. We believe our omni-channel offer, through which we reach customers at our brick-and-mortar stores, through our significant online offering and on our app, appeals to our customers. In 2020, there were approximately 9.8 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February 28, 2020), and approximately 723,000 weekly orders post COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended September 30, 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has increased use of and engagement with our online platforms and we currently fulfil approximately 720,000 online orders per week. Our online grocery business operates from 350 stores, we offer at-home delivery and customers are also able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 ASDA Click & Collect sites. We are also expanding our 1-hour Click & Collect offer. Our business model integrates our store-based and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders. Our online grocery business is profitable and has been consistently gaining market share within one of the world's most developed online grocery markets. We have consistently outperformed the UK online grocery market and increased our online market share in the last three years. According to Kantar, we currently operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, holding 18.2% of market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) as of December 2019, which grew to 19.8% as of December 27, 2020 (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales), representing a 1.5% gain and the second-strongest share gain since December 2019 amongst our key competitors. The chart below shows the evolution of our market share as compared with our key competitors for the periods presented. See also "Industry." (Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the year-to-date as of December 27, 2020 as compared to the 52-week periods through December 31 for 2017, 2018 and 2019.) 156 ----- Our online business is already of significant scale: the chart below shows the growth of our online sales, including a breakdown of online grocery versus George.com sales, for the periods presented. (Source: ASDA information.) According to Kantar, we are the second-largest online clothing retailer overall by volume in the United Kingdom and we held 6.0% of the total UK online clothing (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) market by volume for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020. Combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £1.9 billion in 2019 (of which £1.6 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales) to a total of £2.7 billion for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 (of which £2.4 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 26% between 2018 and September 30, 2020. Additionally, our toyou service allows customers to conveniently collect and return orders from George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 119 brands and process more than 10 million parcels per year. With our team of approximately 140,000 flexible and engaged colleagues serving approximately 15 million customers each week (based on the average of weeks 39 to 42 of 2020), we are committed to and deeply invested in the UK food supply chain. Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the entire UK population, in terms of both customer demographics and geography, with our customer base skewing slightly towards value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers who are attracted by our Every Day Low Price strategy and with strong market shares in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. For more information about our customer mix, see "—Our Customers," and for more information about the geographic distribution of our stores, see "—Our Real Estate Portfolio." Second, we believe we are well-positioned geographically, with a strong regional footprint across the United Kingdom. Our store footprint is strongest in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Our large and diverse store estate offers customers a variety of differentiated shopping formats. We operate 30 supercentres, 396 superstores, 155 supermarkets and 33 ASDA Living stores. For more information on our stores, see "— _Our Store Formats."_ Subject to receipt of regulatory approvals, our 18 standalone PFSs and 305 co-located PFSs (including both their underlying real estate assets and their business operations) will be sold to EG Group pursuant to the Forecourt Business Disposal. However, to the extent we are required to do so in order to obtain regulatory approval for the Acquisition, we will sell all or part of our forecourt business to third parties. In addition, we will transfer to Propco 2 (or an affiliate) the real estate relating to the Warehouse Assets, and to the extent required pursuant to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets promptly following the CMA Clearance Date. We will continue to operate the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets pursuant to the ASDA Leases which will be put in place in accordance with the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. For more information, see "The Transactions—The _Post Completion Disposals." This "Business" section, including historical statements herein, principally_ relates the ASDA's business as it will be following the completion of the Transactions. Following the completion of the Acquisition, we will continue to benefit over the next three years from support provided by Walmart, the world's largest retailer, through the Transitional Agreements. See "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart." In addition to the Transitional Agreements, we have also agreed with Walmart to set up_ 157 ----- separation planning working groups to ensure a smooth transition. Our ongoing relationship with Walmart is expected to bring a number of benefits, in particular: ## • Information and technology support to facilitate the change from the Walmart ecosystem; • Deep research and development expertise and capabilities; • Global sourcing, leveraging Walmart's sourcing capabilities in clothing and general merchandise; • Best practices, leveraging Walmart's expertise and experience as a leading global retailer; and • Long-term support and continued partnership with Walmart's management and leadership. The graphs below shows our revenue (including petrol and other), revenue growth, EBITDA and EBITDA margin for the years ended December 31, 2007 to 2019. 158 ----- The chart below shows our SG&A expenses (including petrol expenses) by type and as a percentage of revenue (excluding petrol) for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Segment Reporting
Subsubsection Text: We are engaged in a single reportable operating segment of business: the retailing of food, clothing, general merchandise, petrol and services in a single geographical segment, the United Kingdom, and online. All significant revenue is generated by the sale of goods through retail outlets in the United Kingdom and through the Company's online channels. The operations of all product areas of the business are subject to similar economic characteristics and are sold in a similar retail environment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are affected by a combination of factors. This section discusses key factors that we believe have had a material effect on our results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, as well as those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on our results of operations and financial condition in the future. While we believe that our results of operations and financial condition, and particularly the results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, have been primarily affected by the following key factors, these factors are not exhaustive, and the entirety of this Offering Memorandum should be reviewed, particularly the "Risk Factors" section. Additionally, although we believe that the underlying operating trends that have benefitted our business in recent years, as described further below, are relatively stable and will generally continue to drive relatively steady patterns of revenue and EBITDA metrics, it is difficult to predict future performance with any degree of certainty. _COVID-19_ The outbreak and spread of COVID-19 was confirmed in the United Kingdom in early 2020 and is resulting in a high level of uncertainty and disruption to UK economic, social and political activity. The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in national and local authorities mandating or recommending various restrictions and other measures throughout most of 2020, including mandatory business restrictions and closures and social distancing, quarantine and lockdown measures. These restrictions and measures, which were intended to slow the spread of the virus and protect lives, have resulted in significant job losses across the United Kingdom and are expected to have serious adverse impacts on domestic and foreign 159 ----- economies for an unknown length of time. The effect of economic stabilisation efforts, including government payments, relief and other support to affected citizens, businesses and industries, as well as future lockdown and containment measures, is uncertain. While our grocery operations have been classified as an essential business in all locations in which we operate and have remained open to serve the needs of our customers since the outbreak in early 2020, our business has been, and we expect will continue to be, significantly impacted by COVID-19. The risks and uncertainties surrounding COVID-19 are broad, however below is a list of factors we consider to be relevant, based on an assessment of the principal financial impacts which have affected us since the start of the pandemic: - customer trends: changes in both the demand for our products as well as the methods in which customers procure our products, including: o a net increase in demand for groceries purchased through retail outlets during periods of national and regional lockdowns and other disruptions, given restrictions in place limiting customers' ability to purchase food from non-retail outlets, such as restaurants; o a net increase in the demand for certain categories of products, such as staple cooking ingredients and baking products, which correlate to apparent increases in at-home cooking, baking and eating by consumers; o a substantial increase in demand for and engagement with online grocery retail offerings, including both home delivery and Click-and-Collect options, as a result of government restrictions on movement and travel and customer fears of exposure to COVID-19; and o reduced customer demand for clothing lines, reflecting deteriorating consumer sentiment; - supply chain: impacts on availability of, and significant short-term increases in customer demand for, certain products, including; o supply chain risks relating to goods produced in areas of significant COVID-19 outbreak or other disruption from suppliers due to financial or operational difficulties; o periods of increased customer demand for certain staple inventory items, such as toilet paper, water, meat, beans, pasta and bread, as well as cleaning supplies and protective equipment, which have at times been, and may in the future again be, in short supply as a result of stockpiling and increased at-home consumption; and o periodic increases in inventory levels to respond to increases in demand for certain products, which may result in excess inventory, resulting in elevated working capital levels and holdings of inventory that we may be unable to sell, or have to sell at discounted prices if demand declines more abruptly than expected and which have, resulted in compensatory payments to suppliers for reduced or cancelled orders; - colleagues: incremental costs related to COVID-19 related impacts on staffing needs and compensation, including: o a significant increase in colleague absences caused by illness, quarantine or government mandates, resulting in increased overtime and other extraordinary labour costs in order to compensate for such absences; o extraordinary bonuses and other payroll increases or benefits paid to our front-line colleagues; and o additional payroll-related costs to meet increases in sales demand (particularly in order to fulfil elevated numbers of online orders) and to ensure adherence to ASDA safety initiatives, including the introduction of safety marshals across our store estate; - operational and other costs: increased operational and other costs incurred as a result of COVID 19 and measures taken in reaction thereto, as well as to protect the health and safety of customers and colleagues, including: o investments in personal protective equipment for our front-line colleagues, as well as 160 ----- enhanced and more frequent store sanitation practices, including application of antimicrobial protective coating to store trolleys and baskets; o investments in our stores to ensure adherence to safety recommendations and requirements, including placement of hand sanitising stations throughout stores, addition of Perspex screens at checkouts and kiosks and placement of additional signage and two-meter markers throughout stores to assist compliance with safety and social distancing measures; o one-off COVID-19 related costs, such as rental payment holidays granted to certain concession vendors; o charitable contributions to hunger relief to help feed families in need during the COVID19 pandemic and ensure that they get the food they need, which reflect ASDA's core principles; and o a temporary pause in our capital investment programme in order to protect customers, colleagues and suppliers during the initial phase of the pandemic. - government: impacts of government measures taken to limit the spread of COVID-19, as well as to mitigate the economic consequences of such government measures: o adverse impacts on the ASDA Group's operations and costs as a result of laws, regulations, interpretations, administrative orders, or applications, which have been and continue to be uncertain and difficult to predict. We consider that the principal risks and uncertainties associated with COVID-19 that have led, and could continue to lead, to a significant financial impact on our business relate, in particular, to product availability, colleague absence and restrictions on customers' ability to physically access stores. We have implemented measures to address these principal risks, including plans in place to protect product availability, to provide cover for increases in levels of colleague absence and to maximise access to ASDA for customers who are considered most vulnerable to the impacts of COVID-19. We believe that during the first UK lockdown, consumers strongly favoured supermarkets and convenience stores that were close to their homes as they responded to the UK government's "stay at home" message. During the second lockdown, we believe that the change in message from "stay at home" resulted in customers being willing to travel further during the lockdown, which supported footfall in out-oftown shops. As a result, we generally performed somewhat behind the market during first lockdown, which we believe was largely driven by not having a convenience offering as well as by consumer hesitation to venture far from home, while we generally performed somewhat ahead of the market during the second lockdown, which we believe reflects greater consumer willingness to return to more ordinary shopping habits as well as the appeal of one-stop shopping experiences, which we believe has benefitted us. This appeal was further supported by strong promotional and pricing activity during the second lockdown period. 161 ----- Structural shifts due to COVID-19 have led to increased overall growth in the grocery retail market. During the COVID-19 pandemic, customer behaviour has changed, with a shift away from out-of-home food consumption towards at-home food consumption, to the benefit of the UK grocery retail market. The chart below shows COVID-19-accelerated channel shifts over the periods presented. For further information on prevailing trends in the grocery retail market and, in particular, the recent channel shifts which have been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, please see "Industry." (Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.) Grocery sales have grown by 12.3% between December 1, 2019 and December 27, 2020, according to Kantar, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales. Changes to consumer behaviour that have positively benefitted the grocery market during the COVID-19 pandemic include: increased consumption of food at home, a shift to online shopping channels, increased preference for shopping locally, in particular during the first UK lockdown (which we believe benefitted retail groups with a strong convenience store presence), and an increased focus on food safety, hygiene and health. Despite significant challenges posed by COVID-19, our business has remained resilient, supported by a well-developed online channel which saw significant growth through the government-imposed lockdowns as customer behaviour evolved. We were able to quickly increase the capacity of our online offer in response to increased demand driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, gaining market share and improving the profitability of our online business. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have benefitted from healthy revenue growth driven by higher food sales volumes (which were in turn driven by stockpiling and increased customer demand for in-home groceries via the online grocery channel), while margins contracted due to adverse changes in sales and product mix resulting from decreases in clothing sales, which impacted the George Clothing brand, the temporary closure of 33 ASDA Living stores and the shift in product mix within the food category away from higher-margin categories, such as food-to-go, and towards lower-margin categories, such as beer, wine and spirits and meat, which factors were partially offset by lower levels of promotional activity and stronger general merchandise sales. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories. Profitability was also adversely impacted by COVID-19-related increases in operating costs, such as the increase in retail colleague wage costs (driven by bonus payments, overtime wages and wages paid colleagues absent from work due to COVID-19, as well as wages paid to colleagues who worked during such sick colleagues' absences, rather than as a result of increased wage rates), increased cost incurred in connection with supplier goodwill compensation paid to clothing suppliers, inventory markdowns on holiday ranges, enhanced cleaning and related health and safety measures, as well as higher retail operating expenditures. We have considered the outbreak of COVID-19 to be a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event: the impact on future results and cash flows is difficult to estimate and we have therefore considered a range of scenarios as described in "Accounting Policies" of the 2019 Financial Statements. See "Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—The impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to create uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control."_ 162 ----- We believe that some of the changes that have arisen during and in response to the COVID-19 pandemic affecting our business and the United Kingdom as a whole, will be persistent and potentially long-lasting, while others may be temporary and transient (for example, following the end of the pandemic, there may be a shift of consumer preferences to more out-of-home dining). The ultimate significance of the impact of COVID-19 on our financial condition, results of operations, and cash flows will be dictated by the severity of the circumstances imposed as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the length of time that such circumstances continue, which will in turn depend on the currently unknowable extent and duration of the COVID-19 pandemic and the nature and effectiveness of governmental and other actions taken in response. In March 2020, as part of a number of measures to support businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK government, the Scottish government and the devolved administrations for Wales and Northern Ireland announced full relief for rates charges applicable to certain eligible commercial properties for the rates year beginning in April 2020 (and in the case of Northern Ireland, such support ended after July 2020). This relief applied to a number of properties owned or leased by the Group and as such, no rates charge has been recognised in these accounts for the period to which this relief applied. See "Risk _Factors— Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—The impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to create uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control."_ On December 3, 2020, we publicly announced that we would voluntarily pay business rates for the April 2020/21 year on the properties to which the relief applied. As rates relief was in place at September 30, 2020, no liability existed at that date and as such, our directors have concluded that the announcement on December 3, 2020 is a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event per the guidance set out in IAS 10. Discussions with the relevant local authorities relating to the timing of payment are ongoing. _Competitive Environment_ We operate in the highly competitive UK grocery retail market, which we believe is undergoing a period of significant structural change, characterised by factors such as strong growth and aggressive pricing on the part of discounters (such as Lidl and Aldi) as well as the other traditional grocers, a shift away from brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing and the recent increase in like-for-like sales growth reported by traditional grocers, all against the backdrop of the general political and economic uncertainty, as well as the uncertain economic prospect of Brexit (including the risk that Brexit may, among other things, increase regulatory and compliance costs for imports and products shipped from mainland Great Britain to Northern Ireland, which we might pass through to customers) and the continuing COVID-19 pandemic, the latter of which has accelerated many of these trends. Across all of our market channels, we compete with grocery retailers and other operators for customers, employees, locations, products and other important aspects of our business. Our success depends on our ability to satisfy customer needs more effectively than the competition. In order to do so, we have adopted a strategy to differentiate ourselves from our competitors and compete effectively against them on product selection, quality, price, convenience of location and the overall shopping experience, among other things. Our market differentiation strategy focuses on optimising our product offerings, monitoring our mix of formats and store concepts, strengthening our brand identity through strategic partnerships and by seeking out opportunities to increase omni-channel sales. Further, our strategy is based on what we believe to be a well-established own-brand grocery offering, our large and diverse store estate that caters to our customers' different preferences and our deployment of digital tools and online platforms and innovation and a well-known and successful clothing brand, George, which was the number two clothing brand by volume of units sold (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) in the United Kingdom for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020, according to Kantar. Competition may also affect the prices we charge for our products, which in turn impacts our revenue and margins, although this is usually experienced on a product-specific basis. For example, a competitor may cut its prices to attract footfall to its stores, which in turn may require us to respond with a similar price reduction. We in turn have implemented various strategic initiatives, including our price investment in mid2020 and accompanying "That's ASDA Price" slogan and "pocket tap" PR market campaigns, investments in new product development, particularly low cost/high-quality options, and accessing the convenience market through our trial of the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience asset-light business model, to help us remain competitive. 163 ----- Prices for most of our products are set on a national basis and, as a result of significant structural changes to the UK grocery market, there has been substantial pressure on profit and EBITDA margins across the industry, which has led market participants to engage in intense short-term promotional activity, particularly through coupons and selective price cuts. At the same time, we have also experienced an overall market trend of food and other input price inflation. For example, increases in the UK National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage have led to grocery market wage inflation. Moreover, following the Brexit referendum, the relative value of the pound sterling has declined as compared to other relevant currencies, including the euro. As a result, we and other grocers have experienced inflationary pressures relating to food prices, as the price of non-British sourced foods, in particular, rose in sterling-denominated terms. In 2019, 45% of food consumed in the United Kingdom was imported, according to the UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. Overall, we believe that UK food retailers are trying to balance the retention of market share with their desire to maintain margins. We manage this input cost inflation in several ways, such as by using our bargaining power with suppliers, increasing or decreasing the prices of certain products to offset each other, through product reengineering, for example by maintaining the same price point and altering the weight or recipe, but without compromising on quality and, in certain circumstances, passing through cost increases to consumers. These changes, however, have put pressure on our profit and EBITDA margins during the periods under review and we expect moderate input cost inflation to continue during the remainder of 2020. We also monitor the competitive UK grocery retail market and trends at a regional and store concept level and react to such trends by reinforcing our market differentiation strategy, as described above, and adjusting pricing as appropriate in response to such trends. For example, consumer trends may include sustained interest (despite COVID-19) in sustainably-sourced products and plant-based eating. We also seek to identify and execute opportunities to increase our addressable market where appropriate, develop new concepts and adapt our existing formats to meet customer demand and respond to market trends. We also operate in the highly competitive UK clothing and footwear retail market through the George Clothing brand, which offers a wide variety of low cost, high-quality clothing and apparel for babies, children, men and women, including jewellery, footwear and hosiery selections. The George Clothing brand was the number two clothing brand by volume of units sold (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) in the United Kingdom for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020, according to Kantar, with strong margins as compared to food categories and strong online growth in the past three years. However, we face competitive challenges in the clothing and footwear retail market, which in the first half of 2020 experienced a significant downturn as a result of decreased clothing sales relating to the COVID-19 pandemic (see "Industry—UK Clothing and Footwear Retail Market"). Furthermore, we face competitive challenges from competitors that continue to invest in their online and in-store presence. Such competitors target some of George Clothing's key customer categories. As of September 2020, we completed a reorganisation of the George business, which was aimed at developing an agile operating model in order to enable us to retain and grow our customer base and further drive our value proposition. However, we will continue to face steep competition on the basis of, among other things, the location of our stores; our website and mobile applications, and their respective design; the breadth, quality, style, price and availability of our merchandise; and the level of customer service offered. See "Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—Competitive pressures in the apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are high." For a further discussion of our_ competitive landscape, market share and consumer trends in the UK grocery retail business, see "Industry—UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape." _General Economic Conditions in Our Geographic Markets_ Our core grocery retail business generated 85% of our total sales (excluding petrol) for the year ended December 31, 2019 and 87% of our total sales (excluding petrol) for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. The grocery retail business is generally relatively insulated from swings in demand related to general economic conditions because consumer purchases of grocery and non-grocery staples tend to be less discretionary than purchases in other retail categories. Certain of our other non-grocery offerings, on the other hand, are more correlated to discretionary spending, and therefore, are more susceptible to changes in general economic conditions. Such offerings, including George Clothing and general merchandise, generated 15% and 13% of our total sales (excluding petrol) for the year ended December 31, 2019 and for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, respectively. Notwithstanding the overall resilient nature of our core grocery retail business, consumer tastes and shopping practices are affected by specific economic conditions in the local markets in which we operate, as well as, to a lesser extent, global economic conditions. Such conditions include employment levels, inflation, GDP growth, average and minimum wage levels, real disposable income, currency exchange 164 ----- rates, consumer confidence and consumer willingness to spend. For example, we believe that when consumers are confident about current and future economic conditions, our premium grocery offerings, which carry higher margins, are more likely to attract shoppers. Moreover, we believe that consumers with rising disposal incomes are more likely to make impulse purchases, which can be margin accretive and lift average basket sizes. During times of economic stress, such as during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, basket sizes may tend to decrease while frequency of trips increases. Additionally, during a recessionary environment, we may also record more purchases of our affordably-priced and attractive midtier and opening price point own-brand products relative to local and international third-party branded goods. According to data from the World Bank, the United Kingdom has some of the strongest macroeconomic indicators globally and in Europe, ranking as the sixth largest economy globally, and the second-largest in Europe by real GDP. According to the ONS, the United Kingdom's real gross domestic product ("GDP") amounted to £2.3 trillion in 2019. According to Fitch Solutions, although the United Kingdom's GDP is projected to have declined by 9.0% in 2020 due primarily to COVID-19, GDP is expected to rebound in 2021 and return to pre-COVID-19 levels and stabilise by 2023, with an average expected GDP growth of approximately 1.7% from 2023 to 2025. Other general economic conditions in the United Kingdom have also been favourable in recent years. According to Fitch, GDP increased by 1.7%, 1.3% and 1.3% between the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively, which translated into stable household expenditure on groceries. For the nine-month period ending September 30, 2020, GDP in the United Kingdom declined by approximately 8.6%, according to ONS. Average weekly household spend on food and non-alcoholic drinks as a percentage of total household spend was 10.5%, 10.6% and 10.6% between the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. For a further discussion of the macroeconomic conditions in the UK grocery retail market and the trends affecting its growth, see "Industry." Additionally, there are a number of ways in which Brexit could have an impact on our business, results of operations and prospects. There are two areas in which we believe the potential for Brexit impacts on our business to be most relevant: non-tariff barriers to trade and Northern Ireland. As regards non-tariff barriers to trade, we believe that delays at port could pose a significant risk relating to fresh produce imported from the EU. We believe that all of the major UK grocery operators are exposed to a similar risk in this respect. We have a port delay risk mitigation plan in place, which we also would deploy in case of other disturbance events and which we would use to re-direct shipments from Calais to other ports if needed. As regards Northern Ireland, we operate 17 stores in Northern Ireland and we are eligible for the special provisions for supermarkets as we operate in Northern Ireland only and do not have any stores in the Republic of Ireland. While "supermarket solution" rules have been proposed, we believe that significant bureaucratic hurdles may result. We note that the EU has granted the United Kingdom a six-month exemption from its ban on prohibited and restricted goods for products (such as minced meat) being transported into Northern Ireland. However, this means that alternative sourcing will be needed from July 2021. We also note that current proposals would require significant re-labelling and classification updates to products in order to sell in Northern Ireland. _Sensitivity of Our Cost Structure_ Excluding purchases of goods sold, we have a largely fixed cost base in the short- to medium-term, which does not fluctuate with sales volumes. Instead, our costs generally increase from period to period based on the sensitivity of certain costs to inflation. We are able to control some costs to a certain degree, such as those related to marketing and labour (via short-term contracts as well as adjustments to the number of hours our colleagues work), but must maintain sufficient sales levels to absorb the increase in our expenses in order to maintain or improve our retail margins. We have also been able to reduce overall costs by leveraging our vertically integrated procurement arm, IPL, which is a wholly-owned supplier that serves us exclusively and provides us with a cost price advantage by eliminating the "middle man" in our supply chain. However, even after taking such actions, certain expenses such as rent, the price of food ingredients, energy costs, energy taxes and other direct and indirect taxation are outside of our control. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to our Business—We are vulnerable to fluctuations in the availability _and price of food ingredients commodities and packaging material, as well as to fluctuations in the price of electricity and fuel."_ Labour costs represent a significant part of our cost structure. Whilst we can adjust the size of our workforce, where we have proposals to reduce our headcount, we have legal obligations to consult with colleague representatives (including trade unions) and engage other labour force actors before proposals can be implemented. The obligation to consult with colleague representatives may result in amendments 165 ----- to proposed reductions in headcount and therefore take time before we can implement such changes should they proceed. Additionally, we are subject to laws setting minimum wages. During the periods presented, the UK government increased the National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage, which had an impact on our cost structure and generally increased our costs, although this has been in part offset by cost saving and efficiency initiatives. In particular, as of April 2020, the National Living Wage increased from £8.21 per hour for April 2019 to £8.72 per hour. Any further increase in wages, energy, maintenance or any other input in our cost structure which is not mitigated, can also affect our results of operations. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our failure to attract and retain qualified _colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and other changes to wage regulations could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition." Investment in New Store Concepts and Channel and Product Innovation_ One of the drivers of our results of operations is our ability to maintain our traditional customer base and attract new customers through our ongoing investments in fulfilment capacity and development of our operations, including the evolution of our network of brick-and-mortar retail stores. Our retail store network is largely mature; however, we regularly evaluate the performance of our stores and have repositioned and remodelled stores under new store concepts to improve our customers' experience and respond to their changing preferences. For example, we have refocused capital expenditure on remodelling our existing stores, in particular to realign store space and offerings to enhance our customer proposition and better respond to customers' shopping behaviour. In October 2020, we opened our first "sustainability store" at our Middleton superstore location, which is a concept designed to encourage customers to reuse and refill their products, allowing customers to bring and fill their own containers with products such as coffee, rice, pasta and other goods, as well as offering second-hand clothing and increased recycling options. We generally incur initial and ongoing capital expenditure and pre-opening costs with each new grocery retail store, although these store concept improvements are expected to require a lower capital expenditure investment than the format refurbishments we have completed in the past. We are further responding to shifting customer preferences through our recent trial of the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience asset-light business model. We believe that this store concept will allow us to access the smaller convenience market and is responsive to changes in our customers' lifestyles. This represents our first entrance into the growing convenience market, which we have undertaken with in an asset-light approach. We have also dedicated significant investment into the expansion of our online grocery channel, ASDA Groceries, and our Click & Collect and toyou services to access new and existing customers who are increasingly shopping online, a trend that has accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic. We intend to continue to target operating model improvements to our online channel supported by developments in our IT infrastructure. _The Online Grocery Market in the United Kingdom_ The UK online grocery market was estimated to have a value of £7.1 billion on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2019 and has grown faster than the overall grocery market since its inception, according to PlanetRetail. We believe it will continue to grow substantially in the mid-term, fuelled by consumers shifting to online channels and at-home consumption, which have accelerated through the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe our growth has been, and we expect our growth to continue to be in the medium term, ahead of the UK online grocery market. We currently operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, according to Kantar, representing 18.2% of the market (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) as of December 2019, which grew to 19.8% as of December 27, 2020 (on a 52week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales), representing a gain of 154 basis points and posting the second-strongest share gain of any online grocery retailer since December 2019 and throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. See "—Overview" for further detail. The UK online grocery market is intensely competitive. We compete with traditional grocery retailers that are active in the online grocery retail market, including Tesco.com, Sainsburys.co.uk, Waitrose.com and Morrisons.com, as well as with new competitors in the online grocery market, including broad-reaching e-commerce companies such as Amazon, which recently began offering online grocery sales in the United Kingdom, including through its Morrisons@Amazon offering, and which expanded the rollout of its online grocery service through Amazon Prime more broadly across the United Kingdom at the end of 2020, as well as pure online players like Ocado, which has recently added Marks & Spencer food products to its grocery offerings following the creation of a joint venture between Ocado and Marks & Spencer. In order to retain our competitiveness in the evolving UK online grocery market, we continue to develop innovative customer solutions, such as our Express Collection service which enables customers to place an order for 166 ----- collection within one hour while other grocers also explore rapid delivery offerings (e.g. Ocado Zoom, Sainsbury's Chop Chop). Furthermore, we continue to invest in strategic partnerships that lead to innovation and which we believe will drive further increases in our market share, such as our partnership with Uber Eats, which provides express and last-mile delivery options for convenience groceries. See "Business—Our Online Platform" and "Business—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners" for further detail. We believe these broad-ranging online options, and in particular our in-store picking model, has bolstered, and will continue to bolster, the performance of our online channel and our ability to adapt to shifting consumer demands. _Significant Real Estate Asset Portfolio_ We are supported by a significant freehold real estate backing from properties across the United Kingdom in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland, with 71% of our retail sites being freehold (calculated as gross square footage of freehold stores as percentage of gross square footage of total stores, as of December 20, 2020; freehold percentage also includes certain properties that are freehold with a partial leasehold or which are leasehold properties for which the leases have been classed as long leasehold for the purposes of this calculation as those leases have nil or a peppercorn ground rent). We believe we currently own a greater percentage of our real estate (by square footage) than all but one of our traditional grocer peers. See "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Financial, _Reporting and Other Matters—We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the third-party brokers' opinions of pricing of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete." Accounting Treatment of Properties Used in Our Business_ In accordance with IAS 16 (Property, Plant and Equipment), land and buildings are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses except for certain items that were revalued to fair value prior to January 1, 2004, the date of our transition to IFRS, which are measured on the basis of deemed cost, being the revalued amount at the date of that revaluation. Items under construction are valued at cost and not depreciated. Depreciation is charged from the date that the assets are available for use. Assets acquired by way of a finance lease are stated at an amount equal to the lower of fair value and the present value of the minimum lease payments at inception of the lease, less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Following the adoption of IFRS 16, these amounts are classified as right-of-use assets. When an item is disposed of or when no future economic benefits are expected to arise from its continued use, any gain or loss arising on the derecognition of the asset is included in the income statement. _Expanding Partnerships and Taking Advantage of Synergies_ Creating a platform of partnerships has been key to reaching new customers and consistently delivering innovative customer propositions that draw shoppers to our stores, driving increased sales in our core grocery retail business. We have commercialised our capabilities and years of learning derived from our retail experience to partner with various service providers who can deliver access to, among other services, new convenience and delivery channels, where we believe there are significant opportunities to serve our customers in new and appealing ways. For example, since July 2020, we have been partnering with UberEats in 100 of our stores to provide a new delivery option to our customers. Certain partnerships have also allowed us to focus on our omni-channel proposition. For example, we are currently trialling an instore and click & collect concession with the DIY product retailer, B&Q, that expands our reach to customers in the DIY and garden channel. Additionally, we have developed partnerships with general merchandise retailers, that leverage their authority in certain categories and will attract customers to our stores. For example, we have launched a trial with The Entertainer which will see them take over our offering in children's toys. Partnerships across our various channels will continue to be an important focus for us as we continue looking for new ways to reach existing and new customers and to capitalise on our customers' growing desire for convenient lifestyles, whereby individuals seek to accomplish multiple missions at once. See "Business—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners" for further detail. In addition to rental income payable from EG Group to ASDA arising from EG Group's proposed roll out of ASDA Food to Go outlets, we also anticipate synergies stemming from incremental uplift to ASDA's wholesale margin from the roll out of the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience concept, which is currently being trialled by EG Group at three of their sites. Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 reflects an adjustment of £7.0 million based on the Shareholders' estimates of the total potential forward-looking run-rate synergies that we expect to realise in the first 24 months from the anticipated uplift to ASDA related to incremental wholesale margin from the roll out of the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience concept by EG Group across its network. 167 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The comparability of the Company's historical financial information is impacted by a number of factors. This section discusses key factors that the Company believes have had a material effect on the comparability of its results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, as well as those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on its results of operations and financial condition in the future. _Seasonality of Our Results of Operations_ Our sales and cash flows are affected to a relatively limited extent by seasonal variations due to consumers' shopping habits and, to a lesser extent, weather conditions. Family groups represent a significant proportion of our customer base. As a result, our revenue has historically been comparatively higher during the Christmas and Easter periods. In general, revenue shifts due to weather tend to be relatively short-term, with impacts occurring within a given month, rather than across a quarter or a longer period. From time to time, we may also experience reduced sales revenue if inclement or severe weather reduces in-store footfall and impulse purchases, without concomitant offset by online sales. At the same time, adverse weather conditions, such as snow or flooding, can increase customer demand for our online offerings, although they can also adversely affect our ability to deliver products to customers. In this case, however, increased demand for online offerings would not likely offset reduced sales revenue in stores resulting from inclement weather, as online sales account for a comparatively small portion of our total revenue (excluding petrol) (9.8% in the year ended December 31, 2019 and 13.9% in the 12 months ended September 30, 2020). In general, our fixed costs, including labour expenses (other than related to seasonal workers), real estate leases and SG&A expenses, are more evenly distributed over the year. Additionally, our procurement and sourcing activities are also generally more evenly spread throughout the year, except for a build-up in preparation for the Christmas season. While our financial calendar generally aligns with our operational profile, we experience calendar effects when, for example, the number of trading days or payroll periods in a given period varies from period to period or year to year or certain holidays fall in different periods from year to year. As a result of the foregoing, comparisons of consecutive interim periods may not be a good indication of our performance, and the calendar effects we experience may have an impact on year-on-year comparisons of interim periods. _ASDA Group Pension Scheme Buy-In_ During the year ended December 31, 2019, the trustees of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme entered into an agreement for a bulk annuity insurance buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme with Rothesay Life. This agreement secures the benefits of members and the transaction is expected to de-risk and simplify the Company's balance sheet, is entered into with Rothesay Life, and insures the long-term benefits of approximately 12,300 members of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme. The buy-in transaction, which was enabled by a one-off final contribution by ASDA of £0.7 billion and a loan facility made available by the ASDA Group Pension Scheme's sponsor, ASL (see below), has taken place ahead of a full schemebuy-out that is expected to take place in the first half of 2021. The transaction removes future ASDA Group Pension Scheme liabilities from the ASDA and Walmart balance sheets, simplifying the business. The agreed buy-out will also mean ASDA Group Pension Scheme members will receive an individual annuity policy, issued by Rothesay Life, which will pay members' pension benefits in full. See note 1 ("Accounting _policies") and note 17 ("Employee benefits") of the 2019 Financial Statements._ At the time of the buy-in, it was agreed that certain of the assets of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme did not meet the criteria for transfer to Rothesay Life pursuant to the buy-in transaction and were retained by the ASDA Group Pension Scheme (the "Illiquid Assets"). The sponsor of the scheme, ASL, agreed to make a loan facility available to the trustees in an aggregate principal amount of £467.0 million with the principal purpose of providing liquidity to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme to allow the trustees to pay the premium in full under the buy-in policy with Rothesay Life, and also to provide prudent reserves that are available to fund the operation of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme up to completion of the buy-out and eventual winding-up (the "Pension Scheme Expenses"). The loan facility was set up on arm's-length terms, including in relation to interest. From completion of the buy-in transaction any proceeds realised in respect of the Illiquid Assets are required to be applied by the trustees to fund interest and principal payments under the loan facility, to the extent such proceeds are not required to be retained to maintain prudent reserves with respect to the Pension Scheme Expenses. Pursuant to arrangements agreed in connection with the Acquisition Agreement, payments received by ASL under the loan facility that are attributable to the Illiquid Assets are required to be paid to Walmart. Accordingly, the risk and reward of the performance of the Illiquid Assets has effectively been transferred to Walmart. To the extent that realisations from the Illiquid Assets are insufficient to cover interest and principal payments owing to ASL 168 ----- under the loan facility, ASL is obliged under a separate agreement to provide sufficient funding to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme to enable the trustees to fund such shortfall. As the amount of such funding provided by ASL to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme would be applied to repay the loan facility owing to ASL, the combined effect of such transactions would have no net impact on ASL. ASL reached an agreement with the trustees of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme to make a cash contribution of £214.6 million to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme on December 30, 2020. Such amount was applied to repay amounts due to ASL under the loan facility on the same day. _IFRS 16 (Leases)_ With respect to the 2019 Financial Statements, the Company applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach, as defined by the IFRS 16 accounting standard. The cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard were therefore recognised as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial application), while comparative figures were not restated. Additionally, previous lease-related balances including operating lease prepayments, onerous lease provisions and straight-line rent accruals have been derecognised as part of the Company's adoption of IFRS 16. The 2017 Financial Statements and the 2018 Financial Statements have not been restated for the adoption of IFRS 16 and thus cannot be directly compared to the 2019 Financial Statements, and the Company has not otherwise restated comparative amounts as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017 or 2018. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification of leases as either operating leases or finance leases for lessees and introduces a single lessee accounting model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognises a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 is to align the presentation of leases more closely to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or EBITDA and instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the lease liability and a depreciation charge on the right of use asset. _Impact on lessor accounting_ IFRS 16 does not change substantially how a lessor accounts for leases. Under IFRS 16, a lessor continues to classify leases as either finance leases or operating leases and account for those two types of leases differently. Where the Company is an intermediate lessor, the classification under IFRS 16 is required to be made with reference to the right-of-use asset that arises under the head lease. On transition to IFRS 16, there has been no change to how leases where the Company is a head or intermediate lessor are accounted for. _Practical expedients and policy choices_ The Company has applied IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach which: - requires the Company to recognise the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 16 as an adjustment to the opening balance of retained earnings at the date of initial application; and - does not permit restatement of comparatives, which continue to be presented under IAS 17 and IFRIC 4. IFRS 16 allows for certain transition and accounting policy options for companies taking the modified retrospective approach. The Company has applied the following practical expedients at January 1, 2019, but no others: - to rely on the previous identification of a lease (as provided by IAS 17 or IFRIC 4) for all contracts that existed on January 1, 2019; and - to exclude initial direct costs other than those arising on leases with lease buy-out costs from lease buy-outs (see note 11 ("Intangible Assets") of the 2019 Financial Statements) from the measurement of the right-of-use asset on January 1, 2019. With respect to all leases previously classified as operating under IAS 17, the Company has elected to measure right-of-use assets recognised on January 1, 2019 at an amount equal to the lease liability, adjusted by the amount of any prepaid or accrued lease payments relating to that lease recognised in the balance sheet immediately before January 1, 2019. 169 ----- The Company has taken the following ongoing policy choices from January 1, 2019: - to account for any lease with a term of less than 12 months as a short-term lease, recognising cost in the income on a straight line basis over the lease term and not recognising a right-of-use asset and lease liability at the contract date; - to apply the IFRS 16 low value asset exemption threshold based on the value of the asset when new, on an individual asset basis if deemed appropriate; - to apply a materiality threshold to all leases on and post transition: costs relating to leases with total undiscounted cash flows over the life of the lease below a documented threshold will be expensed as incurred and no right-of-use asset or lease liability will be recognised at the contract date; and - to elect to combine lease and non-lease components prospectively after January 1, 2019: this applies to all leases with the exception of IT and printer leases. For more information, see note 1 ("Accounting Policies") of the 2019 Financial Statements. _Financial impact of adoption_ In the year ended December 31, 2019, the overall impact of adoption of IFRS 16 on the Company's consolidated income statement was a decrease in profit before tax of £21.3 million, resulting in a decrease in operating costs of £31.4 million and an increase in finance costs of £52.7 million. In addition, right of use assets of £2,263.9 million and additional lease liabilities of £1,979.4 million were recognised on the Company's consolidated balance sheet as of January 1, 2019. _The Transactions_ Historically, the ASDA Group has had little external indebtedness. On October 2, 2020, the Shareholders announced they had reached an agreement with Walmart to acquire the Company pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement. We estimate that, following the Transactions, the Restricted Group will have total third-party debt of approximately £4,721.0 million (of which £750 million relates to the Forecourt Assets Disposal Bridge, which is expected to be repaid in full during the course of 2021). In addition, we estimate that the disposals of the Warehouse Assets by the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower or Propco 2, following the CMA Clearance Date and the consummation of the Post-Completion Disposals, may trigger a gain upon disposal and result in a net tax liability for ASDA of approximately £40 million. See "The Transactions" and "Capitalisation." Accordingly, our financial condition and results of operations following the Transactions will be impacted by interest costs related to this debt and may differ from the historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion as a result of the Transactions.
