Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) IFRS 16 was adopted on January 1, 2019. The modified retrospective approach was taken: prior year comparatives have not been restated. The table above is thus presented on an IFRS 16 basis for 2019 and an IAS 17 basis for 2018 and 2017. Adoption of IFRS 16 in the year ended December 31, 2019 resulted in a decrease to operating costs of £31.4 million and an increase to finance costs of £52.7 million compared with lease-related expenses charged in the prior year under IAS 17. _Results of operations for the nine-month period ended September 30, 2020 as compared to the nine- month period ended September 30, 2019_ Revenue Revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 was £16,589.4 million, a decrease of £183.6 million, or 1.1%, compared to £16,773.0 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to COVID-19-driven impacts. Petrol sales decreased particularly through the periods of lockdown when there was decreased travel by car. Clothing sales also decreased as consumer shopping habits changed in response to COVID-19. These reductions were partially offset by increases in food sales, particularly in edible grocery and fresh food, which were also COVID-19-driven, both due to consumer stock up behaviour ahead of lockdown and due to food spending shifting away from restaurants and takeaways. Operating costs Operating costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 were £16,098.3 million, a decrease of £290.5 million, or 1.8%, compared to £16,388.8 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower cost of goods sold, driven by decreased petrol and clothing sales, lower business rates as a result of government relief following COVID-19 and lower impairment charges following the impairment of two home shopping centres in the period ended September 30, 2019. There was also a reduction in the expense of share options in the period, primarily driven by lower increases in the Walmart share price. These decreases in operating costs were partially offset by higher cost of goods sold, due to increased food sales and increased employment costs due to COVID-19, including paying colleagues that needed to self-isolate and the payment of an additional thank you payment to colleagues. Food cost of sales was also adversely impacted by the mix of products sold, with an overall shift to lower 173 ----- margin products. There were also increased operating costs as a result of the increase in online sales participation, which incurs more costs for the picking and delivery of orders. Finance income Finance income for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 was £38.5 million, a decrease of £2.8 million, or 6.8%, compared to £41.3 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. The decrease in interest receivable on loans was primarily due to decreased bank interest receivable and was partially offset by increased interest receivable on amounts owed from group undertakings. Finance costs Finance costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 were £49.0 million, a decrease of £18.6 million, or 27.5%, compared to £67.6 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to reduced net interest cost on the defined benefit pension scheme as a result of the buy in of the ASDA Group pension scheme. Following the buy in there is no longer an additional minimum funding liability and therefore no interest charge on this liability. Income tax expense Income tax expense for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 amounted to £83.4 million, an increase of £40.3 million, or 93.5%, compared to £43.1 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to increased profit before tax and decreased available tax relief surrendered from elsewhere in the ASDA Group: in the nine months ended September 30, 2020 £24 million less in losses were surrendered to the ASDA Group than in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 amounted to a loss of £8.0 million, a change of £31.6 million, or 79.8%, compared to a loss of £39.6 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This change was primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars and the settling of those forward contracts that occurred in the relevant period: losses were caused by the GBP strengthening versus the USD over the period of forward contracts, resulting in the contracts being "out of the money." The reduced loss in the nine months ended September 30, 2020 is a result of the GBP strengthening less versus the USD over the average forward contract life in the nine months ended September 30, 2020 as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2019. Forward contracts have historically been used by the ASDA Group to hedge purchases against movements in foreign currency: these are mainly forward purchases of USD in GBP that upon settlement are used to pay for imported non-food goods for resale. These are effective hedges, therefore any gain or loss on the forward contracts is accounted for directly in equity and the cost of sale of the goods for resale is recorded at the hedged forward FX rate in the income statement. Cash flow hedges net (loss)/gain during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts Cash flow hedges net gain during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 amounted to a net gain of £18.1 million, a decrease of £16.3 million, or 47.4%, compared to a net gain of £34.4 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars in each financial year and the value of those contracts not settled at the period end based on the exchange rate at the period end. Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 was an expense of £1.7 million, a change of £3.2 million, compared to a credit of £1.5 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This change was primarily due to the tax impact of cash flow hedges changing from a net loss in 2019 to a net gain in 2020 as described above. Other comprehensive (expense)/income for the period Other comprehensive expense for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 amounted to £75.2 million, an increase of £30.5 million, compared to an expense of £44.7 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to an increase in net expense items not to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods following the defined pension buy in transaction and was partially offset by items to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result of cash flow hedges, as described above, changing from a net expense to a net credit. 174 ----- _Results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2019 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2018_ Revenue Revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019 was £22,899.2 million, a decrease of £17.3 million, or 0.1%, compared to £22,916.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to decreases in non-edible grocery, fresh food, produce, clothing and general merchandise sales and was partially offset by increases in petrol and edible grocery sales. Operating costs Operating costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £22,315.0 million, an increase of £201.7 million, or 0.9%, compared to £22,113.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to higher costs of goods sold as a result of increased petrol sales, increased inventory loss, increased impairment charges, due to the impairment of two home shopping centres in the year ended December 31, 2019, and increased share-based payment charges and was partially offset by lower costs of goods sold due to decreased non-edible grocery, clothing and general merchandise sales as well as the impact of adopting IFRS 16. IFRS 16 results in lower operating costs, as the cost of leases that were previously operating leases and expensed entirely within operating costs are now treated as finance leases, whilst the depreciation component of the charge remains in operating costs, the interest component is now charged to finance costs. Finance income Finance income for the year ended December 31, 2019 was £54.8 million, an increase of £16.9 million, or 44.6%, compared to £37.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increased interest receivable on amounts owed from group undertakings and increased bank interest receivables. The increase in interest receivable on loans was primarily due to Wal-Mart Stores (UK) Limited: the loan to this intercompany entity increased over the year due to interest not being repaid, as well as additional loans being made to that entity. There were also increased bank interest receivables due to higher average cash balances in the year. Finance costs Finance costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £82.4 million, an increase of £46.2 million compared to £36.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the impact of adopting IFRS 16 and was partially offset by increased interest income on the plan assets in excess of the interest expense on the defined benefit obligation. Income tax (expense) Income tax for the year ended December 31, 2019 was an expense of £69.6 million, a decrease of £24.9 million, or 26.3%, compared to an expense of £94.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to a reduction in profit before tax and was partially offset by decreased available tax relief surrendered from elsewhere in the ASDA Group: in the year ended December 31, 2019, £9.0 million less in losses were surrendered to the ASDA Group than in the year ended December 31, 2018. Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to a loss of £38.0 million, a change of £62.2 million compared to a gain of £24.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This change was due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars and the settling of those forward contracts that occurred in the relevant period: losses were caused by the GBP strengthening versus the USD over the period of forward contracts, resulting in the contracts being "out of the money." The loss in the year ended December 31, 2019 is a result of the GBP strengthening versus the USD over the average forward contract life, whereas the gain in the year ended December 31, 2018 is a result of the GBP weakening versus the USD over the average forward contract life. Cash flow hedges net (loss)/gain during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts Cash flow hedges net loss during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to £12.9 million, a change of £51.2 million compared to a net gain of £38.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This change was primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars in each financial year and the value of those contracts not settled at the end of the year based on the exchange rate at the end of the year. 175 ----- Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2019 was a credit of £9.5 million, a change of £21.4 million compared to an expense of £11.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This change was primarily due to the tax impact of cash flow hedges changing from a net gain in 2018 to a net loss in 2019 as described above. Other comprehensive (expense)/income for the period Other comprehensive expense for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to £113.7 million, a change of £193.8 million compared to an income of £80.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to a decrease in items not to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result of the buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme as described above and a decrease in items to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result in cash flow hedges as described above. _Results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2018 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2017_ Revenue Revenue for the year ended December 31, 2018 was £22,916.5 million, an increase of £696.7 million, or 3.1%, compared to £22,219.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to increases in grocery and petrol sales and was partially offset by decreases in clothing and general merchandise sales. Operating costs Operating costs for the year ended December 31, 2018 were £22,113.3 million, an increase of £628.9 million, or 2.9%, compared to £21,484.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to higher cost of goods sold due to increased grocery and petrol sales and increased employment costs and was partially offset by lower share option expense primarily due to lower increases in the Walmart share price. Finance income Finance income for the year ended December 31, 2018 was £37.9 million, an increase of £25.4 million compared to £12.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase in finance income was primarily due to increased interest receivable on loans to Wal-Mart Stores (UK) Limited: the loan to this intercompany entity increased over the year, due to interest not being repaid as well as additional loans being made to that entity. The increase in finance income was also due to higher average cash balances in the year. Finance costs Finance costs for the year ended December 31, 2018 were £36.2 million, an increase of £0.9 million, or 2.5%, compared to £35.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. Income tax (expense) Income tax for the year ended December 31, 2018 was an expense of £94.5 million, an increase of £47.9 million compared to an expense of £46.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to an increase in profit before tax, as well as a decrease in available tax relief surrendered from elsewhere in the ASDA Group. In the year ended December 31, 2018, £28 million less in losses were surrendered to the ASDA Group than in the year ended December 31, 2017. Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement for the year ended December 31, 2018 amounted to a gain of £24.2 million, a change of £60.1 million compared to a loss of £35.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars and the settling of those forward contracts that occurred in each financial year. Cash flow hedges - Net (loss)/gain during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts Cash flow hedges net gain during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts for the year ended December 31, 2018 amounted to £38.3 million, a change of £72.7 million compared to a net loss of £34.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars in each financial year and the value of those contracts not settled at the end of the year based on the exchange rate at the 176 ----- end of the year. Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2018 was an inflow of £11.9 million, a change of £24.4 million compared to an expense of £12.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This change was primarily due to the tax impact of cash flow hedges changing from a net loss in 2017 to a net gain in 2018, as described above. Other comprehensive (expense)/income for the period Other comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2018 amounted to £80.1 million, a change of £145.1 million compared to an expense of £65.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2017. This change was primarily due to an increase in items not to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result of the change in value of the defined benefit pension scheme's assets and liabilities and an increase in items to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result of cash flow hedges as described above.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: The Company's liquidity needs have historically been met primarily by cash flows generated from operations. In recent years, the Company's cash-generative business, due to the nature of the grocery industry, together with the Company's relatively low capital expenditure, has driven cash flow generation, including comparatively high unlevered free cash flow. Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows and borrowings under our Revolving Credit Facilities. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See "Risk Factors." Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings under our Revolving Credit Facilities, will be adequate to meet our anticipated working capital and general corporate needs for the next 12 months, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes offered hereby, or to fund our other liquidity needs. The availability of our Revolving Credit Facilities is dependent upon certain conditions, including compliance with a springing maintenance covenant as described further under "Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement."_ 177 ----- _Cash flows_ The table below presents a summary of the ASDA Group's consolidated cash flows for the periods indicated.

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) IFRS 16 was adopted on January 1, 2019. The modified retrospective approach was taken: prior year comparatives have not been restated. The table above is thus presented on an IFRS 16 basis for 2019 and an IAS 17 basis for 2018 and 2017. Cash flows (used in)/ from operating activities Cash flows from operating activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 increased by £502.0 million, from an inflow of £199.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 to an inflow of £701.5 million for nine months ended September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to increased operating profit, a lower decrease in trade and other payables for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2019, a lower increase in inventories for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and to the Company having paid no further defined benefit pension contributions in the nine months ended September 30, 2020 following the buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme in 2019. This increase was partially offset by a lower add back of non-cash charges due to lower impairment expense as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2019. The change in payables was due to timing, with the year ended December 31, 2019 particularly impacted by December 31, 2018 having a high payables balance, as this fell just before a weekly supplier payment run. Additionally, movement in payroll accruals had an impact, with lower year-to-date reduction in accruals than in the prior year and increased gift card payables, as a result of increased gift card use. The change in inventory is mainly due to September 2019 being a higher than usual inventory value, due in part to issues with excess clothing inventory that were subsequently resolved. Cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 changed by £1,329.8 million, from an inflow of £1,291.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 to an outflow of £38.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This change was primarily due to the cash outflow associated with the buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme of £827.1 million (see note 17 ("Employee benefits") of the Company's 2019 Financial Statements for further details), a decrease in trade and other payables of £385.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, as compared to an increase in trade and other payables of £242.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2018, as a result of having 53 weekly supplier payment runs in 2019, a higher benefit from negotiating improved payment terms with suppliers in 2018 than 2019 and, due to trading performance, a reduction in purchases contributing to lower trade and other payables in 2019, compared to a growth in purchases in 2018 and a reduction in operating profit of £219.0 million relating to decreases in non-edible grocery, fresh food, produce, clothing and general merchandise sales that were partially offset by increases in petrol and edible grocery sales. This was further partially offset by a change in cash flow classification arising from the implementation of IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019, which results in a higher value of cash outflows associated with lease payments being recognised within net cash flow from financing activities, rather than net cash flows from operating activities. Cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 increased by £1.8 million, from an inflow of £1,289.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to an inflow of £1,291.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increased operating profit for the year and a lower year on year increase in inventory, partially offset by an increase in trade receivables for the year ended December 31, 2018 as compared to a decrease in the year ended December 31, 2017 178 ----- and a lower increase in the share-based payment liability for the year ended December 31, 2018 than the increase recorded in the year ended December 31, 2017. Cash flows used in investing activities Cash flows used in investing activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 decreased by £148.7 million, or 78.1%, from an outflow of £190.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 to an outflow of £41.6 million for nine months ended September 30, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the cash inflow from the partial repayment of the loan made to the pension scheme as part of the pension buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme as described above. Cash flows used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by £288.5 million, or 88.6%, from an outflow of £325.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 to an outflow of £614.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme as described above (for which there was no impact in the year ended December 31, 2018), which accounted for £308 million of this change and which was partially offset by reduced capital expenditure. Cash flows used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 decreased by £48.9 million, or 13.1%, from an outflow of £374.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to an outflow of £325.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower capital expenditures, as well as higher interest received on cash held and intercompany receivables between the Group and Walmart. Cash flows used in financing activities Cash flows used in financing activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 increased by £1,178.3 million, from an outflow of £213.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 to an outflow of £1,391.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to a dividend of £1.15 billion paid in the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and no dividends having been paid during the nine months ended September 30, 2019. Cash flows used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by £112.9 million, or 51.1%, from an outflow of £221.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 to an outflow of £333.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to reclassification of cash flows following the implementation of IFRS 16, and was partially offset by a lower increase in intercompany receivables between the Group and Walmart for the year ended December 31, 2019 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2018, due to the Group providing lower loan amounts to other Walmart companies in the year ended December 31, 2019 than in the year ended December 31, 2018. Lease-related cash outflows classified as financing activities were £182.5 million (as compared to £11.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2018). Although the classification of lease-related cash outflows was impacted by the implementation in the year of IFRS 16, as noted above, there was no significant impact from IFRS 16 on total cash flows. Cash flows used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 decreased by £384.7 million, or 63.5%, from an outflow of £605.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to an outflow of £221.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to an increase in intercompany payables between the Group and Walmart for the year ended December 31, 2018, as compared to a decrease in intercompany payables between the Group and Walmart for the year ended December 31, 2017. _Revolving Credit Facilities_ As part of the Transactions, the Group entered into the Senior Facilities Agreement which provides for the Senior Facilities, including the Revolving Credit Facilities. The Group expects to draw under the Revolving Credit Facilities upon the completion of the Offering. The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for multi-currency senior secured revolving credit facilities in an aggregate amount equal to £690.0 million. The Revolving Credit Facilities may be utilised by any Original Revolving Facility Borrower or Additional Revolving Facility Borrower (subject to certain exceptions) under the Senior Facilities Agreement. Pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, a Lender may also provide Letters of Credit, Fronted Ancillary Facilities or Ancillary Facilities (in each case as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) on a bilateral basis in place of all or part of its Revolving Facility Commitment. Pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, loans made under the Revolving Credit Facilities may be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time. Such loans will be available to be used 179 ----- for, amongst other purposes, general corporate and working capital purposes of the Group (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) and, without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, to fund certain permitted acquisitions, capital expenditure, certain fees and other amounts payable in connection with the Transaction (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) and to backstop existing ancillary facilities, letters of credit and/or hedging arrangements of the Target Group (if applicable) and financing or refinancing any other transactions contemplated in connection with the Acquisition (each as defined under the Senior Facilities Agreement). The Group will be subject to certain customary affirmative, negative and incurrence covenants under the Senior Facilities Agreement, which impose restrictions on, among other things, incurrence of other debt, making restricted payments, disposal of assets and granting of security, subject to certain agreed exceptions and permissions, qualifications and thresholds. See "Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements." Capital Expenditure_ The Company typically has relatively low capital expenditure requirements. Capital expenditure has on average amounted to 1.5% of sales (excluding petrol) between the year ended December 31, 2017 and the nine months ended September 30, 2020, and has mainly been invested in store remodelling and real estate. The table below presents our capital expenditure for the periods indicated. For more information, including the definition of capital expenditure, see "Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non_IFRS Measures."

Subsubsection Text: (1) Capital expenditure is a measure of assets received by the company within the financial period whereas the purchase of property, plant and equipment and the purchase of intangible assets is a measure of cash outflow relating to the purchase of assets. The primary reason for the difference in these two items is due to the timing of when the assets are paid for. During the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018 capital expenditure focused principally on replacing essential assets and refreshing our store estate. In addition, the year ended December 31, 2018 we also opened one grocery home shopping fulfilment centre. During the year ended December 31, 2019, work started on a third George.com fulfilment centre in the North East of England, with other capital expenditure continuing to focus on replacing essential physical and digital assets and implementation of the store refresh programme. During the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, capital expenditure activity was impacted significantly by COVID-19-driven programme delays, but recovered quickly in the third quarter of the 2020 financial year, with a continued focus on our store refresh and asset replacement programmes, and on the acceleration of strategic change programmes to transform our front end and counters propositions, as well as increasing online fulfilment capacity. Our capital expenditure requirements vary from year to year based on, among other factors, specific reinvestment requirements in relation to our sites and specific initiatives to develop our technologies, and as such, we cannot assure you that our level of capital expenditure will not increase significantly in the future. 180 -----

Subsection Title: Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2020, the Company had no material off balance sheet arrangements or funding arrangements that would be classified as a contingent liability under IFRS, except for a contingent liability relating to the ongoing Equal Value Claims. With respect to these claims, the Company has not recognised a provision on the basis that any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings cannot be reasonably estimated and any potential liability is only a possible obligation, as it has yet to be confirmed whether the entity has a present obligation that could lead to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits. See note 13 ("Contingent liabilities") of the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements for further information on contingent liabilities. See "Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal _Value Litigation" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters—From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability."_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview
Subsubsection Text: _Overview_ In the ordinary course of the Company's business, it is exposed to a variety of market risks arising in relation to its financial assets and liabilities, including credit risk, interest rate risk, liquidity risk, foreign currency risk and capital risk. The Company has a risk management programme in place through which it seeks to mitigate the adverse effects of these market risks. Following consummation of the Transactions, we may hedge interest and exchange rate exposure. We do not enter into financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes. _Credit risk_ We believe there is no significant credit risk within the Company. The maximum credit risk exposure relating to financial assets is included in their carrying value as at the balance sheet date. See note 13 ("Trade and other receivables") of the Company's 2019 Financial Statements for further information on trade receivables and details of recoverability. The Company has established procedures to minimise the risk of default in relation to trade receivables including detailed credit checks undertaken before a customer is accepted. Historically, these procedures have proven effective in minimising the level of impaired and past due receivables. Surplus cash is placed on short-term deposit with various global financial institutions. This is managed by the Company's treasury function, which actively monitors the market in order to identify the best terms of deposit. Deposit limits and approved financial institutions have historically been dictated by the investment policy of the ultimate parent company. Intercompany receivables have been considered in relation to the expected credit losses 181 ----- model under IFRS 9 (Financial Instruments) and no impairment is required. _Interest rate risk_ The Company's short-term borrowings have historically all been held with entities which are part of the Walmart Inc. group and have been at fixed rates of interest. Amounts owed to fellow subsidiaries (see note 24 ("Related Parties") of the Company's 2019 Financial Statements) accrue interest at a rate of 5.448% to 6% in the year ended December 31, 2019 (which was also the case during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018). As interest rates have been fixed on all of the Company's historical debt, interest rate movements would not have an impact on profitability, cash flow or equity in prior periods. Following the Transactions and subject to the assumptions set forth under "Use of Proceeds," our indebtedness and other debt arrangements will be primarily composed of the Senior Facilities, including the Revolving Credit Facilities, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility and the Notes (all of which, other than the Notes, will bear a floating interest rate based on EURIBOR or LIBOR, as applicable). _Liquidity risk_ The Company's Treasury function ensures that the Company continues to have sufficient funding by monitoring rolling forecasts of the Company's cash flows. The Company's objective is to maintain a balance between continuity of funding and flexibility through the use of operating cash flows and intercompany balances. At December 31, 2019, the Company had no external borrowings, other than lease liabilities. At December 31, 2019, the Company held cash of £1,929.3 million (as compared to £2,916.1 million at December 31, 2018 and £2,171.7 million at December 31, 2017), utilised along with overdrafts where necessary, to secure short-term flexibility. At December 31, 2019, the Company had committed overdraft facilities of £30.0 million (as compared to £30.0 million at December 31, 2018 and £30.0 million of uncommitted overdraft facilities at December 31, 2017), standby credit facilities, including bonds of £96.7 million (as compared to £112.1 million at December 31, 2018 and £112.9 million at December 31, 2017), and committed lines of credit facilities of £30.0 million (as compared to £125.0 million at December 31, 2018 and uncommitted lines of credit facilities £125.0 million at December 31, 2017). The Company also has historically had access to an intercompany financing facility which gives ASDA the ability to borrow from other Walmart entities and which is available to other subsidiaries of Walmart, the limit of which depends on the usage by fellow subsidiaries. This intercompany financing facility will be terminated upon the completion of the Acquisition. _Foreign currency risk_ The Company purchases goods and services denominated in currencies other than pounds sterling. Cash flows can be affected by movements in exchange rates, primarily US dollars and euro. Some purchases in US dollars are managed through the use of forward contracts. The Company implements hedge accounting and had forward currency hedging contracts outstanding at December 31, 2019, designated as hedges of expected future purchases from suppliers in US dollars. The forward currency contracts are being used to hedge the foreign currency risk of the future purchases. The terms of the forward currency hedging contracts have been negotiated to match the terms of the commitments and none exceed a period of more than 12 months after December 31, 2019. Amounts recognised in other comprehensive income are transferred to the income statement when the hedged transaction affects profit or loss. The cash flow hedges of the expected future purchases were assessed to be highly effective and as at December 31, 2019, a net unrealised loss of £11.8 million (as compared to a net unrealised gain of £29.6 million as at December 31, 2018 and a net unrealised loss of £21.0 million as at December 31, 2017) was included in the hedge reserve in respect of hedging contracts. The net loss recognised in other comprehensive income during the year in respect of these hedging contracts was £41.4 million (as compared to a net gain of £50.6 million as at December 31, 2018 and a net loss of £57.8 million as at December 31, 2017). This consists of £38.0 million of gains reclassified to the income statement during the year (as compared to £24.2 million of losses as at December 31, 2018 and £35.9 million of gains as at December 31, 2017), a £12.9 million loss on not-yet-matured contracts during the year (as compared to a £38.3 million gain as at December 31, 2018 and a £34.4 million loss as at December 31, 2017) and a £9.5 million taxation credit (as compared to a £11.9 million charge as at December 31, 2018 and £12.5 million credit as at December 31, 2017). 182 ----- Under the Company's hedging policy, the only items for which forward currency contracts are in place are forecast purchases of goods for resale. The Company hedges up to 95% of forecast cash flows. Gains and losses attributable to forward contracts are transferred to cost of inventories recognised as an expense within the income statement upon maturity of the forward contract. Forward contracts entered into which are not in line with forecast cash flows would be the principal source of hedge ineffectiveness. No instances of this occurred during the year ended December 31, 2019 (which was also the case during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018), therefore amounts recognised in the income statement in relation to ineffective hedges were nil (which was also the case during the year ended December 31, 2018). The Facility B will be denominated in euro and the Senior Secured Notes, Senior Notes, Facility A and the Forecourt Assets Disposal Bridge Facility will be denominated in pounds sterling, and changes in foreign exchange rates will therefore give rise to foreign exchange exposure with respect to the Facility B. As the Company manages more than half of its foreign currency exposure through the use of forward currency contracts, changes in exchange rates are not expected to have a significant impact on shortterm profitability or cash flow. It is anticipated that a 5% movement in the US dollar/pounds sterling exchange rate, which represents management's assessment of a reasonably possible change, would give rise to a movement in the cash flow hedge reserve of £29.7 million (as compared to a movement of £36.6 million during the year ended December 31, 2018 and £42.1 million during the year ended December 31, 2017). _Capital risk_ The Company is subject to the risk that its capital structure will not be sufficient to support the growth of its business. In order to maintain or adjust the capital structure, the Company has historically had the option to adjust the amount of intercompany loans payable or receivable to and from the Walmart Inc. group of companies. There were no changes to the Company's approach to capital management during the year ended December 31, 2019. Full details of the Company's approach to capital management and how the Company defines capital is provided in the Strategic Report that is included in the 2019 Financial Statements. Full details of the amount of intercompany loans payable or receivable to and from the Walmart Inc. group of companies are disclosed in note 24 ("Related Parties") of the Company's 2019 Financial Statements.

Subsubsection Text: In the application of its accounting policies, the Company is required to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of its accounting policies and the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that are considered to be relevant. Actual results may differ from these estimates. Significant accounting policies and key accounting estimates are set out in note 1 ("Accounting _policies") of the Company's 2019 Financial Statements, as included elsewhere in this Offering_ Memorandum. 183 -----

Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of the Company's results of operations and financial condition as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, and as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2020, as derived from the Financial Statements. All references in this Offering Memorandum to the financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019 shall be deemed to be to the financial information for the relevant period prepared in accordance with IFRS. This section includes forward-looking statements, including those concerning future sales, costs, capital expenditures and financial condition. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. Results of operations for prior years are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for the year ended December 31, 2020 or any future period. See "Forward-Looking Statements" and "Risk Factors." The discussion and analysis below provides information that we believe is relevant to an assessment and understanding of our historical financial position and results of operations of the ASDA Group. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the Financial Statements and in the sections entitled "Presentation of Financial and Other Information," "Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial Data" and "Selected Consolidated Financial Information." The following discussion of our results of operations also makes reference to Non-IFRS Measures. Prospective investors should bear in mind that the EBITDA Measures, Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion and capital expenditure are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS, may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. See "Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures."_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: The retail sector in the United Kingdom, across all sales channels, was estimated by Euromonitor in the Retailing 2020 edition to have had sales of approximately £384.4 billion in 2019 (based on a Retail Value Retail Sales Price basis excluding sales tax ("Retail Value **RSP") in current value terms) and to have grown at a CAGR of 2.2% between 2007 and 2019. According to Euromonitor, grocery retail – referring to the sum of hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, and food and drink e-commerce – is the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom and in 2019 it represented £163.1 billion of Retail Value RSP (comprising approximately 42% of total retail sales). In the past twelve years, grocery retail in the United Kingdom has not experienced negative year-on-year ("YoY") growth, despite macroeconomic uncertainties and periods of food deflation measured by the consumer price index ("CPI"), according to the OECD. We operate in the retail market, offering a wide range of both food and non-food products and services from our supercentres, superstores, supermarkets and ASDA Living stores, as well as through various online platforms. The origins of our business are in the UK grocery retail market and, while our business has grown and diversified into other markets including clothing retail and general merchandise retail, we remain focused on offering high-quality, value-based grocery retail options to our customers. Within the UK grocery retail market, we hold the third-largest market share, representing 12.2% of total expenditure by households in the United Kingdom on specific grocery sectors (fresh & chilled, ambient, frozen, alcohol, household, toiletries and healthcare) ("Total Grocery Absolute Sales"), calculated on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar. 184 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Market Sizing
Subsubsection Text: The following chart sets forth the growth of the UK grocery retail market size on a Retail Value RSP basis in each calendar year from 2007 to 2019 according to Euromonitor. (Source: Euromonitor: Retailing 2020 Edition. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to the sum of channels, including hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail as well as food and drink e-commerce.) In 2019, grocery retail was the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom and was valued at £163.1 billion on a Retail Value RSP basis, according to Euromonitor. Between 2007 and 2014, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 4.3%. Between 2014 and 2019, the market experienced limited growth, in part due to stagnant or marginally declining selling prices, which led to a CAGR of 1.6% over that period. Generally, however, we believe that sales in the UK grocery retail market have demonstrated resilience and stability through economic cycles. The UK grocery retail market is expected to continue to grow in spite of the macroeconomic challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit, both of which are likely to drive recessionary shopping patterns. According to the ONS, the United Kingdom's real gross domestic product ("GDP") amounted to £2.3 trillion in 2019. The following chart sets forth the historical and projected YoY real GDP growth in the United Kingdom for the period from 2007 to 2023. According to Fitch Solutions, although the United Kingdom's GDP is projected to have declined by 9.0% in 2020 due primarily to COVID-19, GDP is expected to rebound in 2021 and return to pre-COVID-19 levels and stabilise by 2023, with an average expected GDP growth of approximately 1.7% from 2023 to 2025. (Sources: Fitch Solutions.) 185 ----- According to the ONS, as set forth in the following chart the United Kingdom's population reached 66.8 million in 2019 and is expected to grow at an approximate CAGR of 0.4% between 2019 and 2031. (Source: ONS.) In 2019, UK households spent, on average, £61.90 per week on food and non-alcoholic drinks, comprising 10.6% of average weekly household expenditure according to the ONS. Between 2007 and 2019, the percentage of average household expenditure spent on food and non-alcoholic drinks ranged from 11.3% to 10.4%, as shown in the following chart. (Source: ONS.) Furthermore, the split between at-home and out-of-home ("OOH") food and drink consumption in the United Kingdom has remained relatively stable in recent years. While the percentage of at-home food and drink consumption as compared to OOH food and drink consumption increased by approximately 200 basis points from 2007 to 2012 as a consequence of the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, the split remained relatively stable from 2007 to 2019, as illustrated in the following chart. (Sources: ONS, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs ("DEFRA").) 186 ----- Moreover, as shown in the following chart, the UK grocery retail market has continued to show positive YoY market growth for the past twelve years. This growth too is reflective of the relatively essential nature of grocery purchases, which represent a necessary and regular household expenditure as compared to more discretionary spending categories, such as clothing, footwear and electronics. (Source: Euromonitor: Retailing 2020 Edition. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to the sum of channels including hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, and food and drink e-commerce.) While the overall UK grocery retail market has in recent years remained stable in many respects, market channels and customer habits have been changing. Customer preference has shifted away from larger, out-of-town formats towards smaller, proximity formats, with customers prioritising convenience and shopping habits shifting towards smaller basket sizes coupled with increased frequency of purchases. The industry has also seen the rapid growth of discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) that compete through differentiation on price coupled with a more limited selection of own-brand products. In addition to these changes within the physical store channels, the UK grocery retail market has also seen an increasing shift away from physical stores towards online purchasing. More recently, according to Kantar, COVID-19 has accelerated the shifts towards these online and convenience formats since lockdown measures were first introduced in the United Kingdom earlier this year, as shown in the chart below. Underlying all of these trends is a shift towards at-home food and drink consumption away from OOH food and drink consumption, which has led to an 12.3% YoY increase in the value of the overall UK grocery retail market on a Total Grocery Absolute Sales basis for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020. For more information, see "— _UK Grocery Retail Key Trends."_ (Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.) 187 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape
Subsubsection Text: The following chart sets forth the UK online grocery market share of the top six UK grocery retailers on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020 as compared to the 52-week periods through December 31 for the years 2017 to 2019, according to Kantar. (Source: Kantar as of December 27, 2020.) The largest players in the UK online grocery retail market are Tesco, ASDA, Sainsbury's, Morrison's Waitrose and Ocado (which operates a 50/50 joint venture between Ocado Group and M&S). According to Kantar, we had a 19.8% market share in the UK online grocery market measured on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the YTD as of December 27, 2020, while Tesco, Sainsbury's and Ocado had a market share of 35.8%, 19.5% and 14.3%, respectively.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape
Subsubsection Text: The UK grocery retail market experienced industry-wide price deflation from 2014 to 2016, with deflation at -0.2% in 2014, -2.6% in 2015 and -2.4% in 2016, respectively, according to the OECD (measured by the CPI). Low or no inflation or deflation, along with weakening customer demand and lower real wage growth, contributed to discounters gaining a stronger foothold in the UK grocery retail market as they competed through low prices and store openings to attract more price-conscious customers. These combined factors resulted in downward pressure on our LFL sales growth from 2014 to 2016, as set forth in the following two charts. (Source: Company information with respect to ASDA, OECD 2020 Inflation (CPI) indicator.) 190 ----- (Source: Euromonitor: Retailing 2020 edition (with the exception of the 2019 numbers, which are taken from competitor public disclosure).) However, as food inflation in the United Kingdom has increased in more recent years, our LFL performance has improved.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape
Subsubsection Text: The following chart illustrates the UK grocery market breakdown by channel on a Retail Value RSP basis and its development between 2007 and 2019, as well as the CAGRs between the years 2007 and 2014, 2014 and 2019, and 2007 and 2019. (Source: Euromonitor Retailing 2020 Edition. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to the sum of channels including hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, and food and drink e-commerce.) Grocery retail sales in the United Kingdom are made via multiple channels, including hypermarkets, supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retailers and online. We currently operate in the hypermarket, supermarket and online channels. Hypermarkets are larger-format retail stores, frequently located on out-of-town sites or as anchor stores in a shopping centres, with a primary focus on selling food, beverages, tobacco and other groceries while offering a wide variety of non-grocery products, such as general merchandise and clothing. Supermarkets are smaller-scale retail stores that offer a wide variety of food, beverages and household products. Hypermarket formats are offered by the traditional grocers, while supermarket stores are offered by the Co-op, Waitrose and M&S, in addition to the traditional grocers. Based on Euromonitor data, the sum of hypermarket and supermarket channels constitute the largest share by Retail Value RSP of the UK grocery retail market, representing 61.1% of grocery Retail Value RSP in 2019. However, in the last five calendar years, growth for the sum of these two channels has declined, with a combined CAGR of -0.4% between 2014 and 2019, according to Euromonitor. In contrast, over the past fifteen years convenience stores such as Tesco Express, Sainsbury's Local, Co-op On the Go, Little Waitrose and M&S Simply Food, have gained popularity. In 2019, they represented 19.0% of Retail Value RSP and are the second-largest channel in the grocery retail market, according to Euromonitor. The 2007-2009 global financial crisis and the resulting weakened customer sentiment thereafter helped discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) to gain a strong foothold in the UK grocery retail market. Between 2007 and 2014, discounters gained considerable scale and market share due to new store openings and increased footfall resulting primarily from product offerings targeted at increasingly priceconscious customers. According to Euromonitor, the discounters channel represented 11.4% of the total grocery retail market on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2019. For more information see "— UK Grocery Retail _Key Trends."_ The UK grocery retail market has seen an increasing shift away from physical stores to online purchasing, with online grocery sales having grown significantly faster than those of physical stores in recent years. According to Euromonitor, in 2019 the online channel (food & drink e-commerce) comprised 5.1% of the UK grocery retail market. The online channel, which has also reported strong Retail Value RSP 188 ----- growth historically, with a 11.0% CAGR between 2007 and 2019, is driven by shoppers' growing appetite for convenience and digital connectivity, as well as by service enhancements in online operations. Following the recent outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, this growth has been bolstered as customers increasingly turn to online groceries in order to maintain social distance, a trend which may result in a sustained change in preferences going forward. On the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, we are the third-largest player in the UK grocery retail market with a 12.2% market share, according to Kantar. Other key players are Tesco (with a 24.0% market share), Sainsbury's (with a 13.4% market share) and Morrisons (with a 9.3% market share), in each case on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar. Together, the traditional grocers comprise 58.8% of the total market on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar. Other grocery retailers include Aldi, Co-op, Lidl, Waitrose and M&S Food. Waitrose and M&S Food operate at the premium end of the market and command lower shares of the market, with 4.6% and 3.3%, respectively, while discounters hold market shares of 6.9% and 5.2%, respectively, in each case according to Kantar and on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020. The following chart sets forth the UK grocery market share of each main UK grocery retailer on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar. (Source: Kantar as of December 27, 2020; 52-week Total Grocery Absolute Sales.) 189 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Clothing and Footwear Retail Market
Subsubsection Text: The following chart below sets forth the development of the UK clothing and footwear retail market from 2007 to 2019 on a Retail Value RSP basis, including the breakdown between in-store and online sales, according to Euromonitor. (Source: Euromonitor: Retailing 2020 Edition. Note: The UK Clothing and Footwear Retail Market is referring to the sum of Apparel and Footwear Specialist Retailers and Apparel and Footwear E-Commerce.) In addition to the grocery retail market, we operate in the UK clothing and footwear retail market, which includes the sale of all types of clothing, footwear and accessories, through the George Clothing brand. According to Euromonitor, the UK clothing and footwear retail market was valued at £42.3 billion on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2019. During the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, the UK clothing and footwear retail market declined as a result of rising unemployment, pressure on discretionary spending and weakened customer confidence. Furthermore, the market experienced a period of price inflation between 2010 and 2012. Over the past five years, the UK clothing and footwear retail market has grown at a CAGR of 2.8%, with much of the growth driven by online channels, which had a CAGR of 12.1% between 2014 and 2019 in comparison to a CAGR of only 0.1% for in-store channels, each on a Retail Value RSP basis, as stated by Euromonitor. These results reflect an overall trend toward increased access to, and usage of, the internet coupled with a greater propensity to buy online and growing usage of social media to influence and facilitate clothing and footwear retail sales. The UK clothing and footwear retail market experienced a significant downturn in the first half of 2020 due to COVID-19 related lockdowns and reduced consumer demand for non-essential purchases which included clothing and footwear. During the first of such lockdowns which lasted from March 23, 2020 to July 4, 2020, all non-essential retail stores including all clothing and footwear stores were ordered to close by the UK government. Subsequently, the value of retail sales of clothing and footwear at current prices (seasonally adjusted) decreased by 12.6% in the first quarter of 2020 and 54% in the second quarter of 2020 respectively as compared to the same period a year earlier, according to ONS. The third quarter of 191 ----- 2020 saw a gradual recovery with an 17.8% decrease in the value of retail sales of clothing and footwear at current prices (seasonally adjusted) compared to the same period a year earlier, according to ONS. As a result of COVID-19 related lockdowns, the UK clothing and footwear retail market also experienced a significant shift from in-store purchasing to online channels. However, in-store sales began to recover in the third quarter of 2020 as lockdowns were eased. For a further discussion of ASDA's position in the clothing market, specifically relating to the George Clothing brand, see "Business—Our Brands" and "Key _Strengths—The George Clothing and George Home offers are profitable and well-established."_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Homeware Retail Market
Subsubsection Text: The following chart sets forth the development of the UK homeware retail market from 2007 to 2019 on a Retail Value RSP basis, including the breakdown between in-store and online sales. (Source: Euromonitor: Retailing 2020 Edition. Note: The UK Homeware Retail Market is referring to the sum of Homewares and Home Furnishing Stores and Homewares and Home Furnishing E-Commerce.) We also operate in the UK homeware retail market, which includes the sale of all types of home furniture and furnishings, homewares, floor coverings and soft furnishings through the George Home brand. According to Euromonitor, the UK homeware retail market was valued at £12.8 billion on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2019. Between 2007 and 2019, the UK homeware retail market experienced growth at a 0.3% CAGR on a Retail Value RSP basis as stated by Euromonitor. In the past five years, the UK homeware retail market has grown at a CAGR of 2.9%, with growth mainly driven by the online channel, which had a CAGR of 9.5% between 2014 and 2019, each on a Retail Value RSP basis, as stated by Euromonitor. While online sales continue to grow, traditional in-store formats remain important in the UK homeware and home furnishing retail market as customers combine online research and purchasing with in-store visits as part of their buying process. Between 2014 and 2019, the in-store segment experienced marginal growth with Retail Value RSP of 1.1% over that period, according to Euromonitor. Similar to the UK clothing and footwear market, the UK homeware market also experienced a significant downturn in the first half of 2020 due to COVID-19 related lockdowns and reduced consumer demand for non-essential purchases. During the initial COVID-19 lockdown which lasted from March 23, 2020 to July 4, 2020, all non-essential retail stores including all homeware stores were ordered to close by the UK government. Subsequently, according to ONS, the value of retail sales of homeware at current prices (seasonally adjusted) decreased by 11.3% in the first quarter of 2020 and 50.1% in the second quarter of 2020 respectively as compared to the same periods a year earlier. According to ONS, the UK homeware market gradually rebounded in the third quarter of 2020 with a 5.3% increase in the value of retail sales of homeware at current prices (seasonally adjusted) compared to the same period a year earlier as lockdown restrictions eased. The increased time spent by consumers at home due to the COVID-19 outbreak in the United Kingdom has led to higher demand for home office equipment and home improvement activities, resulting in the gradual homeware market rebound in the third quarter of 2020. For a further discussion of ASDA's position in the homeware market, specifically relating to the George Home brand, see "Business— _Our Brands" and "Key Strengths—The George Clothing and George Home offers are profitable and well- established."_ 192 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Key Trends
Subsubsection Title: Increased focus on Value-Based Propositions and Growth of the Discounters
Subsubsection Text: Since the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, customers have become increasingly price sensitive. Such customers, however, still desire high-quality offerings. In response, discounters developed a range of valuebased propositions focused on delivering high quality at low prices, which appeal to this growing number of UK shoppers who seek a good 'value'. These propositions have helped discounters to achieve a strong presence in the UK grocery retail market. For example, discounters Aldi and Lidl have increased their combined market share (on a Total Grocery Absolute Sales basis) from 3.7% in the calendar year 2007 to 12.1% in the calendar year 2019, according to Kantar and as reflected in the following chart. (Source: Kantar.) From 2013 to 2019, discounters gained considerable scale and market share as a result of new store openings and continued price consciousness from customers. According to Euromonitor and relevant public reporting, discounters' store count grew from approximately 1,118 in 2013 to approximately 1,664 in 2019, as set forth in the following chart. (Source: Euromonitor: Retailing 2020 edition (with the exception of the 2019 numbers, which are taken from competitor public disclosure).) As discounters have increased their store counts, they have won market share from other market players. 193 ----- According to Kantar, as of December 27, 2020, we had significant market share in the same geographic areas where discounters already commanded a relatively high market share - the North of England, Scotland and Wales - on a Total Grocery Absolute Sales basis. We believe that, as discounters seek to increase their market share through expansion in new areas, they are likely to consider expanding into new regional markets - particularly in London, South of England and East of England - where we have a lower market share, a trend that we believe is supported by the information about market share by geography set forth in the following chart. We also believe the majority of ASDA's stores have discounters in their catchment area. (Source: Kantar as of December 27, 2020.)

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Key Trends
Subsubsection Text: ASDA, along with Tesco, Sainsbury's, Morrisons and Waitrose, offer groceries and non-food items for purchase and delivery online alongside "Click & Collect" services for purchases made through our websites. Pure online players, such as Ocado and Amazon Fresh, also compete in the UK online grocery market. The strong growth of online grocery sales in the United Kingdom is supported by multiple drivers, including: - Increasing population of tech-aware customers with a higher propensity to buy online; - Higher internet penetration (driven by increased usage of mobile and faster connections) combined with an increasing propensity to use the internet to buy online; - Technological advances significantly improving the online proposition for customers (such as better interfaces, mobile apps, convenient digital wallets and payment systems); 194 ----- - Improving product offerings as technology improves and competition increases (for example, greater availability of products online compared to in-store); and - Improving delivery options as density of deliveries improves (resulting in cheaper, faster deliveries and improved availability of more predictable, flexible and diverse delivery timeslots). Growth in online grocery has been accelerated by the onset of COVID-19 as customers have increasingly prioritised factors such as social distancing and convenience and government restrictions have encouraged customers to find ways to remain at home.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Key Trends
Subsubsection Text: Another significant customer trend shaping the UK grocery retail market is customers' increasing prioritisation of convenience. As part of that, there is an increasing preference amongst customers for more frequent but smaller shopping trips, with numerous top-ups through the course of the week at smaller, more conveniently located stores. This trend can be partly explained by a preference for reduced food waste in light of growing environmental concerns, smaller households, less pre-planned lifestyles and a growing preference in general for convenience. This trend has also been compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic as shoppers increasingly seek conveniently located stores in order to avoid longer travel for health and safety reasons and comply with government restrictions put in place since the outbreak of the pandemic.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Key Trends
Subsubsection Text: Increasing digitalisation and evolving customer dynamics have shaped an increasingly fast-paced market. Customers are now seeking a transparent and frictionless experience to improve and expedite their grocery retail experience. This is reflected in the increased usage of self-checkout, "Scan & Go," "Click & Collect" and online services as customers opt to use these facilities to tailor and improve their shopping experiences. In line with the growing desire for convenience and efficient shopping experiences, there is increasing demand for combined and differentiated service offerings in the grocery retail market, which allow customers to fulfil multiple needs in one convenient location such as parcel collection and drop-off, pharmacy services and selections of household items, all in addition to traditional grocery retail offerings. Grocery retailers, like ourselves, have responded with increased service offerings such as "toyou," which takes advantage of customers' growing online shopping habits to create a service that allows customers to return or collect online purchases while on a regular trip to a brick-and-mortar grocery retailer.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Key Trends
Subsubsection Text: Dedication to social responsibility is increasingly relevant to customers, particularly for Gen Z and Millennial customers, and a commitment to social responsibility has become a necessary factor if retailers want to meet customers' expectations. There is a growing share of customers who have concerns about animal welfare, environmental sustainability and ethical sourcing, and who view their purchasing decision as a lifestyle statement. In line with these concerns, customers are increasingly demanding traceability and information about production methods, driving the popularity of fair trade and organic products that can meet these needs. In response, retailers are adapting their business models in order to meet customers' demand. 195 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Key Trends
Subsubsection Text: The UK grocery retail market has been undergoing a fundamental shift in recent years, driven by changing customer lifestyles, technological changes, evolving competitive dynamics and socio-economic factors. These trends have led to a shift towards discounters, convenience stores and online channels, amongst other changes. We believe there are five key trends that may shape the future of the UK grocery retail market: the increased focus on value-based propositions and the growth of the discounters, the growth of the online channel, the shift to convenience, the redefinition of service expectations and the increased demands for social responsibility.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: _This Offering Memorandum contains statistical data, estimates and forecasts that are based on independent industry publications, such as those published by Euromonitor International Limited ("Euromonitor"): Retailing 2020 Edition, Kantar Worldpanel ("Kantar") and the Office for National Statistics ("ONS"), or other publicly available information, as well as other information based on our internal sources. Information in this Offering Memorandum on the retail market from independent market research carried out by Euromonitor or Kantar should not be relied upon in making, or refraining from making, any investment decision. With respect to Kantar data presented in this Offering Memorandum, references to the "United Kingdom" do not include Northern Ireland. This information involves many assumptions and limitations, and you are cautioned not to give undue weight to these estimates or place undue reliance on this information. This information has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but some information may be derived from estimates or subjective judgments or may not have been subject to audit or validation. We have not independently verified the accuracy or completeness of the data contained in these industry publications nor other publicly available information and we cannot provide any assurances as to their accuracy. In addition, we believe that data regarding the industry, industry market and sales positions, shares, market sizes and growth provide general guidance but are inherently imprecise. None of the industry publications referred to in this Offering Memorandum were prepared on our behalf nor on behalf of our affiliates nor at our expense. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding any third-party information presented in this Offering Memorandum, the figures are based in part on official statistics, trade associations, trade press, company research, trade interviews and trade services, and as such have not been independently verified by us in each case. The industry in which we operate is subject to a high degree of uncertainty and risk due to a variety of factors, including those described in the section titled "Risk Factors," that could cause results to differ materially from those expressed in these publications and other publicly available information, including "Forward-Looking Statements" which are not guarantees of future performance._ _This Offering Memorandum also contains illustrations and charts derived from our internal information, which has not been independently verified unless specifically indicated._

Section Title: BUSINESS OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We operate a significant store estate of 614 stores (excluding standalone PFSs) that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). The graph below compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers. (Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020. *Ocado Market share shown.) We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. See also "Industry." One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to "Every Day Low Price" and our wholly-owned supplier, IPL, which enables us to take a vertically-integrated approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers and our team of flexible and engaged colleagues. Historically, we have benefited from the support of Walmart, our former parent company. We will continue to receive support from Walmart over the next three years pursuant to the Transitional Agreements negotiated in connection with the Acquisition. For more information about the ongoing support to be provided by Walmart, please see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions— _Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_ We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended December 31, 2019, our revenue was approximately £22.9 billion (including petrol), of which approximately £2 billion was online sales, and our Adjusted EBITDA was approximately £1.2 billion (including petrol). 196 ----- The chart below presents the breakdown of our 2019 revenue by product category (food, general merchandise, clothing and petrol), food category (ambient and fresh and produce) and channel (stores and online (including George.com)). (Source: ASDA information. Year ended December 31, 2019. Note: Does not include £61 million of other revenue.) Our differentiated operating model has resulted in strong financial performance: our successful financial profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. In 2018 and 2019, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 5.5% (including petrol), our cumulative free cash flow was approximately £1.7 billion and our average cash conversion was approximately 70%. The charts below show our EBITDA Margins, Adjusted EBITDA Margins, Unadjusted Cash Conversion ("Unadjusted Cash Conversion" is calculated as Unadjusted Free Cash Flow divided by EBITDA) and Unadjusted Free Cash Flow ("Unadjusted Free Cash Flow" is calculated as EBITDA less capital expenditure) for the years ended December 31, 2015 to December 31, 2019 and our cash conversion and free cash flow for the years ended December 31, 2018 to December 31, 2019. (Source: ASDA information.) 197 ----- (Source: ASDA information.)
