We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our significant freehold real estate asset portfolio. See "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing." We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we maintain a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. Within the UK value market, we have strong market shares across ambient products (13.0%), fresh/chilled (11.6%) and total grocery (12.2%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). Our offer is strong across the full food basket: our category market shares range from 12% to 14% (except household and toiletries) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal ASDA data, our prices are approximately 6% to 7.5% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on a 2020 year-to-date (weeks 1-42) average, based on total goods price gap percentage). Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is supplemented by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food and non-food products to customers as a convenient "one-stop shop" experience that is supported and enhanced by our strong online offer. We believe our omni-channel offer, through which we reach customers at our brick-and-mortar stores, through our significant online offering and on our app, appeals to our customers. In 2020, there were approximately 9.8 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February 28, 2020), and approximately 723,000 weekly orders post COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended September 30, 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has increased use of and engagement with our online platforms and we currently fulfil approximately 720,000 online orders per week. Our online grocery business operates from 350 stores, we offer at-home delivery and customers are also able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 ASDA Click & Collect sites. We are also expanding our 1-hour Click & Collect offer. Our business model integrates our store-based and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders. 198 ----- Our online grocery business is profitable and has been consistently gaining market share within one of the world's most developed online grocery markets. We have consistently outperformed the UK online grocery market and increased our online market share in the last three years. According to Kantar, we currently operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, holding 18.2% of market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) as of December 2019, which grew to 19.8% as of December 27, 2020 (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales), representing a 1.5% gain and the second-strongest share gain since December 2019 amongst our key competitors. The chart below shows the evolution of our market share as compared with our key competitors for the periods presented. See also "Industry." (Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the year-to-date as of December 27, 2020 as compared to the 52-week periods through December 31 for 2017, 2018 and 2019.) Our online business is already of significant scale: the chart below shows the growth of our online sales, including a breakdown of online grocery versus George.com sales, for the periods presented. (Source: ASDA information.) According to Kantar, we are the second-largest online clothing retailer overall by volume in the United Kingdom and we held 6.0% of the total UK online clothing (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) market by volume for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020. Combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £1.9 billion in 2019 (of which £1.6 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales) to a total of £2.7 billion for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 (of which £2.4 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 26% between 2018 and September 30, 2020. Additionally, our toyou service allows customers to conveniently collect and return orders from George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 119 brands and process more than 10 million parcels per year. With our team of approximately 140,000 flexible and engaged colleagues serving approximately 15 million customers each week (based on the average of weeks 39 to 42 of 2020), we are committed to and deeply invested in the UK food supply chain. Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the entire UK population, in terms of both customer demographics and geography, with our customer base skewing slightly towards value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers who are 199 ----- attracted by our Every Day Low Price strategy and with strong market shares in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. For more information about our customer mix, see "—Our Customers," and for more information about the geographic distribution of our stores, see "—Our Real Estate Portfolio." Second, we believe we are well-positioned geographically, with a strong regional footprint across the United Kingdom. Our store footprint is strongest in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Our large and diverse store estate offers customers a variety of differentiated shopping formats. We operate 30 supercentres, 396 superstores, 155 supermarkets and 33 ASDA Living stores. For more information on our stores, see "— _Our Store Formats."_ Subject to receipt of regulatory approvals, our 18 standalone PFSs and 305 co-located PFSs (including both their underlying real estate assets and their business operations) will be sold to EG Group pursuant to the Forecourt Business Disposal. However, to the extent we are required to do so in order to obtain regulatory approval for the Acquisition, we will sell all or part of our forecourt business to third parties. In addition, we will transfer to Propco 2 (or an affiliate) the real estate relating to the Warehouse Assets, and to the extent required pursuant to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets promptly following the CMA Clearance Date. We will continue to operate the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets pursuant to the ASDA Leases which will be put in place in accordance with the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. For more information, see "The Transactions—The _Post Completion Disposals." This "Business" section, including historical statements herein, principally_ relates the ASDA's business as it will be following the completion of the Transactions. Following the completion of the Acquisition, we will continue to benefit over the next three years from support provided by Walmart, the world's largest retailer, through the Transitional Agreements. See "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart." In addition to the Transitional Agreements, we have also agreed with Walmart to set up_ separation planning working groups to ensure a smooth transition. Our ongoing relationship with Walmart is expected to bring a number of benefits, in particular: ## • Information and technology support to facilitate the change from the Walmart ecosystem; • Deep research and development expertise and capabilities; • Global sourcing, leveraging Walmart's sourcing capabilities in clothing and general merchandise; • Best practices, leveraging Walmart's expertise and experience as a leading global retailer; and • Long-term support and continued partnership with Walmart's management and leadership.

Section Title: OUR BUSINESSES
Subsection Title: Our Retail Business
Subsubsection Text: Our retail business comprises a food segment, which consists of our grocery business, and a non-food segment, which includes our well-known George Clothing and George Home brands, as well as a general merchandise and health and wellness offer. We offer over 90 product groups for sale across 22 categories (excluding petrol). We operate our retail business through both brick-and-mortar retail sites and through online sales made, primarily, via groceries.asda.com and George.com. Our physical retail business operates under four distinct formats: supercentres and superstores, supermarkets, ASDA Living and PFSs. We also recently entered the convenience market, with the launch our ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience concept. The concept is being trialled by EG Group at three of their sites and is based around a wholesale approach. Our standalone PFSs and co-located PFSs will be sold to EG Group pursuant to the Forecourt Business Disposal, or to the extent we are required to do so to obtain regulatory approval for the Acquisition, we will sell all or part of our forecourt business to third parties. For more information on our store formats, see "—Our Store Formats" and for more information on how the Transactions will impact our PFS business, see "The Transactions." We aim to develop ASDA as a platform by forming partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of relevant branded products and services while also building on our existing capabilities such as logistics and the customer-facing toyou proposition. We believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of attractive store destinations, in which more customer missions can be accomplished under one roof. See "—Business Strategies." Food In 2019, our food segment accounted for 85% (£16.6 billion) of our total sales of £19.6 billion (excluding petrol). Within our food segment, in 2019, ambient food items and non-edible items accounted for 53% (£8.8 billion), and fresh/produce accounted for 47% (£7.8 billion), of our food sales. _Ambient_ Our ambient product category includes core grocery items (such as rice, pasta, baking supplies, canned goods, condiments and cereals), impulse grocery items (such as snacks, confectionary treats, biscuits and soft drinks), beer, wine, spirits, baby and toiletry items, non-edible grocery items (such as paper products, pet care supplies, cleaning supplies and laundry-related items), newspapers, magazines and other kiosk items, pharmacy (including health products and ambient medicines) and optical products. We believe that certain of our own-brand ambient products, such as our Little Angels nappies and our Shades toilet rolls, are among the most popular products of their kind on the market. We have recently expanded the range of our plant-based and vegan food products within our overall ambient food selection. In September 2020, we rolled out new offers and dedicated space in our stores to over 70 plant-based products, in addition to our already strong Free From offer. New items offered include vegan and plant-based proteins, cooking sauces, condiments, snacks and sweets. Our goal is to provide vegan and plant-based foods at affordable prices and our intention is that these new vegan items will eventually be rolled out across approximately half of our store network. _Fresh_ Our fresh product category includes core chilled products (such as cheese, cooked meats, pies, salads and dips, eggs and dairy products), fresh proteins (such as fresh beef, fresh pork, fresh poultry, bacon, sausage and pre-packed fish), bakery (such as cakes, breads and morning goods bought and produced in store), in-store café (such as beverages, main meals, snacks and drinks), food to go (such as sandwiches, snacks, confectionary treats, salads and drinks) serve-over and self-serve counters (such as rotisserie, pizza, Greggs, Panku, Sushi Daily, Kulaba Kitchen, ASDA takeaway and various local partners), frozen (such as frozen meat, chips, vegetables, desserts, ice cream and frozen meal solutions) fresh ready meals, soups and pizzas. 209 ----- _Produce_ Our produce product category includes fruit, vegetables, salads, nuts, plants and flowers. Non-Food In 2019, our non-food segment accounted for 15% (£3.0 billion) of our total sales of £19.6 billion (excluding petrol and other), with clothing and general merchandise accounting for 8% and 7% of our total sales (excluding petrol), respectively. _Clothing_ Our clothing product category includes the George Clothing line which offers a wide variety of clothing and apparel, including for baby, children, men, women, jewellery, footwear, socks and hosiery. _General merchandise_ Our general merchandise product category includes George Home (kitchenwares, housewares, electrical appliances, furniture, lighting, bath, kids items and furnishings and bedding), seasonal and occasions products and toys (cards, celebration products, stationary, toys, hobby items and festive and Halloween products), outdoor and essential items (sporting goods, automotive, hardware, paint, access products and home and garden products) and entertainment (electronics, books and telecoms products).

Section Title: OUR BUSINESSES
Subsection Title: Our Other Services
Subsubsection Text: ASDA Pharmacy and ASDA Opticians We operate complementary pharmacy and optical businesses that offer enhanced customer experiences and diversify our cash flows. We have 254 ASDA Pharmacies offering NHS, locally commissioned and private services to our patients. These services include dispensing NHS and private prescriptions, electronic prescriptions and collection services as well as our ASDA Pharmacy flu vaccine service for NHS and private patients. Examples of NHS services we offer include our New Medicine Service in England, Pharmacy First in Scotland and our Common Ailment scheme in Wales, each of which are commissioned by the home nations. ASDA Opticians offers our customers access to optical services and products in 156 stores and has a dedicated online site selling contact lenses. In our stores, we complete eye examinations, contact lens examinations and provide additional NHS services. Our in-store spectacle pricing model does not charge extra to patients for prescription needs, including varifocals. We offer a wide contact lens portfolio of various brands, designs and modalities. We also offer safety spectacles, sunglasses, eye care products, accessories and contact lens solutions. ASDA Money We offer certain financial and insurance products on a commission-only basis. All products are provided through third-party partnerships. The products we offer include home insurance, car insurance, travel insurance, pet insurance, money transfer, breakdown cover, third-party gift cards, personal loans, credit cards and travel money. See also "Regulation—Regulation Relating to our Money and Insurance Offers." ASDA Gift Cards We offer ASDA branded gift cards for sale in our stores and on our dedicated websites, which can be used to buy goods in-store, on George.com or to purchase online groceries. Our gift card offer includes ASDA's Christmas Savings Card, an ASDA-branded card that pays a bonus to customers in November based on how much they have saved on their card up to that date. We also participate in pre-paid card schemes through our business-to-business gift card programme, through which a commission is paid to businesses to encourage end-users to shop at ASDA. Businesses who purchase ASDA gift cards can also receive a discount on bulk purchases. ASDA Mobile ASDA Mobile operates as a Mobile Network Virtual Operator, offering pay-as-you-go mobile services to customers. The ASDA Mobile network is currently powered by EE. In 2020, we entered into an exclusive five-year agreement with Vodafone to begin operating ASDA Mobile. We expect our mobile network to be transitioned to Vodafone during the first half of 2021. Existing customers using EE's services will be asked to migrate over to the new network, which will have additional features and benefits not currently available through the EE network. 210 ----- We sell our SIM cards in our stores at dedicated bays alongside mobile handsets. We also operate a dedicated website where customers can order a SIM card. See also "Regulation—Regulations Relating to _our Mobile Offer."_ Other Service Offers We also offer our customers other services, including our toyou service, which allows customers to collect and return orders from partner retailers at ASDA locations, ASDA Tyres (which sells tyres and connects customers to local tyre fitting services via a dedicated online shop), and ASDA Media Partnerships (an advertising service helping brands to reach and influence ASDA's customers through digital, social, in-store and out-of-store advertising opportunities).

Section Title: OUR BUSINESSES
Subsection Title: Our Online Platform
Subsubsection Text: We offer online grocery shopping through our online ASDA groceries platform, including delivery services for our customers' online orders, as well as our Click & Collect service. We also offer our popular George Clothing and homeware range online through George.com. ASDA groceries ASDA groceries is our online groceries business. We sell our groceries through groceries.asda.com and our mobile application. Customers place an order either for delivery or for collection from one of approximately 460 Click & Collect sites. Delivery orders are fulfilled either from our home shopping centres, which are dedicated fulfilment centres for online grocery orders, or from ASDA stores, depending on the customer's location. This in-store online model proved effective in responding to rapid increases in demand during the recent COVID-19-related lockdowns in the United Kingdom and we believe this demonstrates our ability to scale our online offering quickly to meet customer demand. Delivery to customers is primarily made by ASDA colleagues using our van fleet. For deliveries, customers book a delivery slot and can choose to either pay per delivery or to sign up for unlimited deliveries across a period of time for a fixed cost. Online innovation continues to be a priority for us, as evidenced in our strategic partnership with UberEats to enable convenience groceries to be delivered to customers quickly and our Express Collection offer, which enables customers to place an order for collection within an hour. In 2020, there were approximately 9.8 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February 28, 2020), and approximately 723,000 weekly orders post COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended September 30, 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has increased use of and engagement with our online platforms and we currently fulfil approximately 720,000 online orders per week. George.com We sell George Clothing and George Home products online through George.com. Customers place an order either for delivery or collection from one of approximately 460 Click & Collect sites. Delivery of orders is provided by third-party couriers, with orders prepared at our three fulfilment centres. George.com also delivers to customers around the world. Following the Separation, it is intended that Walmart will agree to permit us to continue to use the George brand internationally. For more information about where we will be able to use the George brand following the Separation, see "Certain ### Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart—Trade Mark Agreement." In 2019, we launched the George Rewards loyalty scheme, through which customers earn points as they shop online and can use the points to unlock discounts. 211 -----

Section Title: OUR BUSINESSES
Subsubsection Text: We are an omni-channel retailer centred around a brick-and-mortar store network, which is geographically diversified across the United Kingdom, and our websites (primarily through groceries.asda.com and George.com). Our retail business comprises a food (which in turn comprises produce, ambient products and fresh food products) and a non-food offer (which in turn comprises clothing, homeware and general merchandise offers). We also offer our customers other services, including, among other things, a mobile phone service, various financial products, parcel drop and collection and in-store pharmacies and opticians.

Section Title: OUR CUSTOMERS
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our value proposition is particularly attractive to value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers. The chart below presents the life stage and income bracket distribution of our customer base. (Source: Kantar. Based on numbers of shoppers in the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020.)

Section Title: OUR BRANDS
Subsubsection Text: We operate generally under our well-known ASDA brand, for groceries, and George brand, for clothing, footwear and homeware.

Section Title: OUR STORE FORMATS
Subsubsection Text: We believe we have a well-invested and geographically diversified store estate, 71% of which is freehold calculated as gross square footage of freehold stores as a percentage of gross square footage of total stores, as of December 20, 2020; freehold percentage also includes certain properties that are freehold with a partial leasehold or which are leasehold properties for which the leases have been classed as long leasehold for the purposes of this calculation as those leases have nil or a peppercorn ground rent. The map below presents the geographic split of our market shares by sales by region and site numbers and the accompanying chart presents the geographic split of our site network (including 614 stores and 18 standalone PFSs). (Source: ASDA information.) We have historically operated four distinct store formats. The principal formats of our retail stores include: - _Supercentres and superstores: Supercentres are our largest-format stores, which offer food and non-food products and typically include concessions (such as McDonalds and Subway), petrol as well as in-store dining and refreshment facilities. We operate 30 supercentres (approximately 5% of our total stores), 82% of which are freehold or long leasehold and which accounted for 11% of our store-based revenue (which is all revenue that is derived from stores (including grocery home shopping orders fulfilled from stores, as opposed to the home shopping centres), and excluding George.com, income from the distribution network and grocery home shopping orders fulfilled from home shopping centres) in 2019. Supercentres generally have net square footage of 65,000 to 101,000 square feet and an average sales area of approximately 83,000 square feet. Superstores are large-format stores featuring a food-led offer, as well as a non-food offer, including general merchandise, clothing, concessions and in-store dining and refreshment facilities, with petrol being offered at most of our superstores. We operate 396 superstores (approximately 65% of our total stores), 73% of which are freehold or long leasehold and which accounted for 82% of our storebased revenue in 2019. Superstores generally have net square footage of 15,000 to 75,000 square feet and an average sales area of approximately 42,000 square feet. - _Supermarkets: supermarkets are small-format stores focused on food, with a limited general merchandise and George Clothing offer. We operate 155 supermarkets (approximately 25% of our total stores), 83% of our supermarkets are freehold or long leasehold and our supermarkets accounted for 5% of our store-based revenue in 2019. Supermarkets generally have net square footage of 5,000 to 15,000 square feet and an average sales area of approximately 9,000 square feet. 214 ----- - _ASDA Living: ASDA Living stores are dedicated non-food stores that include general merchandise, George Clothing and George home offers. We operate 33 ASDA Living stores (approximately 5% of our total stores), none of which are freehold or long leasehold and which accounted for 1% of our store-based revenue in 2019. ASDA Living stores generally have net square footage of 15,000 to 39,000 square feet and an average sales area of approximately 27,000 square feet. - _Petrol filling stations (PFSs): PFSs include the current network of standalone petrol filling stations, including 42 small convenience stores with a limited range of food and non-food offers. We have historically operated 305 co-located PFSs and 18 standalone PFSs, 81% and 94% of which are freehold or long leasehold, respectively. PFSs generally have net square footage of 500 to 2,500 square feet. These standalone PFSs and co-located PFSs will be sold to EG Group pursuant to the Forecourt Business Disposal or, to the extent we are required to do so to obtain regulatory approval for the Acquisition, we will sell all or part of our forecourt business to third parties. For more information, see "The Transactions—The Post Completion Disposals."

Section Title: OUR TENANTS AND STRATEGIC PARTNERS
Subsubsection Text: We work with a number of tenants and strategic partners that operate retail locations within our stores, such as McDonalds, Gregg's, Sushi Daily, Timpson, Decathlon and Claire's, or provide other services to our customers, such as UberEats, which provide grocery home delivery, B&Q, with which we are trialling in-store and click & collect concession, and Music Magpie, with which we are trialling an offer of a range of used DVDs, as well as EG Group, who are trialling our ASDA On the Move format, which is a wholesale arrangement whereby ASDA's own brand products as well as branded products will be sold in third-partyowned smaller convenience store formats.

Section Title: OUR COLLEAGUES
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2019, we employed approximately 140,000 individuals. Typically, our total number of colleagues increases during peak retail periods, such as Easter and Christmas, due to seasonal hires. We are committed to providing colleagues the training, education and incentives they need to strengthen their skills and become part of our community. Our colleagues are subject to standard employment terms, depending on their role, and are provided with colleague handbooks (where relevant) and policies. We have union agreements in both the retail and distribution parts of our business with the GMB Union and the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers. We are committed to offering competitive compensation in line with market practices. For information related to certain ongoing legal proceedings relating to wages, please see "—Legal Proceedings—Equal _Value Litigation." We also offer variable compensation to colleagues, including those working in retail and_ distribution, to encourage performance based on the fulfilment of business targets.

Section Title: OUR SUPPLIERS AND LOGISTICS
Subsection Title: OUR QUALITY CONTROL SYSTEM,** **HEALTH AND SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL POLICIES Quality Control
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to providing customers with safe and high-quality products, including both our ownbrand products and name brand products. We have a due diligence framework in place which covers, among other things, our supplier audit framework, our governance policies, product testing and our specification management system. Our supplier audit framework measures compliance, supplier performance against food safety hazard analysis and critical control point principles. In addition, we have a quality management system that measures how our products perform in terms of quality. To control the quality of the products we sell, we execute a number of quality control initiatives. We conduct regular quality controls on the acceptance of fresh food at our depots. In addition, we analyse ownbrand product samples in our in-house sensory kitchens and through a third-party, Cambridge Market Research, to ensure that our products meet our customers' expectations. We conduct quarterly food safety audits at our stores to ensure that each store meets our required standards for food safety and hygiene. We conduct annual refresher trainings for store colleagues to ensure that they are trained in all relevant aspects of food safety, including allergen management. All new own-brand suppliers must be Global Food Safety Initiative accredited and must pass a new supplier audit before proceeding. In addition, all own-brand suppliers will have an annual unannounced ASDA bolt-on food safety audit that measures supplier adherence to ASDA policy. 217 ----- When deciding whether to work with an own-brand supplier, we monitor the quality of its products based on a control of samples delivered by the supplier during the selection phase. Following selection, we regularly evaluate the quality of the products the supplier offers, including through randomly selected samples. Our general supplier terms and conditions include a section dedicated to quality, safety, labelling and traceability. By signing these terms and conditions, our suppliers confirm that they are fully aware of, and comply with, our safety and quality standards. Furthermore, suppliers must adhere to our technical manufacturing guide and associated policies for food as well as work with our own-brand technical teams to ensure compliance with this guide and these policies.

Section Title: OUR SUPPLIERS AND LOGISTICS
Subsection Title: Health, Safety and Environmental Policies and Ethics
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to maintaining high standards of health and safety practices for our colleagues, customers, visitors, contractors and anyone affected by our business activities. We therefore consider good health, safety and environmental management as an essential part of our business performance and culture. We formally monitor health and safety incident rates. Our health and safety policies and procedures include: - managing risk and promoting a corporate culture that emphasises the benefits of health and safety; - appropriate training and education of all colleagues to support legal compliance and best practices; and - proactively conducting regular risk assessments and root cause analyses to provide and maintain safe and healthy working environments to significantly reduce occupational injuries or illnesses. We carry out a range of monitoring activities to provide assurance of the effectiveness of our policies and procedures. These activities are completed by both internal teams and external experts. We have a wide variety of health and safety and ethics policies that address topics such as Food Safety, Food Contamination, Warehouse Safety, Product Safety, Privacy, Environment and Environmental Services, Anti-Money Laundering and Licences and Permits, among others. We also have a number of policies that relate specifically to waste management issues, such as Food and Drink Waste, Confidential Waste, Optical Waste and Pharmacy Waste.

Section Title: OUR SUPPLIERS AND LOGISTICS
Subsection Title: Our Environmental, Social and Governance Goals
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to reducing our environmental impact and having a positive social impact in the communities we serve and we have a governance programme in place to support us achieving this aim. With respect to our environmental goals, we strive to reduce carbon emissions, promote sustainable farming and fishing practices, sustainably source ingredients like palm oil that make their way into our products, reduce food, product and packaging waste throughout our supply chain and deliver a greener proposition to customers at a great value. We have a demonstrated track record of giving back to local communities through our ASDA Foundation, among other dedicated community initiatives, while also striving to tackle wider social issues through fundraising efforts with long-standing partners such as Breast Cancer Now and BBC Children in Need. In line with our commitment to public health, we also aim to increase the proportion of low fat, salt and sugar content products within our own-brand offering. We manage our commitments to environmental and social impact goals with our established governance structure. We have compliance policies in place regarding privacy and ethics, grocery supply standards, anti-corruption, anti-trust, licences, consumer protection and health and safety, all of which are managed by qualified and experienced audit and legal teams. We also maintain clear work standards across our supply chain and collaborate with our stakeholders as well as across industries and organisations to improve working conditions, including through initiatives to promote the dignity of workers as well as combat modern slavery. As a result, we have been recognised for our overall compliance with the Groceries Supply Code of Practice. In addition, we have been actively engaged in passing on our best practices through our ASDA Local Supplier Development Academies, which help small suppliers develop their capabilities in logistics and sustainability.

Section Title: OUR SUPPLIERS AND LOGISTICS
Subsubsection Text: We operate a "hub and spoke" logistics network, with two hubs and two deconsolidation centres serving 33 depots throughout the United Kingdom. Our logistics model is designed to support our extensive store and online businesses. This approach starts with suppliers that provide goods to our hubs and depots as well as directly to our stores for certain products. Our hubs and depots supply our stores via our fleet. In addition to in-store purchasing, ASDA and ASDA Logistics Services also offer customers home delivery and Click & Collect services. _Hubs: Our two hubs are split by category: our Lutterworth hub handles general merchandise and_ ambient goods, while our Doncaster hub, which is operated by a third party, handles general merchandise and ambient products. _Suppliers: We had more than 4,400 active suppliers as of September 30, 2020, the top 20 of which_ (excluding IPL and petrol) reflected approximately 35% of cost of goods sold (excluding VAT, for the October 1, 2019 to September 30, 2020 period). These suppliers deliver goods either to a hub (such as for ambient and non-edible products and non-food products), direct to depots (such as for fresh food, produce and fast-moving ambient) or direct to stores (such as for bread). New suppliers undergo a number of checks and procedures managed via the shared service centre team. If a supplier is identified as a third-party intermediary, which is typically only relevant to goods not for resale suppliers presenting a bribery and corruption risk, further procedures are required as part of the on-boarding and ongoing management processes for that supplier, focused on anti-corruption. During the on-boarding of goods not for resale suppliers, we undertake a compliance risk review covering topics including, among others, modern slavery, information security and privacy. If compliance risks are identified, then we agree on and implement 215 ----- appropriate mitigation measures. Relationships with goods for resale suppliers are managed by the relevant buying team within the commercial team. Our buyers are responsible for negotiating key terms, including pricing, promotional activity, supplier income arrangements, and payment terms. For goods not for resale suppliers, the applicable business owners manage the contract terms and arrangements. We leverage supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity. _Ordering process: the purchase order process varies according to the category of goods._ ## •Goods for resale: Automatic orders are generated with suppliers based on stock levels / stock availability, historical demand trends and forecast trends. This is applicable for the majority of food orders. The supply team has manual override capabilities for automatic orders, albeit limited and rarely required. Non-food products typically operate on a longer lead time. The orders are based on forecast sales numbers provided to the supply team by the buying team and the commercial finance team. ## •Goods not for resale: Purchase orders are raised by the procurement team or the applicable colleague and reviewed by the budget holder (the individual who is responsible for the budget to which the associated cost relates) within that colleague's team. Logistics facilities: logistics facilities_ receive, process, warehouse and distribute goods for sale at our stores. IPL, Forza and Kober are treated as suppliers and largely deliver to depots. In addition, we operate home shopping centres, which are fulfilment centres for online grocery orders. _Fleet: ASDA drivers deliver goods to stores and customers using fleet vehicles (approximately 1,150_ leased tractors and approximately 2,300 leased trailers), home shopping vans (approximately 2,800 leased vans) or occasional spot-hire or use of third-party hauliers (figures as of January 6, 2021). _Stores: aside from in store purchasing, we also offer our customers home delivery and Click & Collect_ service. **IPL** We believe we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via IPL and its two subsidiary companies, Forza and Kober, which enables a vertically integrated approach to procurement. IPL is an important asset that provides valuable sourcing differentiation. In 2019, £1.5 billion was purchased through IPL, reducing our overall costs. Our 2019 product mix sourced from IPL was 60% produce, 28% protein, 8% beverages and 3% grocery. IPL employed over 4,000 colleagues as of December 31, 2019 across its group of companies, and only serves us. IPL receives products directly from producers and centralises sourcing, processing and packaging. This disintermediation of export agents, import agencies, suppliers and packers is the foundation of IPL's cost price advantage: IPL sources produce, cooked meats, wine, nuts and dried fruit, plants and flowers and has a national footprint of nine processing facilities across the United Kingdom, supported by seven overseas technical/logistical operations. IPL's overseas offices provide us with the benefit of being close to our foreign suppliers and sources, which we believe gives us greater insight and control over our supply chain, conferring on us a competitive advantage as compared to competitors that do not benefit from comparable vertically integrated procurement. 216 ----- The map below shows IPL's UK footprint. (Source: ASDA information.) IPL operates with five business units: produce (sourcing approximately whole and prepared fruit, whole vegetables, potatoes and onions, plants and flowers), protein (sourcing cooked meat and bacon), beverages (sourcing wine), grocery (sourcing snack nuts, desserts and baking, cereal and other nuts and dried fruit) and central functions (employing colleagues across IT, finance, legal and compliance and HR functions). The key countries of origin from which we source products via IPL are: the United Kingdom, Spain, the Netherlands, Denmark and other European Union countries, South Africa, Thailand, Brazil, Vietnam and Bolivia.

Section Title: OUR TECHNOLOGY AND INFORMATION SYSTEMS
Subsubsection Text: Our information systems are critical to our business operations. They provide management, analytical and performance evaluation tools that assist management at all levels to undertake business processes. Our technical infrastructure and computer applications are also used for the day-to-day management of our business, including purchasing, sourcing, distribution, online sales, data exploitation, invoicing, cash collection, reporting, consolidation and electronic data interchange. Our business depends on the ability of our colleagues to process transactions on secure information systems and our capacity to store, retrieve, 218 ----- process and manage information. Our information systems are highly integrated, covering most of our fundamental business service areas. The majority of our core systems are currently provided and managed by Walmart, and we aim to migrate off of these systems onto alternative solutions following the Separation, as part of a three-year transition process. We believe that our information systems are robust, adequate to support our activities and operate at standards that are comparable to other operators in our industry. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of _ASDA from Walmart" and "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart."_

Section Title: OUR PUBLICITY,** **MARKETING AND CUSTOMER SERVICE
Subsubsection Text: Marketing is an integral part of the promotion of our brand, stores and products. We carry out a number of branding and advertising initiatives through our stores, websites and mobile applications, as well as through print, social and broadcast advertising campaigns. We work these through owned, earned and paid channels. The key focus of our messaging to our customers is an emphasis on value, the innovative, high-quality and well-priced products we offer and brand sentiment, services and ways to shop as well as a focus on corporate social responsibility. We also have an online and paper magazine, ASDA MAG/Good Living, through which we promote our products and brand values, as well as encourage customer engagement with our brands and offers. Our ASDA Price News publication (which is available in online and paper formats) promotes our value offer and competitive deals. We receive publicity for our innovations in product range and quality across own-brands, which helped us to win 543 product awards, 200 food awards, 343 beer, wine and spirits awards and 15 retailer awards in 2019. Customer service is key to winning and retaining customers. We make customer service available in our stores, online and by telephone. We also offer our customers loyalty programmes, such as George Rewards.

Section Title: OUR INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
Subsubsection Text: We use a variety of trade names, service marks and trade marks in our business and rely on trade mark and copyright laws, confidentiality procedures and contractual provisions to protect our intellectual proprietary rights. Our key brands are, among others: ASDA, George and George Home. We believe that the brand names of each of our various banners enjoy high brand recognition and are material to our business. Our intellectual property policy is centred around the protection of our brands, associated logos and our domain names. This policy involves filings and reservations on either a local country basis or in the full range of countries where we operate or wish to preserve and protect our rights. Certain intellectual property rights related to ASDA, including trade marks, are owned solely by Walmart. In particular, intellectual property rights relating to the George Clothing brand are owned by a Walmart group company and used by both Walmart and ASDA. Following the Separation, Walmart will grant ASDA a licence to use the George brand in the United Kingdom (for sale, marketing and distribution purposes on an exclusive basis) and in certain specified countries in Europe (on a non-exclusive basis) where it is currently used as part of ASDA's business (and is expected to grant ASDA a licence to use the George brand in certain other territories outside the United Kingdom and such specified European countries (on a non-exclusive basis) in substantially the same way as and to the same extent the brand was used by ASDA immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement, as specified in, and subject to the terms of, the TMA), in each case on and subject to the terms of the TMA, while Walmart will continue to own the brand and use it in other territories. See "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional _Agreements with Walmart," "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_

Section Title: INSURANCE
Subsubsection Text: We maintain insurance coverage against the risks inherent in our various businesses. Our insurance policies are currently placed by Walmart pursuant to an umbrella policy, which covers marine and cargo, directors and officers, core property, terrorism and political, cyber, employment practices and crime risks. Following the Separation, we will replace the umbrella policy that has historically been provided by Walmart with our own insurance policies. We also carry combined liability (employee liability, public liability, products liability, medical malpractice (for our pharmacy business) and motor, marine (for our toyou offer), non-core property (material damage and property owners' liability), machinery movement and health insurance policies in addition to the umbrella policy. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There _are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_ To support our insurance programme (in particular the self-funding/deductible and aggregate provisions), letters of credit are provided to our insurers for each policy year. These are amended from time to time to reflect the existing and anticipated book value in each policy. 219 ----- We consider our policies adequate to cover the major risks of our business, and we believe that the level of insurance which we maintain is comparable, in each case, to that maintained by other companies in our primary markets operating in the same business area, but there can be no assurance that this coverage will be sufficient to cover the cost of defence or damages in the event of a significant claim. See "Risk Factors—We may incur liabilities that are not covered by insurance and could be exposed to _significant financial risks if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate."_

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Controlled Land Order
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the Groceries Market Investigation (Controlled Land) Order 2010 (the "Controlled

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Land Order") which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land
Subsubsection Text: being used by their competitors for grocery retailing in the future. The Controlled Land Order is administered by the CMA.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Groceries Supply Code of Practice and Groceries Code Adjudicator
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the Groceries Supply Code of Practice (the "GSCOP"), which is UK legislation designed to regulate the relationship between designated retailers and their grocery suppliers. GSCOP provides detail on how retailers should manage their relevant supplier relationships fairly. The Groceries Code Adjudicator (the "GCA") is the independent regulator of GSCOP.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Food Safety, Hygiene, Labelling and Nutrition and Consumer Protection
Subsubsection Text: We have a food safety team, which forms part of our compliance team, to ensure food handling procedures are monitored closely to guarantee product safety, quality standards and compliance with all applicable food safety and hygiene laws and regulations. Scheduled internal and external audits are conducted by qualified, third-party food safety experts to ensure procedural compliance and adherence with our policies. This verification programme identifies and evaluates the hazards that are significant for food safety and hygiene, taking account of the Food Safety Act 1990, the Food Information Regulations 2014 (as amended) and Food Safety and Hygiene Regulations in place across England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Regulation Relating to our Health and Wellness Offers (ASDA Pharmacy and ASDA Optical)
Subsubsection Text: With respect to our Optical offer, we are regulated by the General Optical Council ("GOC"). ASL is a registered Body Corporate with the GOC, which allows us to provide Optical services subject to the GOC Business Standards and the Opticians Act of 1989. Our professionals are registered as individual registrants with the GOC and are subject to GOC Standards for Individuals and the Opticians Act of 1989. We hold NHS mandatory contracts for all of our ASDA Opticians locations and are subject to the terms of these contracts. In some of our English ASDA Opticians locations, we also hold Enhanced Services contracts and are subject to the NHS standard contracts and local service level agreements. With respect to our pharmacies, we are regulated by the General Pharmaceutical Council ("GPHC"). Each of our individual pharmacies is registered with the GPHC. This allows us to carry out pharmaceutical activity from our registered premises subject to the Standards for Registered Pharmacies. Our pharmacists are registered with the GPHC as individual registrants and are subject to the GPHC Professional Standards. 220 -----

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Regulation Relating to our Money and Insurance Offers
Subsubsection Text: _Financial Conduct Authority-authorised Entities_ ASL has been authorised by the FCA since 2017 and currently holds a limited permission to carry on credit brokerage activities (limited to secondary broking). As a result of this authorisation, ASL is regulated and supervised by the FCA. _Appointed Representatives_ The Group includes two introducer-appointed representatives: ASL and ASDA Financial Services Limited. In addition to the FCA authorisation noted above, ASL is also payment services directive agent and introducer-appointed representative that is currently involved in credit, insurance and payments intermediation. ASDA Financial Services Limited is an introducer-appointed representative which is currently involved in credit and insurance intermediation. In respect of these roles, ASL and ASDA Financial Service Limited are not directly authorised by the FCA but may instead perform certain regulated activities and act as agent for firms that are directly authorised by the FCA.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Regulations Relating to our Mobile Offer
Subsubsection Text: _OFCOM Regulations_ ASDA is selling mobile communication services to consumers under the ASDA Mobile brand using EE's network pursuant to a mobile virtual operator agreement with EE. See also "Our Businesses—Our Other _Services—ASDA Mobile." The sale and supply of mobile communication services are regulated primarily_ by the Office of Communications ("OFCOM"), an independent regulator and competition authority for the UK communications industries, within the framework set by the various European directives, the UK Communications Act 2003 and other UK and European Union regulations and recommendations. ASDA does not require a licence to operate the mobile communication services, however, it must comply with the provisions of OFCOM's General Conditions of Entitlement that apply to such services.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Regulations Relating to Electricity Purchasing
Subsubsection Text: We currently purchase our electricity on a wholesale basis via a dedicated subsidiary, which sells electricity back to the rest of the ASDA Group companies. These electricity purchases are regulated by the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets ("OFGEM"), which is the government regulator for gas and electricity markets in Great Britain. In addition to OFGEM, we are also regulated by Elexon, which is the administrator of the Balancing and Settlement Code. Therefore, the subsidiary which procures our power is subject to the Performance Assurance Reporting and Monitoring System (PARMS) reporting regime which must be submitted to Elexon on a monthly basis. We are also required to submit certain returns to various government departments pursuant to legislation including the Climate Change Levy Return submitted to HMRC, the Monthly Sales Report submitted to the Department of Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy and the Demand Forecast Submission to the National Grid. In 2021, following the Separation, we aim to transition from our existing wholesale purchasing model for electricity, which is currently arranged through Walmart, to purchasing electricity on a retail basis. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of _ASDA from Walmart."_

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Data Privacy Regulations
Subsubsection Text: Through our in-store and online business, as well as certain of our other services (such as our money and pharmacy offers), we have access to and may process personal data relating to our customers and colleagues or any other individual in connection with the provision of our services (the "Relevant Data"). As such, we are subject to applicable laws and binding regulations on data protection and data privacy, including the General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 ("GDPR") (such laws and binding regulations together with the GDPR, "Applicable Privacy Laws"), which will form part of domestic law of the United Kingdom by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal Act) 2018 following the end of the Brexit transition period. We will continue to review and develop existing processes to ensure that we comply with Applicable Privacy Laws in relation to our processing of any Relevant Data. 221 -----

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsection Title: Miscellaneous Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the foregoing regulations, in the ordinary course of our business, our operations and properties are subject to international, national, regional and local laws and regulations of general applicability, such as labour laws, laws on advertising, regulations governing our relations with our suppliers and distributors, environmental, health and safety regulations, among others. We operate a vehicle fleet that is subject to an Operator's Licence issued by the relevant local Traffic Commissioner, the conditions of which are enforced through the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency. We are also subject to road transport legislation and regulations that determine, among other issues, the maximum weight that large goods vehicles and light vans can carry, and the maximum number of hours a driver can work or drive over defined periods. See also "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and _Regulatory Matters."_

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a wide variety of laws, regulations and industry standards administered by local, national and other government entities. The following provides a brief description of the main laws and regulations that govern our activities. References and discussions to directives, laws, regulations and other administrative and regulatory documents are entirely qualified by the full text of such directives, laws, regulations and other administrative and regulatory documents themselves. We are in regular contact and dialogue with relevant regulators and have subject matter experts across the business who monitor and manage compliance with the regulatory frameworks within which we operate.

Section Title: LEGAL PROCEEDINGS
Subsection Title: Equal Value Litigation
Subsubsection Text: ASL is a defendant in over 40,000 equal value claims (the "Equal Value Claims") that began in 2008 and are proceeding before an Employment Tribunal in Manchester (the "Employment Tribunal") in the United Kingdom on behalf of current and former ASDA store colleagues, and further claims may be asserted in the future. The claimants allege that the work performed by colleagues in ASDA's retail stores is of equal value in terms of, among other things, the demands of their jobs compared to that of colleagues working in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities, that the difference in pay between these job positions disparately impacts women because more women work in retail stores while more men work in warehouses and distribution facilities, and that the pay difference is not objectively justified. The claimants are requesting differential back pay based on higher wage rates in the warehouse and distribution facilities and higher wage rates on a prospective basis. In October 2016, following a preliminary hearing, the Employment Tribunal ruled that claimants could compare their positions in ASDA's retail stores with those of colleagues in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities. ASDA appealed the ruling and the oral argument was held before the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom in July 2020. We are awaiting a decision. Notwithstanding the appeal, claimants are proceeding in the next phase of their claims. That phase will determine whether the work performed by the claimants is of equal value to the work performed by colleagues in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities. At present, we cannot predict the number of such claims that may be filed, and cannot reasonably estimate any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings. Accordingly, we can provide no assurance as to the scope and outcomes of these matters and any losses that may arise from these proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows. We believe we have substantial factual and legal defences to these claims, and intend to defend the claims vigorously. Under a separate indemnity undertaking, the Seller has agreed to indemnify the Purchaser in respect of certain costs and losses incurred by the ASDA Group from Equal Value Claims filed with employment tribunals, up to an agreed cap. As a result of these indemnity arrangements, even if the ASDA Group is ultimately unsuccessful in defending any of the Equal Value Claims, we do not believe that such an outcome would materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and/or results of operations nor our ability to meet our debt service obligations, including on the Notes, or other financial obligations as they become due. As of September 30, 2020, the Company had no material off balance sheet arrangements or funding arrangements that would be classified as a contingent liability under IFRS, except for a contingent liability relating to the ongoing Equal Value Claims. With respect to these claims, the Company has not recognised a provision on the basis that any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings cannot be reasonably estimated and any potential liability is only a possible obligation, as it has yet to be confirmed whether the entity has a present obligation that could lead to an outflow of resources embodying economic 222 ----- benefits. See note 13 ("Contingent liabilities") of the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements for further information on contingent liabilities. See "Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal _Value Litigation" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters—From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability."_ 223 -----

The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is resident in the United Kingdom for tax purposes. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer. The current directors of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer are Zuber Vali Issa CBE (appointed on September 3, 2020), Gary Lindsay (appointed on September 4, 2020), Mohsin Issa CBE (appointed on January 15, 2021) and Manjit Dale (appointed on January 15, 2021) and their business address is Waterside Head Office, Haslingden Road, Guide, Blackburn, Lancashire BB1 2FA, United Kingdom. Gary Lindsay and Manjit Dale are partners of TDR Capital LLP. The Group is not aware of any other conflicts of interest between any duties or private interests of its directors and those duties they owe to us and no sums have been paid or have been agreed to be paid to any director to induce them to become or qualify them as a director, or otherwise for services rendered by the director in connection with this offer. Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Information About Our Principal Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE have been active in the forecourt and convenience retail sector since the acquisition of a single petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001. Following a merger of their UK-based Euro Garages business with TDR Capital LLP's EFR Group in 2016, EG Group was established, which the Issa Brothers now lead as co-CEOs. The business, globally headquartered in Blackburn, United Kingdom, has an established pedigree of delivering a world class fuel, grocery & merchandise and foodservice offer and currently employs in excess of 44,000 people working in more than 6,000 sites across Europe, USA and Australia. The Issa Brothers were honoured as Commanders of the Order of the British Empire by HM The Queen in her Birthday Honours List 2020 for their contribution to business and charity. They were also jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United Kingdom. TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing over €10.0 billion of committed capital across three European buyout funds. Founded in 2002 by Manjit Dale and Stephen Robertson, TDR Capital LLP has been creating value by applying a high-impact approach to investing in a focused portfolio of companies. TDR Capital LLP has a proven value-based and operationally focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of investment and operating professionals from its single office in London. TDR's strong returns have been driven by combining ambitious operational plans for portfolio companies with a rigorous focus on capital preservation. TDR Capital LLP takes an active role in overseeing the transformation and growth of its investments, working in partnership with management through board representation and professional support. To date, TDR has completed 22 investments across the leisure, consumer, business and financial services sectors. Walmart Inc. helps people around the world save money and live better – anytime and anywhere – by providing the opportunity to shop in retail stores and through eCommerce. Each week, Walmart serves over 265 million customers who visit approximately 11,400 stores and numerous eCommerce websites under 55 banners in 26 countries. Walmart is engaged in global operations of retail, wholesale and other units, as well as eCommerce, located throughout the U.S., Africa, Canada, Central America, Chile, China, India, Japan, Mexico and the United Kingdom.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco Shareholders' Agreement
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the completion of the Transactions, Able Holdings Limited (a company owned by Zuber Vali Issa CBE and Mohsin Issa CBE), Optima Group S.à r.l., Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco will enter into a shareholders' agreement (the "Shareholders' Agreement"), which will govern various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco in relation to their direct shareholding in Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco and indirect shareholding in the Group. Pursuant to the Shareholders' Agreement, Able Holdings Limited (the "Individual Investors

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Shareholder"), on the one hand, and Optima Group S.à r.l. (the "TDR Shareholder"), on the other hand,
Subsubsection Text: will be entitled to appoint or remove directors in certain circumstances. The Individual Investors Shareholder and the TDR Shareholder will each be entitled to appoint and remove (i) two members of the board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco so long as such shareholder, together with its affiliates, hold 35% or more of the share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco (as applicable), or (ii) one member of the board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco so long as such shareholders, together with its affiliates, hold between 15% and 35% of the share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco (as applicable). The maximum number of directors for the board of Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco (as applicable) will be five and, subject to certain actions which required the consent of the Individual Investors Shareholder and the TDR Shareholder, as summarised below, all decisions of the board of directors may be made by a majority of the votes cast. 228 ----- The Shareholders' Agreement will provide that certain actions in relation to the Group may not be taken without the consent of either of the Individual Investors Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed by it) and the TDR Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed by it). These include amendments to the organisational documents of any member of the Group, variations to the rights attaching to the shares in any member of the Group, the declaration or payment of any dividend or distribution by any Group company (other than to Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco or another Group company which is wholly-owned by Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco), a material change in the nature or scope of the Group's business and the winding-up or dissolution of Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco, any of their subsidiaries or any other Group company. The Shareholders' Agreement will contain certain restrictions on the transfer by the Individual Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder of its shares in Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco or any other member of the Group, including (other than transfers to certain permitted transferees, including affiliates) an obligation to first offer any shares to the other shareholder before offering them for sale to a third party. At any time on or after the third anniversary of the Acquisition Completion Date either the Individual Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder may propose an exit event involving the Bellis Group and the Group, including the sale of shares in Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco; the sale by Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco or any other member of the Group of all or substantially all of its business, assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco or any other Group company; the reorganisation of Bellis TopCo Limited or any other Group company and the winding up of Bellis TopCo Limited in each case, on specified terms and subject to the occurrence of certain conditions (an "Exit"). The recipient of such proposal regarding an Exit shall consider such proposal in good faith, but shall not be obliged to accept such proposal. At any time on or following the fifth anniversary of the Acquisition Completion Date either the Individual Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder may propose an Exit involving the Bellis Group and the Group. The recipient of such proposal shall be required to accept such proposal provided that certain conditions are satisfied.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Walmart Senior Shares and Special Participation Share
Subsubsection Text: On the Acquisition Completion Date, Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, Bellis TopCo Limited and Global Pinnacle Corporation (among others) expect to enter into a shareholders' agreement (the "Topco 2 Shareholders'

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Agreement"), which will govern various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited in relation to
Subsubsection Text: their direct shareholding in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited and indirect shareholding in the Group. The terms of the Topco 2 Shareholders' Agreement will provide for Global Pinnacle Corporation to hold two classes of shares: (i) the Senior Shares; and (ii) the Special Participation Share. Unless otherwise agreed between the shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (or where such transfer is made to a permitted transferee in accordance with the terms of the Topco 2 Shareholders' Agreement or with the consent of the shareholders), neither the Special Participation Share nor any of the Senior Shares may be transferred to any person unless there is a simultaneous transfer of all of the Senior Shares and the Special Participation Share to the same transferee. Pursuant to the Topco 2 Shareholders' Agreement, Global Pinnacle Corporation, as holder of the Senior Shares, will be entitled to appoint or remove one director to or from the board of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (the "Senior Shareholder Director"). The holder of the Senior Shares will have no voting rights as shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, other than in relation to certain matters that would materially adversely affect the rights of the holder of the Senior Shares. The holders of the Senior Shares will have the right to receive an annual fixed cumulative senior dividend. Such dividend is payable on the principal amount of the Senior Shares plus accrued but unpaid dividends. Bellis TopCo 2 Limited may elect to pay such dividend in cash or for such dividend to accrue unpaid. The Senior Shares will be mandatorily redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited upon the occurrence of certain events, including upon an exit event involving Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. Such exit events include: the sale of the ordinary shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited; the sale by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited or any other member of the Group of all or substantially all of its business, assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited or any other Group company; or a change of control of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Senior Shares will further be mandatorily redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited on the seventh anniversary of the issuance of the Senior Shares. Bellis TopCo 2 Limited may voluntarily redeem the Senior Shares at any time subject to paying a make-whole amount. 229 ----- Pursuant to the Topco 2 Shareholders' Agreement, Global Pinnacle Corporation, in its capacity as holder of the Special Participation Share, will have no right to appoint or remove directors to the board of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, but will have the right to appoint a board observer if no Senior Shareholder Director has been appointed. The holder of the Special Participation Share will have no voting rights as a shareholder of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, other than in relation to matters that would materially adversely affect the rights of the holder of the Special Participation Share. The holder of the Special Participation Share will have the right to participate in 10% of any dividends paid by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited to the ordinary shareholders and any exit proceeds payable to the ordinary shareholders. On the occurrence of a public offering in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, the holder of the Special Participation Share will have the right to redeem the Special Participation Share at a price equal to 10% of the listing value of the fully diluted issued share capital of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited following the completion of such public offering, subject to a minimum hurdle amount. 230 -----
