Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Transitional Agreements with Walmart
Subsubsection Text: On or around the Acquisition Completion Date, ASL and Walmart expect to enter into an ancillary services agreement (the "ASA"), a trade mark agreement (the "TMA"), a transitional services agreement (the "TSA"), ASL and Walmart (or, if agreed between the parties prior to the Acquisition Completion Date, a Walmart affiliate) expect to enter into a global sourcing agreement (the "GSA"), the Company and Walmart expect to enter into a deed of termination and release (the "Termination Deed") and the Seller, the Purchaser and Walmart (among others) expect to enter into a transitional pensions deed (the "TPD"). In addition, a Transitional Electricity Supply Agreement (the "TESA") is expected to be entered into between a subsidiary of Walmart (Texas Retail Energy LLC ("TRE")) and an ASDA entity called Power 4 All, on or around the Acquisition Completion Date. The ASA, the TMA, the TSA, the Termination Deed, the GSA, the TPD, and the TESA are referred to collectively in this Offering Memorandum as the "Transitional

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Agreements."
Subsubsection Text: Under the ASA, Walmart will agree to share (at quarterly meetings with ASL, or more frequently if requested by ASL, acting reasonably) information on information technology developments, research, know-how and innovation (collectively, "Innovation") that may be relevant to ASL's business in the United Kingdom and which Walmart is using or intends to use within the Walmart Group from time to time. Walmart will grant ASL a limited, non-exclusive licence of Walmart's intellectual property rights in respect of any Innovation disclosed to ASL to enable ASL to evaluate such Innovation for use by ASL in the United Kingdom. If ASL wishes to implement any Innovation, the parties will enter into good faith discussions on the terms of that implementation (including the relevant charging model) which will be documented in a separate written licence or agreement between the parties. Although Walmart's obligation to share Innovation-related information will be effective from the Acquisition Completion Date, Walmart will not be required to assist ASL with the implementation of any Innovation unless the parties agree otherwise and reach a separate agreement. The ASA will include customary warranties on the corporate existence and capacity of the parties. No fee will be payable by ASL for the information-sharing services set out in the ASA. Walmart's liability to ASL will be excluded in respect of the provision or receipt of the information-sharing services (subject to certain exceptions including for fraud and for wilful breach of the ASA). The liability of both parties in relation to the wider agreement will be excluded in respect of indirect or consequential loss or any loss of profit or revenue, and ASL's liability to Walmart will be excluded where the loss is attributable to a breach by Walmart of the ASA or TSA (both preceding exclusions subject to certain exceptions including for fraud). The ASA will remain in force for two years following the date of its execution unless it is terminated by one of the parties following the insolvency of its counterparty, a material breach of its terms (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent the breach is remediable) or by one of the parties following its counterparty undergoing a force majeure event which has a material effect on the performance of the counterparty's obligations.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Agreements."
Subsubsection Text: Under the terms of the TMA, Walmart, as licensor, will grant ASL a licence to continue to use certain of Walmart's trade marks, domain names and brand-related intellectual property. The scope of the TMA is expected to include licences of the George, Scan & Go, Smart Price and Rollback brands, certain domain names, including George.com, as well as certain other Walmart-owned trade mark rights used by a member of the ASDA Group between October 2019 and the Acquisition Completion Date (the "Licensed

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: IP"). The TMA is expected to permit ASL to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted
Subsubsection Text: Under the TSA, Walmart is expected to agree to provide certain information technology services to ASL on a transitional basis with effect from the Acquisition Completion Date. The services are expected to comprise all information technology and telecommunications services (and related operational system processes) that Walmart Group Companies provided to the ASDA Group in the 12 months prior to the Acquisition Completion Date, and each such service is expected to be supplied by Walmart until the earlier of (i) migration of the relevant service as part of the separation of ASL from Walmart; and (ii) termination of the TSA in accordance with its terms by one of the parties (as summarised below). The services are arranged into six categories (referred to as "service towers," which relate to stores, supply chain, merchandising, back office, e-commerce and infrastructure/security) for charging and migration purposes. ASL is expected to have the right to terminate any service tower, or the TSA in its entirety, on three months' notice. In addition, either party is expected to have the right to terminate the TSA following the insolvency of its counterparty or a material breach of the terms of the TSA (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent applicable). The TSA is expected to include customary warranties concerning the corporate existence and capacity of the parties and an undertaking to provide information and participate in discussions in connection with the delivery of the services. Walmart is expected to agree to provide each service to a standard and in a manner that is consistent with Walmart's provision of the equivalent service in the 12 months prior to the Acquisition Completion Date. Walmart is not expected to be required to provide the services to, or to meet, any more onerous standard or service level. Walmart is expected to be required to use reasonable endeavours to obtain and maintain third-party consents that are required for the provision of the services. Where a third-party consent is not obtained or maintained, Walmart is not expected to be required to provide the relevant service (and the TSA will terminate in respect of the relevant service without liability on the part of Walmart) and the parties will work together to agree a workaround (including replacement, in-sourcing or early migration) in order to enable ASL to continue to receive the benefit of the affected service. All reasonable one-off or ongoing costs of obtaining and maintaining third-party consents or implementing workarounds are to be borne by ASL, subject to Walmart consulting with ASL before incurring these costs. The TSA is expected to require ASL and Walmart to agree to a separation plan within 120 days after the Acquisition Completion Date and cooperate in achieving separation. Separation costs (excluding internal costs of the Walmart Group) are to be borne by ASL. The charges for the TSA services for the first year following the Acquisition Completion Date are expected to be initially equal to and are capped at £142 million (excluding any VAT) (which the TSA is expected to state has been calculated according to the actual amount of the 2019 intra-group charges 233 ----- incurred by the ASDA Group in respect of the equivalent services), subject to specified adjustments set out in the TSA, and the cap on service charges subsequently rises by 1% per year thereafter. The charges payable for services in subsequent years are expected to be equal to the charges for such services for the previous contract year (subject to any reduction as summarised below) subject to an inflationary increase of 2% per year. The charges per service tower are split on a fixed cost and variable cost basis. The variable proportion of the charges is expected to reduce to the extent that ASL is able to achieve certain agreed milestones in its separation plan and ramp down usage of the relevant service tower. If ASL requires any service to be provided beyond a long stop date of three years from the Acquisition Completion Date, the charges for any remaining services will ratchet up by 10% every six months. The liability of the parties under the TSA is expected to be limited, where service-specific, to the amount of fees paid or payable in respect of the relevant service tower during the relevant contract year. In the case of liabilities that are not related to a specific service tower, the liability of the parties under the TSA is expected to be limited to the total amount of fees paid or payable during the relevant contract year. Each party's aggregate liability for each contract year is expected to be limited to the amount of fees paid or payable during the relevant contract year. These limitations are expected to be subject to limited exceptions, including in the case of fraud. Neither party is expected to be liable for any indirect or consequential losses or loss of profit or loss of revenue and, to the extent Walmart's breach is caused by a third-party default, Walmart's maximum liability to ASL is expected to be limited to the amount that Walmart can recover from the third party (or an equitable proportion thereof to reflect the loss suffered by the ASDA Group as compared to the Walmart Group). Walmart is not expected to be liable to ASL to the extent the relevant liability is caused by a failure on the part of the ASDA Group to perform its obligations under the TSA.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: IP"). The TMA is expected to permit ASL to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted
Subsubsection Text: Under the GSA, Walmart (or, if agreed between the parties to the GSA, an affiliate of Walmart) is expected to provide ASL with (or to procure the provision to ASL of) global sourcing services in relation to apparel and non-apparel, including identifying manufacturers and suppliers on behalf of ASL and supporting ASL's buyers in ASL's negotiation of prices, placing of orders and arranging of shipments. The term of the GSA is expected to be two years from the Acquisition Completion Date unless the parties agree to extend the GSA or the GSA is terminated earlier (in accordance with the termination rights summarised below). During the initial two-year term, ASL is to pay to Walmart a commission of 5% of the net first cost of merchandise procured by Walmart under the GSA. If the term is extended beyond the initial two-year term, ASL will pay a new rate of commission agreed between the parties. The GSA is expected to include customary warranties on the corporate existence and capacity of the parties. ASL is expected to indemnify Walmart against claims for product liability or intellectual property infringement resulting from goods sourced under the GSA (other than claims arising from the gross negligence or intentional tort of Walmart under the GSA). Each party is expected to have a right to terminate the GSA for material breach (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period) or insolvency of the other or a force majeure event which has a material adverse effect on the performance of the other party's obligations. Walmart is also expected to have the right to terminate (subject to a notice period) if ASL is not making material use of the services (determined by reference to a minimum purchase spend in respect of apparel and non-apparel shipped to ASL in a rolling 12-month period). ASL is expected to have the right to terminate the GSA for convenience on six months' written notice to Walmart. Neither party is expected to be liable in respect of loss of profit or revenue and indirect or consequential loss, and each party's liability to the other party is expected to be limited to an amount equal to 100% of the aggregate of all commission that has been paid or would be payable to Walmart in, in the case of the first contract year, that year, or, in any subsequent year, in the previous year (both preceding limits on liability subject to certain exceptions including liability for fraud, gross negligence of Walmart or any of its subcontractors and non-payment by ASL of due and undisputed charges).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: IP"). The TMA is expected to permit ASL to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted
Subsubsection Text: Under the TESA, a subsidiary of Walmart, TRE, is expected to continue following the Acquisition Completion Date to support Asda in the purchase of electricity and services that surround that purchase. TRE have been providing this service since 2008 to an Asda entity called Power 4 All ("P4A"). P4A is a licensed electricity supplier under the Electricity Act 1989 and that leads to a level of reporting which TRE will continue to support for the term of the TESA. There are also multiple forward purchase trades of energy in place with counterparties that are backed by Walmart Group guarantees. The intent is for Asda to procure electricity and services from a new third party and when those arrangements are in place it is intended that the trades are novated to the new supplier and the guarantees in respect to them will fall away. In addition, Walmart is expected to retain some additional Walmart Group guarantees in favour of Distribution Network 234 ----- Operators in respect to P4A payment obligations for the term of the TESA to allow Asda to arrange for replacement security (if required) to be put in place. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the specific services TRE will offer, the price and service levels are being negotiated. However, the principle has been agreed that TRE will continue to provide the services that it is currently supplying for the term of the TESA, together with some transitional support to allow Asda to take over the management of P4A. The parties intend the TESA to run until March 31, 2021 and no further.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: IP"). The TMA is expected to permit ASL to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted
Subsubsection Text: Under the TPD, the Seller is expected to indemnify the Purchaser in respect of any losses incurred by ASDA in respect of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme, provided that the indemnity will not apply if the losses arise from a voluntary act by the Purchaser (or any other affiliate of Bellis TopCo Limited), including failure by ASDA to comply with its obligations under the documentation governing the ASDA Group Pension Scheme Buy-In (described in Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations above). Walmart is party to the TPD and is expected to guarantee the obligations of the Seller in respect of this indemnity. The Purchaser and Bellis TopCo Limited are expected to agree to indemnify ASDA and Walmart in respect of any losses incurred by either of them in respect of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme if the losses arise from a voluntary act by the Purchaser (or any other affiliate of Bellis TopCo Limited), including failure by ASDA to comply with its obligations under the documentation governing the ASDA Group Pension Scheme Buy-In. Liability under both indemnity arrangements is expected to terminate on the later of: (i) three years after completion of the buyout of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme; (ii) the date of completion of the winding-up of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme; or (iii) (in respect of losses relate to tax only) five years after the Acquisition Completion Date. As described in in Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations above, as part of the arrangements in respect of the buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme ASL agreed to make a loan facility available to the trustees of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme. Under the TPD, in the event that a funding obligation arises under the loan facility which ASDA it is unable to satisfy, Walmart Inc is expected to agree to use reasonable endeavours to provide short-term funding to ASDA to allow ASDA to meet the funding obligation. Under the TPD, Bellis TopCo Limited and ASDA are expected to agree to use all reasonable endeavours to complete the buyout of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme as soon as reasonably practicable and to keep Walmart informed of progress towards completion.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: IP"). The TMA is expected to permit ASL to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted
Subsubsection Text: Under the terms of the Termination Deed, Walmart is expected to unconditionally and irrevocably agree in respect of itself, and on behalf of each other Walmart Group Company, and the Company is expected to unconditionally and irrevocably agree in respect of itself, and on behalf of each other member of the ASDA Group that any intra-group arrangement between any one or more Walmart Group Companies and any one or more members of the ASDA Group immediately prior to Completion are terminated upon Completion and each member of the Walmart Group and each member of the ASDA Group is released and discharged from all claims or demands by the other under, or in connection with, such intra-group arrangements (including without limitation claims for negligence but excluding liability for fraud), whether arising at or before the termination of such intra-group arrangement, in each case whether known or unknown to Walmart or ASDA (excluding amounts outstanding, or which are to be invoiced, under the terms of such intra-group arrangements by or from one party to the other for services performed prior to the Acquisition Completion Date). Certain arrangements are expected to be carved-out from this termination and release notably the (i) Acquisition Agreement, (ii) documents entered into pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement (including the Transitional Agreements), (iii) intra-group arrangements relating to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme; and (iv) any arrangements or guarantees between TRE, any member of the Walmart Group and/or any third party(ies) relating to the supply of energy or energy-related services in favour, or for the benefit, of ASDA. The Termination Deed is not expected to terminate, release or discharge obligations in respect of intra-group indebtedness between the Walmart Group and ASDA or in respect of intra-group trading payables and trading receivables between the Walmart Group and ASDA, which in each case are to be repaid or settled in accordance with the Acquisition Agreement.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: IP"). The TMA is expected to permit ASL to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted
Subsubsection Text: sub-licensees, including members of the ASDA Group, existing franchisees to which ASL has granted a licence of the Licensed IP under franchise agreements in place as at the date of the Acquisition Agreement and certain specified companies that are also owned by the Shareholders or funds managed by TDR Capital LLP, provided Walmart is given written notice and the sub-licence fulfils certain conditions, including that it is on terms that are no less onerous than the TMA. Additionally, the TMA is expected to provide that Walmart cannot unreasonably withhold, delay or condition consent for ASL to sub-license the Licensed IP to certain other entities including those that are controlled by the shareholders of ASL's ultimate holding company, provided that the sub-licence fulfils certain conditions, including that it is on terms no less onerous that the TMA. 231 ----- Manufacturing or packaging of goods bearing the Licensed IP may take place worldwide. The scope of the licence for sale, marketing and distribution purposes is expected to be the United Kingdom only (on an exclusive basis) and, for the George brand only, also specified countries in Europe in which ASL has been using the George brand prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement (on a non-exclusive basis). These licences are perpetual and irrevocable, subject to the termination rights summarised below. The TMA is also expected to include a non-exclusive licence to use the George brand in substantially the same way as the brand was used immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement in certain territories outside the United Kingdom and the specified European countries in which ASL has been selling George-branded goods under a specified third-party e-commerce fulfilment contract immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement (the "George RoW Licence"). Walmart is expected to grant ASL: (i) a limited transitional non-exclusive royalty-free licence in the United Kingdom in respect of the Walmart spark logo to allow ASL to continue to print (packaging for products for sale in the United Kingdom for a period of four months from the Acquisition Completion Date (and then to sell down those products, provided that ASL uses commercially reasonable efforts to sell off all products bearing such logo as soon as reasonably practicable following the expiry of a 12-month period and in any event within two years of the Acquisition Completion Date, although it is expected that ASL will not be required to remove from sale or destroy any packaging bearing such logo on goods which are available for purchase within any of ASL's stores at the end of the two year period); and (ii) a limited non-exclusive royalty-free transitional licence to use the phrase "Save Money Live Better" (in respect of new marketing communications and new internal communications in the United Kingdom) until the end of 2021 or, if earlier, the implementation of ASL's new business purpose. All use of the Licensed IP (other than use of the George mark in the United Kingdom) is expected to be required to be in the same manner and style of usage as used between October 2019 and the Acquisition Completion Date, except in respect of the George RoW Licence and licence of the Walmart spark logo, which must be used in the same way as such branding was used immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement and the Acquisition Completion Date respectively. The TMA is also expected to include: (i) an exclusive, royalty-free licence from ASL to Walmart of the Extra Special brand (that is owned by ASDA) to enable Walmart to continue selling, marketing and distributing products sold by Walmart under such brand on a perpetual and irrevocable basis in specified countries in Central America and in Mexico; and (ii) a transitional, non-exclusive, royalty-free licence from ASL to Walmart of other ASDA-owned brands for 12 months to continue printing packaging in respect of any other products sold, marketed or distributed by Walmart under such ASDA-owned brands, and in respect of the territories in respect of which such products were sold, marketed or distributed by Walmart, between October 2019 and the Acquisition Completion Date (and then a licence to sell down those products, provided that Walmart uses commercially reasonable efforts to sell off all products in packaging bearing such brands as soon as reasonably practicable following the expiry of such 12-month period and in any event within two years of the Acquisition Completion Date, although it is expected that Walmart will not be required to remove from sale or destroy any packaging bearing such logo on goods which are available for purchase within any of Walmart's stores at the end of the two year period). In respect of (ii) above, the relevant ASL brands must be used by Walmart in the same way and to the same extent as used by Walmart immediately prior to the Acquisition Completion Date. The licence to Walmart of the ASL brands referred to above is expected to be subject to similar sub-licencing and termination provisions as the licence to ASL of Licensed IP. ASL is expected not to be required to pay any royalties in respect of the above licence of the George brand (other than George RoW Licence), the licences of the Scan & Go, Rollback and Smart Price brands or the transitional licence of the Walmart spark logo and "Save Money Live Better" (other than a nominal £1 royalty fee). The George RoW Licence is expected to be royalty-free for up to 12 months (or earlier if ASL achieves a $25 million threshold of net sales revenue in respect of its use of the George brand under the George RoW Licence outside the United Kingdom and the European countries specified in the TMA) and thereafter subject to the parties, discussing in good faith and at arm's-length with a view to agreeing a commercially reasonable royalty (otherwise the George RoW Licence will be terminated). In respect of all other Licensed IP, ASL will be required to pay an annual royalty equal to 3.5% of the net sales revenue received by ASL and any sub-licensees in connection with the use of such Licensed IP. The TMA is expected to include restrictions and quality control covenants from ASL including ensuring that the products sold by ASL under the Licensed IP maintain certain standards, complying with brand guidelines in relation to visual style and formatting and limiting ASL's use of the Licensed IP and its ability to register the Licensed IP. These covenants are expected to include not committing or knowingly omitting acts which would bring the Licensed IP into disrepute or damage, or weaken or be detrimental to the Licensed IP in any material respect. ASL is also expected to be prevented from maintaining an online or ecommerce presence of any of the businesses (excluding the George business in the United Kingdom) in respect of which the Licensed IP is permitted to be used except in substantially the same manner and to substantially the same extent as the presence those businesses had in the period between October 2019 232 ----- and the Acquisition Completion Date (or in respect of the George RoW Licence, immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement). ASL is also expected to indemnify the Walmart Group against any losses resulting from use of the Licensed IP in material breach of the TMA and losses related to actual or alleged defect in products or services using the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go or Rollback branding), recalls of defective products and actual or alleged mislabelling or food safety issues related to the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go or Rollback brands). There is expected to be no cap on ASL's liability under these indemnities or limit on the heads of loss recoverable. The TMA is expected to include warranties on the corporate existence and capacity of the parties to enter into the TMA but no other warranties or representations (and any implied warranties, terms or conditions implied by statute or common law are excluded to the fullest extent permitted by law). The term of the TMA is expected to be perpetual (other than: (i) the George RoW Licence, which will terminate after 12 months if royalties are not agreed and which Walmart may terminate on a per country or per goods/services basis where Walmart itself intends to use or authorise the use of the relevant Licensed IP in that country (or if required by law), and (ii) in respect of the transitional licences described above). Either party is expected to be able to terminate the licences expected to be granted to ASL under the TMA on a per-licence basis following the insolvency of its counterparty or a material breach or repeated nonmaterial breaches of the terms of the TMA (in respect of the relevant licence and/or the relevant Licensed IP) (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent applicable). Walmart is also expected to have the right to terminate the licences granted to ASL under the TMA on a per-licence basis if ASL challenges the validity of the relevant Licensed IP or following certain change of control events, or with respect to specific trade marks or specific categories or sub-categories of goods or services on 30 days' notice if the relevant Licensed IP is not put to material use for a period of two years. ASL, but not Walmart, is expected to be permitted to terminate the licences granted to ASL under the TMA at any time without cause subject to a three-month notice period. The licence to Walmart of ASDA-owned brands is expected to be separately terminable, under similar terms.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Forecourt SPA
Subsubsection Text: On February 3, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into the Forecourt SPA with Bellis Forecourts Limited for the sale of the entire issued share capital of Acquisition 2 (or, if agreed between the parties, another member of the Bellis Group (other than Bellis Forecourts or Holdco) or a member of the ASDA Group that is or has become the owner of the Forecourt Business (including a newly incorporated company) (a "Forecourt Business Transferee")) (following such company's acquisition of the Forecourt Business). Completion of the Forecourt SPA is conditional on: (i) completion of the Acquisition; (ii) CMA approval of the Acquisition and the IEO ceasing to be in effect (and. as a result, there being no law in effect 235 ----- preventing the sale of the Forecourt Business) and (iii) the seller and the buyer each being satisfied (acting reasonably and in good faith) that Acquisition 2 (or, if relevant, the Forecourt Business Transferee) has acquired the Forecourt Business. Completion of the Forecourt SPA will take place (on the date agreed between the parties) as soon as reasonably practicable once such conditions have been satisfied (or, if applicable, waived). The consideration payable by the buyer is £750,000,000 less any value ascribed by the parties to any Excluded Forecourt(s) or related assets located at an Excluded Forecourt (if any) that are disposed of or agreed to be disposed of prior to completion of the Forecourt SPA (which value will be agreed between the parties to the Forecourt SPA or, in the absence of agreement, based on any price paid for an Excluded Forecourt by a third party or (where this does not apply and in the absence of agreement otherwise) based on the relative fuel volumes sold at the Forecourt Assets in the financial year ended December 31, 2019), subject to a working capital adjustment to the extent the actual aggregate net amount of petrol stock, cash, trade payables and trade receivables acquired by Acquisition 2 (or the Forecourt Business Transferee) (together, "working capital items") exceed or are less than an agreed aggregate value of working capital items that represents a normalised level of working capital for the Forecourt Business. The Forecourt SPA provides that this consideration will become due to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer at completion of the Forecourt SPA, but will be left outstanding and will be payable in cash within five business days of completion. The Forecourt SPA sets out the key terms to apply to the transfer of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 or the Forecourt Business Transferee and for the parties to consult on various matters relating to the structure and detail of the transfer of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 or the Forecourt Business Transferee. The Forecourt SPA includes customary warranties on capacity and ownership of the shares in Acquisition 2 or the Forecourt Business Transferee provided by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and on capacity to enter into the Forecourt SPA from Bellis Forecourts Limited. The maximum aggregate liability of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer under the Forecourt SPA is capped at the consideration payable to it under the Forecourt SPA. The Forecourt SPA provides for the parties to agree an appropriate regime for the provision (by a member of the Bellis Group or the ASDA Group) of customary warranties in relation to the Forecourt Business (from which Bellis Forecourt will (directly or indirectly) benefit) and indemnities customary to a business sale (including in relation to pre-completion liabilities of the Forecourt Business) prior to completion of the Forecourt SPA.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: EG Forecourt SPA
Subsubsection Text: On February 3, 2021, Property Newco and Bellis TopCo Limited and Euro Garages Limited entered into the EG Forecourt SPA for the indirect sale of the Forecourt Business to Euro Garages Limited (or a member of the EG Group) by way of a sale of the entire issued share capital of Holdco (once the acquisition by Bellis Forecourts Limited of the shares in Acquisition 2 or the Forecourt Business Transferee has completed pursuant to the Forecourt SPA) (or, if agreed between the parties, another member of the Bellis Group or the ASDA Group that is the direct or indirect owner of the Forecourt Business (including, in connection with the novation of Property Newco's obligations as seller under the EG Forecourt SPA to the shareholders of Property Newco, the shares in Property Newco)). Completion of the EG Forecourt SPA is subject to the same conditions as the Forecourt SPA and is, in addition, subject to Bellis Forecourts Limited acquiring all of the shares in Acquisition 2 or the Forecourt Business Transferee. Completion of the EG Forecourt SPA will take place (on the date agreed between Euro Garages Limited and Property Newco) as soon as reasonably practicable once such conditions have been satisfied (or, if applicable, waived). The consideration payable by Euro Garages Limited is an amount equivalent to the consideration payable by Bellis Forecourts Limited under the Forecourt SPA less the aggregate amount of indebtedness of Holdco, Bellis Forecourts Limited and its subsidiaries as at completion of the EG Forecourt SPA (to the extent such indebtedness has not already been taken into account in calculating the working capital adjustment referred to in the summary of the Forecourt SPA above), which will become payable on completion. The EG Forecourt SPA sets out the key terms to apply to the transfer of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 (or the Forecourt Business Transferee) and for the parties to the EG Forecourt SPA to consult on various matters relating to the structure and detail of the transfer of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 (or the Forecourt Business Transferee). The EG Forecourt SPA includes customary warranties on capacity and ownership of the shares in Holdco provided by Property Newco and on capacity to enter into the EG Forecourt SPA from Euro Garages Limited. The maximum aggregate liability of Property Newco and Bellis TopCo Limited under the EG Forecourt SPA is capped at the aggregate of the consideration payable by the buyer under the EG Forecourt SPA and the aggregate of any indebtedness of Holdco, Bellis Forecourts Limited and its 236 ----- subsidiaries. The EG Forecourt SPA provides for the parties to agree an appropriate regime for the provision (by a member of the Bellis Group or the ASDA Group) of customary warranties in relation to the Forecourt Business (from which EG Group will (directly or indirectly) benefit) and indemnities customary to a business sale (including in relation to pre-completion liabilities of the Forecourt Business) prior to completion of the EG Forecourt SPA.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: ASDA Leases
Subsubsection Text: To secure the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, certain entities within the ASDA Group are expected to grant first priority mortgages, fixed charges or standard securities, as applicable, over the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent required thereunder, certain Substitute Retail Assets, as well as first-ranking pledges on the Designated Bank Accounts. Prior to the execution of these mortgages, fixed charges, standard securities and pledges, as applicable, entities within the ASDA Group are expected to enter into lease agreements in respect of the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets on substantially the following terms: Demise ...................................** The whole (or substantially the whole) of the landlord's reversionary (or, as applicable, registered) interest. Term .......................................** _Warehouse lease: 20 years. _Store lease: either 20 years or 10 years less 1 day (with a put and_ call option for the grant of a reversionary lease (or, as applicable, extension of the Term) of 10 years plus 1 day exercisable in mid2022 onwards). _Store lease: the store lease (for a lease term of 20 years) contains_ an option to renew (or, as applicable, extend the Term) for a further 10 years. The renewal lease (or, as applicable, extended lease) is expected to contain one further option to renew (or, as applicable, extend) for a further 10 years. The store reversionary (or, as applicable, extended) lease of 10 years plus 1 day contains an option to renew (or, as applicable, extend) for a further 10 years. The renewal lease (or, as applicable, extended lease) will contain one further option to renew for a further 10 years. Warehouse lease: the warehouse lease is expected to contain an option to renew (or, as applicable, extend) for a further 10 years. The renewal lease (or, as applicable, extended lease) is expected to contain one further option to renew for a further 10 years. Landlord and Tenant Act** The lease benefits from security of tenure (not applicable for the 1954 ........................................** leases of the Scottish assets). Pre-emption ...........................** The tenant benefits from a right of first offer prior to certain disposals of the landlord's reversionary interest. Alienation ...............................** Disposals of part, other than certain underlettings, are expected to be prohibited. Certain underletting and the grant of other occupational rights of part are permitted (in some cases without consent, otherwise consent is required). Certain disposals of whole are expected to be permitted either subject to or without landlord consent. Alterations .............................** The lease is expected to permit non-structural and structural alterations and many alterations are permitted without the need for landlord consent. _Warehouse lease: the lease is expected to set a maximum capital_ expenditure below which consent is not required. _Store lease: the lease is expected to set permitted alterations (not_ requiring consent) by reference to a prescribed list and (while the lease remains in the ASDA Group) by reference to a maximum gross internal area added by such alterations, subject to certain exceptions. 237 ----- Repair .....................................** The lease is expected to contain a repairing covenant requiring the tenant to keep the premises in good and substantial repair and condition subject to limited exceptions. Yield up ..................................** _Warehouse lease: alterations are expected to be reinstated by the tenant at the end of the term of the lease unless otherwise agreed by the landlord, acting reasonably. _Store lease: there is not expected to be an obligation to reinstate_ alterations (unless they are not complete at the end of the term of the lease). Insurance ...............................** The landlord is expected to insure, save in circumstances where the original tenant (being an ASDA Group entity or a group company) is tenant in which case the tenant is to insure (unless it elects not to). The lease is expected to contain rent suspension provisions (unless the tenant insures) and termination rights which apply in certain circumstances where reinstatement of the premises as a result of damage caused by insured risks has occurred and such damage has not been reinstated. The lease is expected to contain provisions dealing with damage or destruction to the premises caused by uninsured risks. Forfeiture ...............................** The landlord is expected to have the right to forfeit the lease if: - The rent or any other sum payable under the lease remains unpaid for 15 business days; - The tenant materially fails to comply with the terms of the lease; or - The tenant or its guarantor suffers an insolvency event (unless, in respect of a guarantor's insolvency event, the tenant meets a minimum rating criteria). The lease is expected to contain mortgagee protection provisions which require the landlord to provide advance notice of intended forfeiture to the tenant's mortgagee. Rent review ............................** The lease is expected to contain an RPI linked rent review, calculated annually with a minimum 1% and maximum 3% uplift. On commencement of any renewal lease (excluding the Store reversionary lease) the passing rent is expected to be re-based to the open market rent. Unless otherwise stated the terms provided above are materially the same for the leases of the Select Retail Assets, the Substitute Retail Assets and the Warehouse Assets. Where the foregoing states that consent is required, the consent requirements are, subject to certain exceptions, not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed. In respect of Dagenham (a Substitute Retail Asset) a peppercorn rent lease will also be entered into on substantially similar terms to the store lease, to demise certain land used by that store but held by a separate group entity to the ASDA Group entity that owns the main store. The lease in respect of the main store and the peppercorn lease will be linked for the purposes of assignment, charging, renewal, forfeiture and other termination purposes. 238 ----- In respect of Heston and Dartford (both Warehouse Assets), entities within the ASDA Group are expected to enter into leases on substantially the following terms: Demise ...................................** The whole of the landlord's reversionary interest. Term .......................................** 18 months with (a) a rolling tenant break once the landlord interest leaves the ASDA Group and (b) a rolling landlord break exercisable at any time after 12 months.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Landlord and Tenant Act
Subsubsection Text: 1954 ........................................** The lease does not benefit from security of tenure. Pre-emption ...........................** None. Alienation ...............................** Alienation is limited to: (i) an assignment of whole to ASL; (ii) a licence or commercial arrangement with a person or company with whom the tenant carries on a lawful and bona fide professional or business relationship; and (iii) group sharing. Alterations .............................** Prohibited. Repair .....................................** The lease is expected to contain a repairing covenant requiring the tenant to keep the premises in good and substantial repair and condition with the exception of fair wear and tear, subject to limited exceptions. Yield up ..................................** None other than terminating any derivative occupational interests. Insurance ...............................** The landlord is expected to insure save in circumstances where the original tenant (being an ASDA Group entity or a group company) is tenant in which case the tenant is to insure (unless it elects not to). In the event of damage or destruction to the premises (either as a result of an insured or uninsured risk) there are expected to be rights to terminate the lease in certain circumstances. Forfeiture ...............................** The landlord is expected to have the right to forfeit the lease if: - The rent or any other sum payable under the lease remains unpaid for 15 business days; - The tenant materially fails to comply with the terms of the lease; or - The tenant or its guarantor suffers an insolvency event (unless, in respect of a guarantor's insolvency event, the tenant meets a minimum rating criteria). The lease is expected to contain mortgagee protection provisions which require the landlord to provide advance notice of intended forfeiture to the tenant's mortgagee. Rent review ............................** None. In respect of Grangemouth, a peppercorn rent lease will also be entered into on terms substantially similar to the warehouse lease, subject to the terms of the lease under which the aftermentioned separate leasehold interest is held, to demise certain land used by this warehouse but held as a separate leasehold interest and for the purposes of laying and retaining a pipeline with ancillary connections for the purposes of discharging surface water from the warehouse premises to the waste water network. The lease in respect of the main warehouse and the peppercorn is expected to be linked for the purposes of assignation, charging, renewal and irritancy purposes. 239 ----- The aggregate annual rental pricing for the leases of the Warehouse Assets as per Eastdil Secured's opinion of pricing and the aggregate annual rental pricing for the Select Retail Assets and the Substitute Retail Assets (but excluding the addition (where applicable) of 5% to the base shell rental pricing to reflect the existence of a petrol station forecourt) as per Newsteer's Broker's Opinion of Pricing are set out below:

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Bridge Facilities** **Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer, as borrower, entered into a senior secured bridge facilities agreement dated February 5, 2021 with, among others, Barclays Bank plc, Bank of America Europe Designated Activity Company, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, HSBC Bank plc, Lloyds Bank plc, Morgan Stanley Bank International Limited and Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. trading as Rabobank London as mandated lead arrangers, Barclays Bank plc as agent (the "Agent") and Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch (the "Security Agent") as security agent (the "Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement"). The Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement provides for £550,000,000 and £850,000,000 (euro equivalent) senior secured bridge loan facilities, each made available to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (the "Senior Secured Bridge Facilities"). The Facility (EUR) (as defined in the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement) is subject to certain redenomination mechanics pursuant to which the Facility (EUR) will be redenominated into Euro in the event that closing occurs prior to pricing, with alternative redenomination mechanics in the event that closing occurs after pricing, in each case in accordance with the terms of the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement). All amounts borrowed under the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities are required to be applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards: (i) satisfaction of the consideration payable for the Acquisition (including any interest payments, completion account-related adjustments and purchase price adjustments (however structured)) and any other amounts payable under the Acquisition Documents (as defined in the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement); (ii) refinancing or otherwise discharging any existing indebtedness of the ASDA Group (including backstopping or providing cash-cover in respect of any letters of credit, guarantees, performance bonds or ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements) and paying any related breakage costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such refinancing, discharge and/or the Acquisition; (iii) financing or refinancing the payment of any transaction costs or paying any other related fees, costs and expenses; and/or (iv) making any payments contemplated by the Tax Structure Memorandum, the Funds Flow Statement (each as defined in the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement) or any other documents relating to the Transactions. See "The Transactions—The Financing—Utilisations of Senior _Facilities, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility."_ On or about the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities are, if drawn on the Acquisition Completion Date, expected to be repaid at par, plus accrued and unpaid interest, with the proceeds from the Offering. See "Use of Proceeds."

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Senior Bridge Facility Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Notes Issuer, as borrower, entered into a senior bridge facility agreement dated February 5, 2021 with, among others, Barclays Bank plc, Bank of America Europe Designated Activity Company, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, HSBC Bank plc, Lloyds Bank plc, Morgan Stanley Bank International Limited and Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. trading as Rabobank London as mandated lead arrangers, the Agent and the Security Agent (the "Senior Bridge Facility Agreement"). The Senior Bridge Facility Agreement provides for a £700,000,000 (euro equivalent) senior bridge loan facility made available to the Senior Notes Issuer (the "Senior Bridge Facility"). The Facility (as defined in the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement) is subject to certain redenomination mechanics pursuant to which the Facility will be redenominated into Euro in the event that closing occurs prior to pricing, with alternative redenomination mechanics in the event that closing occurs after pricing, in each case in accordance with the terms of the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement. All amounts borrowed under the Senior Bridge Facility are required to be applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards: (i) satisfaction of the consideration payable for the Acquisition (including any interest payments, completion account-related adjustments and purchase price adjustments (however structured)) and any other amounts payable under the Acquisition Documents (as defined in the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement); (ii) refinancing or otherwise discharging any existing indebtedness of the ASDA Group (including backstopping or providing cash-cover in respect of any letters of credit, guarantees, performance bonds or ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements) and paying any related breakage costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses 241 ----- payable in connection with such refinancing, discharge and/or the Acquisition; (iii) financing or refinancing the payment of any transaction costs or paying any other related fees, costs and expenses; and/or (iv) making any payments contemplated by the Tax Structure Memorandum, the Funds Flow Statement (each as defined in the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement) or any other documents relating to the Transactions. See "The Transactions—The Financing—Utilisations of Senior Bridge Facility." On or about the Issue Date, the Senior Bridge Facility is, if drawn on the Acquisition Completion Date, expected to be repaid at par, plus accrued and unpaid interest, with the proceeds from the Offering. See "Use of Proceeds."

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the financing of the Acquisition, on February 5, 2021 the Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into a senior facilities agreement with, among others, Barclays Bank PLC, Bank of America Europe Designated Activity Company, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, HSBC Bank plc, Lloyds Bank plc, Morgan Stanley Bank International Limited, Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. trading as Rabobank London, Bank of China Limited, London Branch, Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, London Branch, Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A., London Branch, National Westminster Bank Plc and SMBC Bank International PLC as mandated lead arrangers, the Agent and the Security Agent (the "Senior Facilities Agreement"). The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for (i) a senior term loan facility in principal amount of up to £195,000,000 ("Facility A"), (ii) euro- and sterling-denominated senior term loan facilities (collectively, "Facility B") in an aggregate amount of £1,390,000,000 (equivalent) and (iii) revolving credit facilities in a principal amount of £500,000,000 (the "Original Revolving Facility 1") and £190,000,000 (the "Original

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: Capitalised terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Senior Facilities Agreement.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Revolving Facility 2," together with the Original Revolving Facility 1, the "Revolving Credit Facilities,"
Subsubsection Text: Facility A and Facility B are expected to be utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer on the Acquisition Completion Date and the proceeds of such utilisation are required to be applied (directly or indirect) in or towards financing the Acquisition. The Revolving Credit Facilities may be utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of such facilities, in sterling, euro or U.S. dollars and certain other currencies readily available in the amount required and freely convertible into sterling in the Relevant Interbank Market (subject to obtaining consent of the relevant lenders under the relevant Revolving Credit Facility), by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of Letters of Credit and by way of Ancillary Facilities or Fronted Ancillary Facilities (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement). If we settle the Offering after the Acquisition Completion Date, a portion of the initial drawings under Facility B under the Senior Facilities Agreement will be repaid with the proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes. The Senior Facilities Agreement is expected to be amended and restated either prior to or shortly following the Acquisition Completion Date to make certain changes, including making Facility B an all eurodenominated facility (the "Amended SFA").

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Revolving Facility 2," together with the Original Revolving Facility 1, the "Revolving Credit Facilities,"
Subsubsection Text: All amounts borrowed under Facility A and Facility B are required to be applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards: (i) satisfaction of the consideration payable for the Acquisition (including any interest payments, completion account-related adjustments and purchase price adjustments (however structured)) and any other amounts payable under the Acquisition Documents (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement); (ii) refinancing or otherwise discharging any existing indebtedness of the ASDA Group (including backstopping or providing cash-cover in respect of any letters of credit, guarantees, performance bonds or ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements) and paying any related breakage costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such refinancing, discharge and/or the Acquisition; (iii) financing or refinancing the payment of any transaction costs or paying any other related fees, costs and expenses; and/or (iv) making any 242 ----- payments contemplated by the Tax Structure Memorandum, the Funds Flow Statement (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) or any other documents relating to the Transactions. The Revolving Credit Facilities may be used for: (i) financing or refinancing: (A) the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Group (including, without limitation, the financing or refinancing of capital expenditure, any permitted acquisitions (including the Acquisition), investments, jointventures, restructuring costs, operational restructurings and reorganisation requirements of the Group); (B) the financial indebtedness of the Group, the ASDA Group or any acquired target group; and (C) any required arrangement, up-front or original issue discount fees or similar fees or any additional original issue discount fees or other fees arising as a result of any Market Flex (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement), any ticking fees required to be paid in connection with, and any interest accruing under the documents relating to the Transactions or any other Debt Document (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined below)) or any other fees, costs and expenses; (ii) to backstop existing ancillary facilities, letters of credit and/or hedging arrangements of the ASDA Group (if applicable) and financing or refinancing any other transactions contemplated in connection with the Acquisition; (iii) financing any other payments identified in the Tax Structure Memorandum or the Funds Flow Statement (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) or the documents relating to the Transactions; and (iv) financing or refinancing the costs relating to the Acquisition and any other costs and expenses incurred in relation to the purposes referred to in paragraphs (i) to (iii) above. In addition to the Senior Facilities, the Senior Facilities Agreement includes (subject to the limitation on indebtedness covenant and permissions thereunder) the ability to establish an additional facility ("Additional Facility") at any time provided certain conditions under the Senior Facilities Agreement are met, including, without limitation: (i) Indebtedness incurred thereunder constitute Permitted Indebtedness on the Applicable Test Date; (ii) no Material Event of Default (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) is continuing as at the Additional Facility Commencement Date or Applicable Test Date (as applicable) for such Additional Facility; (iii) the Additional Facility complies with any applicable margin, maturity and amortisation restrictions set out in the Senior Facilities Agreement and (iv) the Additional Facility shall rank _pari passu with or junior to Facility A and Facility B._

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Revolving Facility 2," together with the Original Revolving Facility 1, the "Revolving Credit Facilities,"
Subsubsection Text: Facility A and Facility B are available to be utilised from (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement to and including the last day of the Certain Funds Period (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement). The Revolving Credit Facilities may be utilised from (and including) the Closing Date (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) to and including the date falling one month prior to the respective termination dates of the Revolving Credit Facilities. The Original Revolving Facility 1 has a termination date falling 54 months after the Closing Date, and the Original Revolving Facility 2 has a termination date falling 364 days after the Closing Date. The Original Revolving Facility 2 may not be utilised unless on the proposed Utilisation Date the Original Revolving Facility 1 is utilised in full (but, for the avoidance of doubt, the Original Revolving Facility 2 may be utilised contemporaneously with the Original Revolving Facility 1).

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Revolving Facility 2," together with the Original Revolving Facility 1, the "Revolving Credit Facilities,"
Subsubsection Text: Utilisations of the Senior Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Revolving Facility 2," together with the Original Revolving Facility 1, the "Revolving Credit Facilities,"
Subsubsection Text: Loans under the Senior Facilities will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR in respect of loans denominated in euro, and for loans denominated other than in euro, LIBOR, plus an applicable margin, which in each case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Debt to Consolidated EBITDA (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) (the "Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio"). Furthermore, the applicable margin shall be subject to further adjustment upwards or downwards depending on whether the Group's ESG Agency Rating (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) (the "ESG Agency Rating") is more or less favourable, respectively, than the initial ESG Agency Rating obtained by the Group following the Closing Date. If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under Facility B and the Revolving Credit Facilities (as applicable). If LIBOR is less than zero, LIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under Facility A and the Revolving Credit Facilities (as applicable). A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of each Revolving Credit Facility from the Closing Date (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) to the end of the availability period applicable to the relevant Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 30% of the applicable 243 ----- margin for the relevant Revolving Credit Facility. Commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears, on the last day of the availability period applicable to the relevant Revolving Credit Facility and if the relevant Revolving Facility is cancelled in full, on the date on which the relevant commitments under that Revolving Facility are cancelled. Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% on the defaulted amount.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS

Subsubsection Text: First anniversary of the Closing Date 0 Second anniversary of the Closing Date 5 Third anniversary of the Closing Date 10 Fourth anniversary of the Closing Date 10 Termination Date applicable to Facility A 75 (or, if different, such percentage (being the date that is 54 months after the amount as is required to repay the Closing Date) remaining aggregate outstanding principal amount of all Facility A Loans) The aggregate principal amount of any Facility B Loan(s) still outstanding on the date that is five years from the Closing Date (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) shall be repaid in full on that date. In respect of the Revolving Credit Facilities, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings.
